direction.raw_text: - SKY - DAY The camera is moving toward an Indian city. We are high and far away, only the sound of the wind as we grow nearer and nearer, and through the passing clouds these words appear: "No man's life can be encompassed in one telling. There is no way to give each year its allotted weight, to include each event, each person who helped to shape a lifetime. What can be done is to be faithful in spirit to the record, and to try to find one's way to the heart of the man..." And now we are approaching the city, the squalor of the little shanty dwellings around the outskirts, the shadows of large factories... And as we move nearer, coursing over the parched terrain, the tiny fields of cultivation, strands of sound are woven through the main titles, borne on the wind, images from the life we are seeking: British: "Who the hell is he?!", lower class British: "I don't know, sir."... "My name is Gandhi. Mohandas K. Gandhi."... A woman's voice, tender, soft: "You are my best friend, my highest guru... and my sovereign lord."... A man (Gandhi): "I am asking you to fight!"... An angry aristocratic English voice: "At home children are writing 'essays' about him!"... the sound of massed rifle fire, screams...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CITY - DAY And now we are over the city, coming in toward a particular street in the affluent suburbs of New Delhi... there are a few cars (it is 1948), and we are closing on a milling crowd near the entrance to one of the larger homes. We see saris, Indian tunics, a sprinkling of "Gandhi" caps, several tongas (two-wheeled, horse-drawn taxis)... the shreds of sound continue -- American woman, flirtatious, intimate: "You're the only man I know who makes his own clothes." Gandhi's laugh... The sound of rioting, women's cries and screams of terror... An American voice: "This man of peace"... And as the titles end we begin to pick up the sounds of the street... an Australian and his wife, a BBC correspondent... all in passing, as the camera finally closes and holds on one young man: Godse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Godse steps from a tonga as the crowd begins to move toward an entrance-way at the back of a long wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In contrast to those about him, there is tension in Godse's face, an air of danger in his movements. He glances at two policemen who are talking casually, absorbed in their own gossip -- then he looks back at another tonga that pulls up just behind his. Two young men (Apte and Karkare) meet Godse's gaze, and again we get the sense of imminent danger. They descend and pay their driver absently, their eyes watching the crowd. Sitting along in the shadows of a stationary tonga a little distance down the street an elderly man (Prakash) with a short, close-cropped beard and the taut, sunken flesh of a cadaver is watching... Apte and Karkare look back at him. There is just the slightest acknowledgment and then Prakash lifts his eyes to the gate, as though to tell them to be about their business.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He will be saying prayers in the garden -- just follow the others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Godse hesitates before approaching the two gardeners who nonchalantly flank the entrance. He stiffens himself, cautiously touches something under his khaki jacket, then glances back at the stoic face of Prakash. Prakash's gaze is as firm and unrelenting as a death's head. Godse turns back, wetting his lips nervously, then moves into the middle of a group going through the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BIRLA HOUSE - EXTERIOR - TWILIGHT A fairly numerous crowd is gathering here, informally filling the area on one side of a walk that leads to a little pavilion -- some devout, some curious, some just eager to be near the great man. Godse moves forward through them toward the front just as hushed voices begin to remark -- "I see him." "Here he comes!" "Which one is Manu?"... Apte and Karkare move to different sides of Godse, staying a little behind, their movements sly and wary, aware of people watching. Featuring Gandhi. We see him distantly through the crowd. The brown, wiry figure cloaked only in loincloth and shawl, still weak from his last fast and moving without his customary spring and energy as he is supported by his two grand nieces, his "walking sticks," Manu and Abha. We do not see him clearly until the very last moment -- only glimpses of him as he smiles, and exchanges little jokes with some of the crowd and the two young women who support him, occasionally joining his hands together in greeting to someone in particular, then once more proceeding with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera keeps moving closer, and the point of view is always Godse's, but Gandhi is always in profile or half obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. We hear the occasional click of a camera, and we intercut with shots of Godse moving tensely up through the crowd, of Apte and Karkare on the periphery of the crowd, watching with sudden fear and apprehension, like men paralysed by the presence of danger. Featuring Godse. He slides through to the very front rank. His breathing is short and there is perspiration around the sides of his temples. And now, for an instant we see Gandhi close from his point of view. He is only a few steps away, but turned to speak to someone on the other side, and Manu half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly, tension lining his face -- then he moves boldly out into Gandhi's path, bumping Manu, knocking a vessel for incense from her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignoring her, his nerves even more taut, Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma. And now we see Gandhi in full shot. The cheap glasses, the nut-brown head, the warm, eager eyes. He smiles and joins his hands together to exchange Godse's greeting. Godse moves his right hand rapidly from the stance of prayer to his jacket, in an instant -- it holds a gun, and he fires point blank at Gandhi -- loud, startling -- once, twice... thrice. Gandhi's white shawl is stained with blood as he falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amid the screams and sounds of chaos we dissolve through to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) Brother -- Bapu is already late for prayers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, God... oh, God...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW DELHI - EXTERIOR - DAY Close shot. Soldier's feet moving in the slow step, half- step, step of the requiem march... Full shot. The huge funeral procession -- crowds such as have never been seen on the screen massed along the route. People everywhere, clinging to monuments, lamp standards, trees -- and as the camera pulls back from the funeral cortege it reveals more and more... and more. All are silent. We only hear a strange, rhythmic shuffling, pierced by an occasional wail of grief. We see the soldiers and sailors lining the route, their hands locked together in one seemingly endless chain. We see the two hundred men of the Army, Navy and Air Force drawing the Army weapon-carrier that bears the body of Gandhi. And finally we see Gandhi lying on the weapon-carrier, surrounded by flowers, a tiny figure in this ocean of grief and reverence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KINGSWAY - NEW DELHI - EXTERIOR - DAY Commentators from all over the world are covering the ceremony. We concentrate on one, let us say the most distinguished American broadcaster of the time, Edward R. Murrow, who sits on the makeshift platform, a microphone marked "CBS" before him, describing the procession as technicians and staff move quietly around him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (clipped, weighted) ...The object of this massive tribute died as he had always lived -- a private man without wealth, without property, without official title or office...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW DELHI - EXTERIOR - DAY As the cortege continues on its way, we get shots of the marching soldiers, of the faces of Sikhs, and Tamils, Anglo- Indians, Moslems from the north, Marathas from the south, blue-eyed Parsees, dark-skinned Keralans...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the throng, following the weapon-carrier bier of Gandhi as it slowly inches its way along the Kingsway. Mountbatten, tall, handsome, bemedalled, walks at the head of dignitaries from many lands... and behind them a broad mass of Indians. For a moment we see their sandalled feet moving along the roadway and realize their quiet, rhythmic shuffling is the only noise this vast assemblage has produced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the crowd following the bier we pick out the tall, English figure of Mirabehn, dressed in a sari, her face taut in a grief that seems ready to break like the Ganges in flood. Near her a tall, heavy-set man, Germanic, still powerful of build and mien though his white hair and deep lines suggest a man well into his sixties (Kallenbach). He too marches with a kind of numb air of loss that is too personal for national mourning. On the edge of the street an American newspaperman (Walker) watches as the bier passes him. He has been making notes, but his hand stops now and we see the profile of Gandhi from his point of view as the weapon-carrier silently rolls by. It is personal, close. Walker clenches his teeth and there is moisture in his eyes as he looks down. He tries to bring his attention to his pad again, but his heart is not in it and he stares with hollow emptiness at the street and the horde of passing feet following the bier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera picks out those who ride on the weapon-carrier with Gandhi's body... the stout, blunt, but now shattered Patel, Gandhi's son, Devadas, the strong, almost fierce face of Maulana Azad, now angry at the Gods themselves... and finally Pandit Nehru -- a face with the strength of a hero, the sensitivity of a poet, and now wounded like the son of a loving father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A news truck is parked in the mass of the crowd. As the cortege nears, the photographers on it stand to snap their pictures. There is a newsreel crew center. The camera features a woman photographer (Margaret Bourke-White) who sits with her legs dangling over the side of the truck, her famous camera held loosely in her hand, un-regarded, as she watches the body of Gandhi approach. The intelligent features are betrayed by the emotion in her eyes. For an instant we see Gandhi from her point of view, and read the personal impact it has on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera is high and we see the cortege from the rear, moving off down the vast esplanade, its narrowing path parting the sea of humanity like a long trail across a weaving plain... and as the shuffling sound of sandalled feet fades in the distance we dissolve through to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mahatma Gandhi was not a commander of great armies nor ruler of vast lands, he could boast no scientific achievements, no artistic gift... Yet men, governments and dignitaries from all over the world have joined hands today to pay homage to this little brown man in the loincloth who led his country to freedom...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pope Pius, the Archbishop of Canterbury, President Truman, Chiang Kai-shek, The Foreign Minister of Russia, the President of France... are among the millions here and abroad who have lamented his passing. In the words of General George C. Marshall, the American Secretary of State, "Mahatma Gandhi had become the spokesman for the conscience of mankind..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a man who made humility and simple truth more powerful than empires." And Albert Einstein added, "Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this ever in flesh and blood walked upon this earth."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... but perhaps to this man of peace, to this fighter who fought without malice or falsehood or hate, the tribute he would value most has come from General Douglas McArthur: "If civilization is to survive," the General said this morning, "all men cannot fail to adopt Gandhi's belief that the use of force to resolve conflict is not only wrong but contains within itself the germ of our own self-destruction."...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps for the rest of us, the most satisfying comment on this tragedy comes from the impudent New York PM which today wrote, "There is still hope for a world which reacts as reverently as ours has to the death of a man like Gandhi."...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - SOUTH AFRICA - EXTERIOR - NIGHT With the camera high we see a railroad track stretching out across a darkly verdant plain, and suddenly the whistle of a train as its engine and light sweep under the camera, startling us as it sweeps across the moonlit landscape. Tracking with the train. We begin at the guard's van, dwelling for a moment on the words "South African Railways," then pass on to the dimly lit Third Class coaches in the rear of the train, moving past the crowded Blacks and Indians in the spare wooden accommodation... There are two or three such coaches, then a Second Class coach... cushioned seats, better lighting, a smattering of Europeans: farmers, clerks, young families. Their clothes indicate the date: the early 1890s. The conductor is working his way through this coach, checking tickets... The track continues to the First Class coach -- linen over the seats, well-lit luxurious compartments. We pass a single European, and then come to rest on the back of a young Indian dressed in a rather dandified Victorian attire, and reading as a Black porter stows his luggage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SOUTH AFRICAN RAILWAYS - INTERIOR - NIGHT Featuring the young Indian. It is the young Gandhi -- a full head of hair, a somewhat sensuous face, only the eyes help us to identify him as the man we saw at Birla House, the figure on the bier in Delhi. He is lost in his book and there is a slight smile on his face as though what he reads intrigues and surprises him. He grins suddenly at some insight, then looks out of the window, weighing the idea. As he does the European passes the compartment and stops dead on seeing an Indian face in the First Class section. The porter glances at the European nervously. Gandhi pivots to the porter, holding his place in the book, missing the European, who has moved on down the corridor, altogether. We see the cover of the book: The Kingdom of God is Within You, by Leo Tolstoy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The porter has glanced down the corridor, where from his point of view we can just glimpse the European talking with the conductor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up suddenly then turns back quickly to his work. Gandhi glances at the door to see what has frightened him so. The European and the conductor push open the door and stride in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is incredulous that he is being addressed in such a manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's taken out the ticket but there is a bit of bluster in his attitude and it is cut off by a cold rebuff from the European.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures to the back of the train. Gandhi is nonplussed and beginning to feel a little less sure of himself. The porter, wanting to avoid trouble, reaches for Gandhi's suitcases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches into this waistcoat and produces a card which he presents to the conductor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is still puzzled by his belligerence, but is beginning to react to it, this time with a touch of irony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Porter stares -- amazed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks out of the compartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me -- do you think about hell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stares at him blankly) "Hell!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the eternal, earnest sophomore) No -- neither do I. But... (he points abruptly to the book) but this man is a Christian and he has written --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, baas, but how long have you been in South Africa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know how you got a ticket for --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here -- coolie, just what are you doing in this car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why -- I -- I have a ticket. A First Class ticket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you get hold of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent for it in the post. I'm an attorney, and I didn't have time to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are no colored attorneys in South Africa. Go and sit where you belong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take your luggage back, baas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no -- just a moment, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, Mohandas K. Gandhi, Attorney at Law. I am going to Pretoria to conduct a case for an Indian trading firm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you hear me? There are no colored attorneys in South Africa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, I was called to the bar in London and enrolled in the High Court of Chancery -- I am therefore an attorney, and since I am -- in your eyes -- colored -- I think we can deduce that there is at least one colored attorney in South Africa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smart bloody kaffir -- throw him out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You move your damn sammy carcass back to third class or I'll have you thrown off at the next station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (anger, a touch of panic) I always go First Class! I have traveled all over England and I've never...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT Gandhi's luggage is thrown onto the station platform. A blast of steam from the engine. A policeman and the conductor are pulling Gandhi from the First Class car. Gandhi is clinging to the safety rails by the door, a briefcase clutched firmly in one hand. The European cracks on Gandhi's hands with his fist, breaking Gandhi's grip and the policeman and conductor push him across the platform. It is ugly and demeaning. Disgustedly, the conductor shakes himself and signals for the train to start. Gandhi rights himself on the platform, picking up his briefcase, his face a mixture of rage, humiliation, impotence. The conductor hurls Gandhi's book at his feet as the train starts to move. Gandhi picks up the book, looking off at the departing train. A lamp swinging in the wind alternately throws his face into light and darkness. His point of view. The Black porter stares out of a window at him, then we see the European taking his seat again, righteously. The conductor standing in the door, watching Gandhi even as the train pulls out. Then the Second Class coach, with people standing at the window to stare at Gandhi -- then the Third Class coaches, again with Blacks and a few Indians looking at Gandhi with mystification and a touch of fear. Gandhi stands with a studied air of defiance as the train pulls away -- but when it is gone he is suddenly very aware of his isolation and looks around the cold, dark platform with self-conscious embarrassment. A Black railway worker looks as if he would like to express sympathy, but he cannot find the courage and turns away from Gandhi's gaze, pulling his collar up against the piercing wind. The policeman who pulled Gandhi from the train talks with the ticket-taker under the gas-lit entrance gate, both of them staring off at Gandhi. An Indian woman near the entrance sits in a woolen sari, her face half-veiled. A small child sleeps in her arms, and there is a tattered bundle of clothing at her feet. She turns away from Gandhi's gaze as though it brought the plague itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BAKER'S LIVING ROOM - INTERIOR - NIGHT Featuring Gandhi. As if a reverse angle from the previous shot, he is angry, baffled, defiant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are in a large Victorian parlor in a well-to-do home. Facing Gandhi are Khan, a tall, impressive Indian. Singh, slighter and older than Khan, but wiry and looking capable of physical as well as intellectual strength, and Khan's twenty-year-old son, Tyeb Mohammed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is said with a dignity and strength that makes the statement all the more bewildering. Gandhi looks around helplessly. We see Mr. Baker, a wealthy white lawyer, whose home this is, poking at the fire, slightly amused at Gandhi's naivete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is holding a British legal document; he lifts it pointedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at Mr. Baker almost in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Baker smothers a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at Khan incredulously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles, but his eyes show that it is no joke. Gandhi glances from one to the other them -- absorbing the inconceivable. And then almost before our eyes his innocence of the world fuses with his anger at the injustice of it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts the documents threateningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its tone is chilling, and Gandhi's firmness is shaken a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sturdy Khan is studying him with a look of wry interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi glances at Tyeb Mohammed and Baker, then stiffens, plainly frightened by the challenge, but just as plainly determined to take it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But you're a rich man -- why do you put up with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a shrug) I'm rich -- but I'm Indian. I therefore do not expect to travel First Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In England, I was a poor student but I -- KHAN That was England.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This part of "England's" Empire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gandhi, you look at Mr. Khan and see a successful Muslim trader. The South Africans see him simply as an Indian. And the vast majority of Indians -- mostly Hindu like yourself -- (there is a moment of blinking embarrassment from Gandhi at this mention of his own religion) were brought here to work the mines and harvest the crops -- and the Europeans don't want them doing anything else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that is very un-Christian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gandhi, in this country Indians are not allowed to walk along a pavement with a "Christian"!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you employ Mr. Baker as your attorney, but you can't walk down the street with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can. But I risk being kicked into the gutter by someone less "holy" than Mr. Baker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, it must be fought. We are children of God like everyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Allah be praised. And what battalions will you call upon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will write to the press -- here -- and in England. (He turns to Baker firmly) And I will use the courts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will make a lot of trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are members of the Empire. And we come from an ancient civilization. Why should we not walk on the pavements like other men?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I rather like the idea of an Indian barrister in South Africa. I'm sure our community could keep you in work for some time, Mr. Gandhi -- even if you caused a good deal of trouble. (Gandhi reacts uncertainly.) Especially if you caused a good deal of trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY We see a rather crudely stitched sign: "Indian Congress Party of South Africa." Gandhi, now sporting a moustache, stands with Khan and Singh near a fire that has been started in the open area before the Mosque. A wire basket has been placed on supports over the fire. Before them, a small crowd, mostly Indian (Hindus, Sikhs, Muslims), but with a few Whites drawn by curiosity. Gandhi whispers, trying to ignore the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the English reporter waiting skeptically. Near him, trying to be inconspicuous on the edge of the small crowd, are five policemen (one sergeant and four constables). A horse-drawn paddy wagon is drawn up beside them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see five or six women in saris standing together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We feature Gandhi's wife, Ba, standing at the front of the women. She possesses a surprising delicacy of feature, with large expressive eyes and a beautiful mouth -- but at this moment she is ill at ease and uncertain, forcing herself to do that which she would rather not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi wets his lips nervously. He glances with a little apprehension at the police, then takes his notes from his pocket and moves to the front of the fire. He holds up his hand for attention. He forces a smile -- then starts reading -- GANDHI Ladies and Gentlemen, we have asked you to gather here to help us proclaim our right to be treated as equal citizens of the Empire. It is flat and dull, like someone reading a speech to themselves, and those in the crowd who had hesitated before wandering off shrug and continue on their way. Gandhi is unnerved by it a little but he struggles on -- louder, but just as colorlessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This last has come more firmly, and he lifts his head to the crowd, as though expecting a reaction. Three or four committed supporters applaud as on cue, but his technique is so inexpert that it draws nothing but blank faces from the bulk of them. He glances nervously at Ba, who is embarrassed for them both now. She wraps her sari more closely around her and her expression is a wife's "I told you so" -- sufferance, mortification and loyalty, all in one. Gandhi wets his lips again -- and takes a square of cardboard from his pocket -- his "pass."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds it up. A constable glances at the police sergeant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he turns and drops his pass in the wire basket over the fire. The flames engulf it. The police sergeant's eyes go wide with disbelief. The crowd murmurs in shock. At last Gandhi has got a reaction, but the dropping of the card has been as matter-of-fact as his speaking, with none of the drama one might expect from so startling a gesture. Even so, a constable glances at the police sergeant again, "Do we take him?". The sergeant just shakes his head, "Wait." Khan moves up to Gandhi as the tremor of reaction ripples through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes Gandhi's notes from him, and faces the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the end of the speech. He looks at the crowd. No one knows quite what to do. Gandhi harumphs -- gesturing to a shallow box Singh holds. Kahn turns back, extemporizing rather lamely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has stepped forward with his constables, who have faced the crowd, halting the tentative movements of the few committed supporters toward the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is facing the crowd. Behind him, Khan holds himself erect and slowly takes his own card from his pocket. He holds it aloft and then lowers it resolutely into the wire basket. The crowd reacts and the sergeant turns just in time to see it dropped in the flame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures to a constable, who turns from the crowd and marches to Khan, seizing him by the arm and marching him to the paddy wagon. As he passes the sergeant, the sergeant takes his billy club, and faces the crowd, rapping the club menacingly against his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind him, Gandhi wavers indecisively a moment, then takes the box from Singh and moves to the fire. Ba holds her hand to her mouth -- terrified. Again the crowd's reaction turns the sergeant. Gandhi is at the fire. For a second, his eyes lock with the sergeant's -- and then nervously, he takes a card and drops it in the wire basket, and another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has leapt across the distance between them, knocking the box from Gandhi's hands, sending the cards flying and shoving Gandhi to the ground. He turns and faces the crowd angrily, pointing the billy club threateningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, a murmur from the crowd turns him. Gandhi, on his hands and knees, blood trickling from his abraded cheek, has picked up a card from the ground and he leans forward apprehensively, his eyes fearfully on the sergeant, but he drops it defiantly in the basket. The sergeant's fury bursts -- and he slams the billy club down on Gandhi's head. Gandhi sags to the ground. Ba screams. She starts to run to him, but the other women seize her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She fights loose, but one of the constables takes her firmly. The sergeant turns from the commotion to see that Gandhi, his head oozing blood, has crawled to his knees again and is picking up another card. The crowd watches. The newspaper reporter watches. Ba stares in anguish. Gandhi lifts the card. The sergeant stares at him, angry but his emotions somewhat in control after the first blow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An instant of hesitation, then Gandhi drops the card into the basket. The sergeant almost stops, but he strikes again. A quiver of distaste at his own act crosses his face as Gandhi sags. Ba's anguished face is wet with tears. The newspaper reporter stares without making notes. Khan, at the paddy wagon, watches in wonder. Gandhi, his head bleeding badly now, rises to his knees -- a breath and he gropes around the ground for another card. His fingers finally clutch one. The sergeant stares, his face wracked with uncertainty and confusion. Gandhi lifts the card and painfully holds it over the fire, then drops it in the basket. The sergeant slams the billy club down again -- firmly, but with a manifest reluctance. The crowd watches breathlessly, the newspaper reporter stares. The sergeant draws a breath, grasping the club, but he bites his lip as he sees Gandhi lift his head feebly, his shaking hands, stained with his own blood, groping for another card...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's the English reporter. I told you he'd come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You also said your article would draw a thousand people. (If the crowd numbers 100 they're lucky.) At least some of the Hindus brought their wives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I asked my wife to organize that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) Some of them are leaving...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We do not seek conflict. We know the strength of the forces arrayed against us, know that because of them we can only use peaceful means -- but we are determined that justice will be done!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The symbol of our status is embodied in this pass -- which we must carry at all times, but no European even has to have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the first step to changing our status is to eliminate this difference between us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) You write brilliantly, but you have much to learn about handling men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the reading not fluent, but firm and pointed) We do not want to ignite... the fear or hatred of anyone. But we ask you -- Hindu, Muslim and Sikh -- to help us light up the sky... and the minds of the British authorities -- with our defiance of this injustice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will now burn the passes of our committee and its supporters. We ask you to put your passes on the fire with -- POLICE SERGEANT Oh, no, you bloody well don't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those passes are government property! And I will arrest the first man who tries to burn one!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take him away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now -- are there any more?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You little sammy bastard -- I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want that kind of trouble -- you can have it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - SOUTH AFRICA - INTERIOR - NIGHT Ba is gently removing Gandhi's suit coat, staring fearfully at a bandage on his head, another along the side of his face. The room is gaslit, overfurnished in the Victorian manner. Middle class. Gandhi sits carefully on the bed, where some newspapers are spread out, English-language ones among them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba reaches forth, gently touching the bandages on his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi doesn't take his eyes from the papers, but he shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles whimsically, then turns back to the papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba stares at the back of his head, wounded by that remark, bearing it as stoically as he bore the blows against him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Gandhi can retort there is a knock on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small, round ayah (an Indian nursemaid) pushes open the door and proudly admits her charges, Gandhi's sons: Harilal (ten), Manilal (six) and Ramdas (two). They are all dressed in European suits, ties and stiff collars. They step forward, one by one, making the pranam (the Hindu gesture of greeting), then bending and touching the hands and lips to Gandhi's feet in the traditional obeisance of child to father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Ramdas runs to him and Gandhi bends to kiss him as Ramdas put his arms around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi pats him indulgently, then carefully stands erect, looking at them all with satisfaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two older boys show the expected apprehension -- and interest. Gandhi nods to the ayah. She claps her hands smartly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boys bow and leave like boys used to household discipline. The ayah closes the door and we hear their chatter at they go down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is stretching out on the bed, taking up another paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba comes and sits down on the bed beside him, maneuvering so that she can get at the bandage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba pauses and looks at him mischievously, as though that's not a bad idea. He scowls at her, then recognizes her "joke" and grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba pulls one of the strands of tape and Gandhi flinches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is nursing the moustache; he looks at her wryly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans forward to pull at the remaining piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is watching her as she leans across him, her beauty and proximity obviously stirring him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has pulled the other piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she slowly pries the gauze free from the strands of hair above his lip. As she does Gandhi watches her more and more intently, and slips his arms around her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba examines the bandage and gently touches the wound, but she is aware of his burning eyes and arms around her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It slows Gandhi uneasily for a moment and Ba must grin at his discomfiture. He leans back -- still holding her, but looking at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba makes a moue of acceptance and starts to pull free of him -- but his arms still hold her. She smothers a smile and lies down, her face next to his, but neither of them looking at each other. A long beat... and then Gandhi turns his head. She is aware of his eyes on her, but she doesn't move. Gandhi leans forward and touches his lips to her neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba smiles. Still not looking at him, she places her hand behind his head, gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi laughs... and buries her in love.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You saved the papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish you were still struggling for work in Bombay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hated that -- all the pettiness, the little corruptions. (A reflective grin.) And I was more laughing stock than lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But they needed me here. If I'd never been thrown off that train, perhaps no one would ever have needed me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: high court judge has confirmed that Mr. Gandhi would have been within his rights to prosecute for assault since neither he nor Mr. Khan resisted arrest." -- I told you about English law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As I told you about English policemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are glad to have you back, Bapu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I am glad to be back. (He holds his hands out to Ramdas.) Come...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be careful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow I will tell you what it feels like to be a jailbird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come. Come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just like proper English gentlemen. I'm proud of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are boys. -- And they're Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hm. Will you take this off? (he touches the bandage on his cheek) It pinches every time I speak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, you see? Even the South African papers apologize -- "a monstrous attack."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (of the tape, as she is about to pull it) Are you sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) Yes -- I can't talk like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pull!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oww!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mockingly) Mr. Khan said they called you brave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you would let me teach you to read, you could see for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could have told them you were merely foolish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It proves what I told you. If I had prosecuted him as everyone advised -- even you -- they would have hated me -- by showing forgiveness I -- ouch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as though continuing the argument) You see there is such a thing as moral force -- and it can be harnessed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not always. You have told me twice now that you were giving up the pleasures of the flesh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am. I am convinced the holy men are right. When you give up, you gain. The simpler your life the better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will fast tomorrow -- as a penance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you enjoy it a great deal you must fast for two days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JOHANNESBURG - EXTERIOR - MORNING General Smuts -- sitting erect and imposing on a beautiful chestnut horse -- rides down a tree-lined street. He wears civilian clothes with riding boots and breeches. Behind him, a junior British officer rides as escort. He turns into the entrance-way of an imposing building. The hooves of Smuts's horse clatter on the cobblestones as the General rides into the courtyard. Two sentries come smartly to attention. A stable boy rushes to take the horse, and a tall civil servant approaches the General busily as he dismounts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tall civil servant checks his notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts has given the reins to the stable boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he strides into the building, past the smartly saluting sentries.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: STREET AND COURTYARD OF GOVERNMENT BUILDING

dialogue.raw_text: The London papers have arrived from the Cape, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The worst was the Daily Mail, sir. They said, "The burning of passes by Mr. Gandhi was the most significant act in colonial affairs since the Declaration of Independence."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did they? Well, they'll find we're a little better prepared this time. Mr. Gandhi will find he's on a long hiding to nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JOHANNESBURG - EXTERIOR - MORNING Gandhi comes from the house door. He carries a briefcase and is still dressed in European clothes, though far less elegant than we have seen him in before. His mien, the cut of his hair, all suggest a passage of time. As he turns, he stops because he is face to face with Charlie Andrews, a very tall, thin Englishman, who wears a rumpled white suit and a clerical collar. He has descended from a horse-drawn taxi that carries his luggage. He too has stopped. For a moment they both appraise each other, neither speaking. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and waves to the parlor window. The three boys are there -- all bigger -- and Ba holds a new addition; they all wave. And Gandhi turns back, and starts down the long, hilly street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures Charlie on and starts walking. Charlie nods uncertainly. He looks back at the cab in confusion, then signals the driver to follow and hurries on to match strides with Gandhi's brisk pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: JOHANNESBURG SUBURB - EXTERIOR - MORNING They have come to a turning, nearer to town, the area poorer, run-down. Ahead of them three youths (twenty, twenty-one) in working clothes, carrying lunch boxes, lean indolently against a building directly in their path. They react to the sight of Gandhi -- fun. Then stride the pavement menacingly. One of them tosses aside his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi restrains him and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to move forward. Charlie hesitates, then follows nervously, more nervous for Gandhi than himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are getting closer. The youths laughing, whispering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One youth has flicked his cigarette -- hard. It lands at Gandhi's feet. He pauses, looking at the youth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts forward again, he is almost on the youths -- clearly frightened, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he reaches forth to haul Gandhi from the pavement, but -- A WOMAN'S VOICE Colin! Colin! What are you doing? A woman is leaning out of an upstairs window, looking down at the fracas disconcertedly. It is the first youth's mother and her presence reduces the pitch of his hostility considerably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A snickering response from the other youths -- but they are embarrassed by the questioning disapproval of Colin's mother's attitude. There's no note of apology in her cold stare at Gandhi, but she clearly believes her son should not be doing what he is doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment of crisis has passed. Nothing will happen while she is there. Gandhi steps back on the pavement, addressing the first youth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he steps around him, Charlie trailing, as the first youth stares at them sullenly. As they stride on, Charlie glancing back -- CHARLIE (relieved) That was lucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi laughs as they turn the corner.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd be Gandhi -- (Gandhi nods.) ...I thought you'd be bigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it's all right. It doesn't matter. (He suddenly steps forward and thrusts out his hand.) I'm -- my name is Andrews, Charlie Andrews. I've come from India -- I've read a great deal about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some of it good, I hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) Would you care to walk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (noting Charlie's collar) You're a clergyman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I've -- I've met some very remarkable people in India... and -- and when I read what you've been doing here, I -- I wanted to help. (He looks at Gandhi, then smiles awkwardly.) Does that surprise you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not anymore. (And now he smiles.) At first I was amazed... but when you are fighting in a just cause, people seem to pop up -- like you -- right out of the pavement. Even when it is dangerous or --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey -- look what's comin'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A white shepherd leading a brown sammy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps I should --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't the New Testament say, "If your enemy strikes you on the right cheek, offer him the left"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think perhaps the phrase was used metaphorically... I don't think our Lord meant --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not so certain. I have thought about it a great deal. I suspect he meant you must show courage -- be willing to take a blow -- several blows -- to show you will not strike back -- nor will you be turned aside... And when --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and when you do that it calls upon something in human nature -- something that makes his hate for you diminish and his respect increase. I think Christ grasped that and I -- I have seen it work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get off the pavement, you bloody --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nuthing... nuthing. We were just cleaning up the neighborhood a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're already late for work. I thought you'd gone ten minutes ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll find there's room for us both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you were a man of God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wittily, but making his point) I am. But I'm not so egotistical as to think He plans His day around my dilemmas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JOHANNESBURG - EXTERIOR - MORNING A busy street in the center of the town. Gandhi and Charlie come around the corner into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has paused before an office and a young girl (Sonja) has come from it to speak to him about something of urgency, but she hovers, not interrupting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he turns to Sonja. Behind her we see the small office "M.K. Gandhi/Attorney." Several clients waits, most of them conspicuously poor. Sonja's tone is loaded with foreboding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi absorbs the news stiffly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...you could call it a "communal farm," I suppose. But we've all come to the same conclusion -- our Gita, the Muslim's Koran or your Bible -- it's always the simple things that catch your breath -- "Love thy neighbor as thyself" -- (He smiles, thinking back at the youths.) not always practiced -- but it's something we Hindus could learn a lot from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the sort of thing you'll be seeking on this "farm"...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a smile) Well, we shall try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to change the pass laws.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY A strong masculine hand scrawls a signature across a document.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beneath the signature we see the boldly printed identification: Jan Christian Smuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle. A cameraman records the moment with a flash photo. General Smuts, whose presence is equal to his office, addresses someone out of shot as a male secretary removes the document.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The reporter who stands opposite him is Walker, much, much younger, almost boyish compared to the way we saw him at the funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts has risen. He knows how to concede with grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gaze is firm, strong, cynical...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's taken time, but it needed to be done fairly. We didn't want to create an injustice simply because Mr. Gandhi was abusing our existing legislation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just one second, sir, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But on a short trip, I wouldn't spend too much time on the Indian question, Mr. Walker. It's a tiny factor in South African life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a helpless shrug) It's news at the moment. I will certainly report on your mines and the economy -- but I would like to meet this Mr. Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. We Westerners have a weakness for these -- these spiritually inclined men of India. But as an old lawyer, let me warn you, Mr. Gandhi is as shrewd a man as you will ever meet, however "otherworldly" he may seem. But I'm sure you're enough of a reporter to see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE FARM - EXTERIOR - DAY The sides are half up, but it is dusty and hot. This is where the magazine Indian Opinion is printed and we see stacks of it lying around. A short Westerner (Albert West) is running the simple printing press which is powered by a crude generator. A small staff helping him. A Sikh, a Muslim, a couple of Hindus, two young boys. Gandhi and Walker are approaching the tent from the river, Gandhi discoursing earnestly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've reached the entrance to the tent, and he gestures in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This last remark has been directed toward Charlie Andrews, who sits near them at a cluttered table, typing on an old typewriter. He waves, and Gandhi shouts out to them all over the putt-putt of the generator:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They nod. One of the Hindus bows with his hands clasped together. Gandhi hands Walker a copy of Indian Opinion and they start across the relatively barren field toward some other tents, Walker glancing at the paper. Gandhi watches him, grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This carries a weight and apprehension that none of the rest of the conversation has. Walker measures Gandhi with a little surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi seems trapped by an ineluctable fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctant as it is, it too carries commitment and Walker senses it. But they have come by a site where a building is being erected, and a European (Kallenbach) is perched above a doorway on the half-completed structure, getting a level. Some Indians are working below him. Gandhi turns to him, light-hearted again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker waves his notebook at him and Kallenbach lifts his level in greeting. On his bronzed chest there is a Star of David. Walker looks around, grinning, shaking his head. We see two women in saris trying to quell some squabbling children in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker looks at him appraisingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment of embarrassed doubt, then he starts toward a half- finished building -- wooden sides, door, but canvas still covering the roof. It has an awning spread before it. Walker's carriage is tethered nearby, a Black driver standing in the sun, waiting. In the background we see two women cleaning a latrine. Walker glances at the latrine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we have approached we see a table set for tea under the awning. There are two places. Having set the places, Ba is walking along the side of the building, away from them. She glances at Gandhi tautly and deliberately avoids speaking or acknowledging him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba looks at him coldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back and walks into the building by the rear entrance. Gandhi is disconcerted by her attitude, but he tries to answer Walker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A grin -- but forced. When a girl (Sora) comes from the building bringing another cup and place setting, Gandhi calls to the driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he goes into the building, determined to find the source of Ba's aloofness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...so it's not "spiritualism" or "nationalism" -- we're not against anything but the idea that people can't live together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see -- Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Jews -- even Christians.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Walker! Of The New York Times!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Without a paper -- a journal of some kind -- you cannot unite a community. (A teasing smile.) You belong to a very important profession.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hm. And what should an "important professional" write about your response to General Smuts's new legislation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I'm still searching for a "response."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a leading question) You will respect the law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) There are unjust laws -- as there are unjust men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a very small minority to take on the Government -- and the Empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you are a minority of one, the truth is the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Mr. Kallenbach. He is our chief carpenter -- and also our chief benefactor. He has made this experiment possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's quite a place, your "ashram" -- is that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. The word only means "community." But it could stand for "village"... or the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're an ambitious man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncertainly) I hope not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They tell me you also take your turn at peeling potatoes and cleaning the "outhouse" -- is that part of the experiment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little surprised, a little annoyed) Ba -- we will need another place set for Mr. Walker's driver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will tell Sora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's one way to learn that each man's labor is as important as another's. In fact when you're doing it, "cleaning the outhouse" seems far more important than the law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please come and join us -- you'll need something before your journey back. (He nods to Walker.) Excuse me a moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Ba is sitting sullenly on a carpet near the rear entrance to the building. She does not look up at Gandhi, but she is aware of his presence. He crosses and stands in front of her with all the irritation of a husband. It is hushed, aware that Walker might overhear them, but bristling with suppressed anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Ba looks at him hostilely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds her gaze as angrily as she holds his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she starts to rise he grabs her arm, but she pulls free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She says it derisively and it stings, but Gandhi is aware of Walker and he fights to hold his temper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba settles back defiantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment Gandhi stares at her, and she back at him, resentfully. He suddenly reaches down and grabs her arm, pulling her roughly to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is hushed but violent as he pulls her toward the rear door, opening it to push her out as she struggles against him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lurches free of his grip, glaring at him angrily. For a moment they both stare at each other, shattered by their violence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stares at her breathlessly, his temper subsiding into a dazed remorse. He sinks numbly to a stool, sitting, holding his head in his hands. Ba studies him for a moment -- and she sighs, her temper and breathing subsiding too. She moves and kneels before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment, then she soothes the top of his head -- like the mother-wife she is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks up at her, blankly, abjectly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Gandhi grins weakly. Ba catches it and sends it back, warmer, less complicated by doubts. Gandhi sighs, putting his arms around her and she leans into him so that their heads are touching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba mutters "Hm" and holds him a little firmer. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi holds her back so that he can look at her. She looks at him evenly -- no smile, but the warmth still in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sora was sent to tell me I -- I must rake and cover the latrine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone takes his turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is the work of untouchables.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In this place there are no untouchables -- and no work is beneath any of us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she looks up at him) I am your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the more reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally, scornfully) As you command.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The others may follow you -- but you forget, I knew you when you were a boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not me. It's the principle. And you will do it with joy or not do it at all!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all then...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, go! You don't belong here! Go! Leave the ashram! Get out altogether! We don't want you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it! Stop it! What are you doing!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Have you no shame? I'm your wife... (Like lead) Where do you expect me to go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is the matter with me...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) You are human -- only human.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it is even harder for those of us who do not even want to be as good as you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I apologize...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must go back to that reporter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And I must rake and cover the latrine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT The theater is packed. The front rows near the stage are held by rich Muslim merchants, the back of the stalls with small traders, peddlers, artisans -- Muslim, Hindu, Parsee, Sikh. The gallery is bulging with indentured laborers -- largely Hindu. The mood is restless, belligerent. On the stage. Gandhi moves forward and he holds up his hand for silence. Seated on the stage are Khan, Singh, three more leaders of the Indian community. Charlie Andrews and Herman Kallenbach sit at the very end of the line of chairs. Gandhi looks around the audience and we see the packed house from his point of view, ending with two plainclothes European policemen conspicuous in seats at the end of the front row. A uniformed policeman stands near them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A buzz, then applause -- loud and defiant. When is subsides Gandhi looks down at the plainclothes policemen, fixing his gaze on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And again the audience bursts into applause. The policemen just sit like stone -- confident, sure, immune to rhetoric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the gallery a rhythmic pounding signals the anger and protest and is taken up around the hall. The police stare imperturbably. Khan leans towards Singh, nodding to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Singh smiles at the understatement. Gandhi holds up his hand, silencing the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi just waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now a violent response -- a large, powerful merchant rises in the third row.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another cheer. When it subsides, Tyeb Mohammed rises near the back, where he is seated with a number of other young men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The police half rise to look back at him, but there is a smattering of applause and several stand to look back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now there is general applause. Gandhi waits, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the audience. This is the more sober Gandhi they have come to know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks down at the police, making the point stick. There is a tentative reaction from the audience, but uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has their attention now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he gets the response he has wanted. Firm, mature, determined. Gandhi holds up his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the audience. A second, then a merchant stands, signifying his pledge. And then another. Then Tyeb Mohammed and the youths about him. Then all over the theater they begin to stand and on the stage until everyone is standing. It is all done is silence. Gandhi looks at the full theater -- all standing. He takes a step forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A prison door slams: we are close on one face, another slam, another face, and again and again in the rhythm of marching feet...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the house) I want to welcome you all!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every one of you. (Then, still at them) We -- have -- no -- secrets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let us begin by being clear about General Smuts's new law. All Indians must now be fingerprinted -- like criminals. Men and women. (A rising, angry response; Gandhi just waits.) No marriage other than a Christian marriage is considered valid. Under this Act our wives and mothers are whores... And every man here a bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's become quite good at this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And a policeman passing an Indian dwelling -- I will not call them homes -- may enter and demand the card or any Indian woman whose dwelling it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God damn them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Understand! He does not have to stand at the door -- he may enter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swear to Allah I will kill the man who offers that insult to my home and my wife! (A guttural cheer; he glares at the police.) And let them hang me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I say talk means nothing. Kill a few officials before they disgrace one Indian woman -- then they might think twice about such laws!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In that cause, I would be willing to die!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I praise such courage. I need such courage -- because in this cause, I too am prepared to die... (A response; he looks at Tyeb Mohammed) But, my friend, there is no cause for which I am prepared to kill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have asked you here tonight because despite all their troops and police, I think there is a way to defeat this law. Whatever they do to us we will attack no one, kill no one... But we will not (the climatic point) give our fingerprints -- not one of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They will imprison us, they will fine us. They will seize our possessions. But they cannot take away our self-respect if we do not give it to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you been to prison? They'll beat us and torture us! I say -- GANDHI I am asking you to fight -- ! (It catches the audience a little, holds them.) To fight against their anger -- not to provoke it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will not strike a blow -- but we will receive them. And through our pain we will make them see their injustice (quickly) and it will hurt, as all fighting hurts! (Utter silence.) ...But we cannot lose. We cannot. (He looks down at the police.) Because they may torture my body, may break my bones, even kill me... (Up to the house) They will then have my dead body -- not my obedience.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are Hindu and Muslim -- children of God, each of us. Let us take a solemn oath in His name that -- come what may -- we will not submit to this law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a coarse singing) God save our gracious King... Long live our (the audience takes it up) ...noble King. (And their voices fill the auditorium) God save the King!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi, Singh and Tyeb Mohammed are leading a large procession of Indian mine workers along a dirt road from a mining complex -- sheds, elevator platforms, pulleys -- toward a distant city. We see crude, handworked banners: "We are Citizens of the Empire," "Justice for All," "One King -- One Law"... Tyeb Mohammed suddenly touches Gandhi's arm and nods ahead. Their point of view. A canvas-topped open touring car (circa 1910) pulls out from a turning between two factory buildings and comes towards them. Resume Gandhi. There is a little hesitation in the ranks as the car approaches. In it we can see two uniformed policemen and a civilian. The car swings across the center of the road and stops right in front of Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The civilian smiles slowly. He looks from Gandhi to the miners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The civilian looks at him sharply, then smiles derisively, signaling the car off. As it pulls away, Tyeb Mohammed and Singh come up to Gandhi, both made wary by the man's evident satisfaction with what has transpired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi watches the disappearing car worriedly, then turns and signals the miners on. They start forward. Their point of view. The car rides on past the factory building out of which it turned, and suddenly mounted police come swinging out from the buildings and face the procession. Tracking back before Gandhi, Singh and Tyeb Mohammed as they move forward, fear suddenly making their pace more labored. Tracking back before the mounted police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They come on fast, batons at the ready. Gandhi screws up his courage, marching on. Tyeb Mohammed sets his jaw in defiance. Singh forces himself along at Gandhi's side. The mounted police riding on, batons at the ready. Featuring an Indian miner. He is in the front rank of the procession, watching the horses approach. He has a blunt farmer's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to go down, and others around him, convinced by the authority of his voice. The sense of the idea seizes Gandhi, and as the sound of the galloping horses nears, he turns and shouts too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the miners begin to go down, some face up, shielding their faces with their hands, some burying their faces in the earth and covering their heads with their hands. Close fast traveling, the sergeant's point of view. We arrive at the prone miners. Close on Gandhi, his arms crossed in front of his face, staring up, frightened, but determined to bear it. Wide angle. The horses cannot bring themselves to gallop over the human carpet; they rear, plunge, swerve. Close shot -- miner who shouted "down." He is peering through his crossed hands, a tight smile of satisfaction at knowledge confirmed. He turns to see: The sergeant thrown off his horse. He lands heavily, scrambles up, furious, darts after it. Mounting, he is enraged to hear laughter. Close shot. Singh and the miner who shouted "Down" kneeling, grinning at the chaos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Singh smiles, but suddenly looks up fearfully. The sergeant looms over them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And without taking his booted foot from the stirrup he swings it into the miner's face. The man goes down, bleeding. An angry roar from the miners. Several stand and shake their fists. "Bastard!," "God damn you, Englishman!," "Jackal!" The wounded miner himself starts to stagger up. The sergeant sweeps them, his eyes glittering -- this he can deal with. But -- GANDHI Lie down! Lie down! It is a command, and angry in its own way, but it carries all the weight of his influence on them. They begin to go down again and the sergeant wheels his horse and rides at Gandhi. With deliberate, almost fatalistic pace, Gandhi goes first to his knees and then sprawls down flat, his hands over the top of his head, awaiting the blow of the horse's hoof. Close shot, the horse's head, its eyes rolling as it swerves again. Close shot, the sergeant controlling it, cursing, but unable to make it plunge down on the man. Full shot, the sergeant wheeling his horse, angrily -- surveying the whole of the procession as they lie sprawled on the ground, his mounted police circling in front of them, not knowing what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his horse angrily and gallops back toward the factories. Gandhi, Singh and Tyeb Mohammed are looking off at the retreating horses. The car with the civilian has returned in the distance. Gandhi looks at the miner who first shouted "Down" -- a smile, a nod of recognition and thanks. The miner grins, rubbing at the blood on his face, shrugging off Gandhi's implied praise. Featuring the police. The sergeant wheels by the car with the civilian; his police turn their horses, lining up across the road again. Their point of view. Gandhi and the miners coming on once more, chanting forcefully. "One King! One Law! One King! One Law!"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: These men are contracted laborers. They belong in the mines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have put their comrades in jail. When you free them they will go back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've warned you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have warned each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think that is very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the canter -- for-ward!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (half to Gandhi) We should lie down -- the horses won't tramp on us. (Then shouting out) Down! Down! Everyone lie down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lie down! Lie down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The horses have more mercy than the men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Follow me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are we supposed to do now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching the procession narrowly) Let them march... In our own sweet time, in our own sweet way -- we'll get them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - SOUTH AFRICA - INTERIOR - DAY We are close on Charlie Andrews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The congregation is listening to him stiffly, unsympathetically, and there is more than one murmur of assent at his words. The clergyman who has given Charlie the use of his pulpit sits beneath it, embarrassed, but sticking resolutely to his decision to give Charlie a hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few men in the congregation rise and pointedly escort their families from the church. Charlie struggles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More of the congregation rise and march from the church... though a few pointedly do not.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Some of you may be rejoicing that Mr. Gandhi has at last been put into prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I would ask you -- assembled here in this house of God -- to recognize that we are witnessing something new, something so unexpected, so unusual that it is not surprising the Government is at a loss. What Mr. Gandhi has forced us to do is ask questions about ourselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As Christians, those are difficult questions to answer. How do we treat men who defy an unjust law -- men who will not fight, but will not comply?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Small, packed. Gandhi is threading his way in a line for soup. But it is a line that winds through masses of prisoners, some with bowls, eating, some not yet in the line. As Gandhi near the two stone blocks that hold the large barrels of soup, he sees that Khan is serving from one of them. He too wears a prison uniform and there is a bandage on his head. When he turns and reacts to the sight of Gandhi -- GANDHI They're sparing no one, I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes his soup from Khan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles, but they turn as the gate opens and a paddy wagon is backed into the press of prisoners. Khan shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks around the crowded yard at the soiled bandages, the defiant, determined faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is distracted by a phalanx of guards (an officer and four men) pushing their way through the prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners are moving back from them resentfully but their glances reveal who Gandhi is. The prison officer's eyes fall on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No. You were the surprise. It's been all over the prison. We thought they'd be too afraid of the English press.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So did I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (acidly) Don't worry about the meat -- it's Hindu (referring to the soup)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: there's not a trace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know who they've left out there to do the work. There can't be one mine left open. Have they touched the women?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My wife publicly defied the law. They've arrested her and four others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) The fools! (He spills some soup.) Sorry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's split the Government.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's one victory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we hold firm, it won't be the last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry -- I've never seen men so determined. You've given them a way to fight... And I don't think --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gandhi! I want Gandhi! Which sammy is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JOHANNESBURG - EXTERIOR - DAY A side street, but active. Gandhi -- now manacled -- is being marched down the pavement before two guards. The prison officer strides in front of them. People in the street stop and turn, staring. That part of Gandhi that is still the dandy is discomfited, but there is a growing part of him that defies appearances. Featuring a doorway. It is the side door of a large imposing building. The prison officer leads his little procession toward it. He knocks and the door opens. The tall civil servant has been waiting for them. The prison officer reaches forward and undoes Gandhi's manacles.
direction.name: direction
