direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY The tall civil servant, moving with aloof distaste for his assignment, walks ahead of Gandhi, who in turn is followed by one of the prison guards, toward a grand staircase that is at right angles to them (i.e. facing the front of the building). People working in offices pause to stare at Gandhi as he moves along, more uncomfortably aware of his prison garb than ever. The grand staircase. The tall civil servant turns and starts up the staircase. Gandhi is even more exposed to everyone's surveillance on the wide, white expanse of the stairway. He hesitates, looking around in discomfort, then follows the tall civil servant on toward the large, white doors at the top of the staircase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY The tall white doors open, the tall civil servant indicates that Gandhi enter. Gandhi passes two male secretaries, and the tall civil servant scoots decorously around him to knock once on the inner doors. Then he pushes them open and gestures Gandhi in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY We have seen it before when Walker spoke to Smuts, but now we see its full breadth -- and the imposing figure Smuts makes as he stands behind the grand desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to the tall civil servant, who bows and closes the door. Smuts crosses the room toward a small cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts looks at Gandhi, a little surprised at the frigid tone of that refusal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He appraises Gandhi, measuring the irony of his words, his determination. Then with a little sigh at the lost opportunity he replaces the stopper on the sherry, turns and gestures Gandhi on into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has indicated a chair near his desk, but as Gandhi goes forward he pauses by a spread of papers from England on a long table near the middle of the room. We see one headline in close shot: "Thousands Imprisoned in South Africa/Mines Close. Crops Unharvested," a subhead, "Gandhi Leads Non- Violent Campaign." He looks at Smuts. Smuts smiles, a passing nod at the papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wry smile, and he sits on the edge of the chair Smuts has directed him to. Smuts measures him again, not absolutely certain how to deal with him. A pause, and he affects to take Gandhi's irony at face value.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Gandhi does understand it -- as a guiding principle. Never humiliate your enemy. And his tone conveys it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts does a slight double take, a smile, then the "tough" politician.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He measures Gandhi challengingly, obviously expecting some contest. Gandhi mulls it, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smuts stares at him... a moment, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now Smuts smiles with him. He bends suddenly and signs a group of documents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stands, a little uncertain about the sudden change in his status. Smuts signs the last document, then sees Gandhi's doubt -- and misreads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tall civil servant (Daniels) enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daniel stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still a little confused, Daniels reaches in his pocket and produces a shilling. He hands it to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows slightly and starts out the door. Daniels immediately starts to accompany him, but Gandhi stops. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And his own steel shows in the oblique reference to the ignominy of his way in. Daniel bows, and he and Smuts just stare as the uniformed "prisoner" goes out through the grand doors, past the stunned men in the office to the outer doors and on to the grand staircase. The prison guard appears in the doorway, looking off in confusion at Gandhi, then back at the office for guidance. Daniels simply shakes his head "Let him be." Finally, when Gandhi has disappeared down the stairs, Daniels turns to Smuts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Mr. Gandhi. I thought we might have a little talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you have a glass of sherry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps some tea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a shake of the head) I dined at the prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ahh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please -- please do come and sit down. It's prison I wanted to talk to you about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gandhi, I've more or less decided to ask the House to repeal the Act that you have taken such "exception" to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) Well, if you ask, General Smuts, I'm sure it will be done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hm. Of course it is not quite that simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somehow I expected not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad to hear you say that... very glad. You see if we repeal the Act under pressure (a nod at the papers again) under this kind of pressure it will create a great deal of resentment. Can you understand that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit surprised) Good. Good. (The bland politician: the compromise.) I have thought of calling for a Royal Commission to "investigate" the new legislation. (He gestures, implying they'll do what they're told.) I think I could guarantee they would recommend the Act be repealed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waiting for the catch) I congratulate them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But they might also recommend that future Indian immigration be severely restricted -- even stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Immigration was not an issue on which we fought. It would be wrong of us to make it one now that we -- we are in a position of advantage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're an extraordinary man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his grin; he brushes at his prison garb) I assure you I feel a very ordinary man at this moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm ordering the release of all prisoners within the next twenty- four hours. You yourself are free from this moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Assuming we are in agreement?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- yes. It's just that... in these clothes I'd -- I'd prefer to go by taxi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused by his hesitation) All right. Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm -- I'm afraid I have no money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! (He quickly feels in his waistcoat pockets -- and realizes he has no money!) Neither have I. (He reaches forth and touches a buzzer.) I'm awfully sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daniels, would you lend Mr. Gandhi a shilling for a taxi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I beg your pardon, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a second thought) How far will you be going, Mr. Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a mischievous smile) Well -- now that this is settled -- I had thought seriously of going back to India (he faces the startled Daniel) but a shilling will do splendidly for the moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. (To Smuts) Thank you both for a very enlightening experience.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ice) I'm obliged, Mr. Daniels, but I will find my own way out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a shake of the head) He's either a great man or a colossal fraud... Either way, I shall be glad to see the last of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Ship's siren, military band... a jubilant crowd on the pier, passengers waving to the receiving crowd. A group of First Class passengers, ninety percent English, look down from the upper deck. From their point of view. We see the main section of the pier, a crowd of mostly European civilians on one side. A mass of military on the other: European officers, topees and swagger sticks, Indian cavalry, Gurkha infantry, Sikh lanoers -- turbans, rifles, bugles, an Indian military band -- a showy awe-inspiring display. Featuring two Englishmen. First Class passengers, white suits, Oxbridge accents; one quite young, the other a bit older, both civil servants coming to "administer" India.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their point of view. A British general is coming down the gangplank accompanied by his ADC. The officer commanding and the Guard of Honor await him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young Englishman glances at him quizzically. The General has taken the salute and moves to inspect the troops to the accompaniment of the military band.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is suddenly aware of a well-dressed Indian half-listening to their conversation. He glances at him and the well-dressed Indian simply nods slightly and moves off a little. The second Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman and looks down again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is looking aft. His point of view. Another far less elaborate gangplank extends from the aft section of the ship. Third Class passengers are disembarking here, and on shore, separated by a wire fence from the rest of the pier. A large crowd of Indians is reacting excitedly to someone coming down the gangplank but we can't yet see that person. The young Englishman glances back at the well-dressed Indian to make sure of his distance, then speaks quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their point of view. There has been a little hiatus in those disembarking but now Gandhi has appeared, coming down the gangplank with Ba and the children (grown-up sons now), and three or four people behind them, including the tall figure of Charlie Andrews. But Gandhi is wearing an Indian tunic and sandals and he has shaved his hair except for a central section on the top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young Englishman glances back cautiously toward the well- dressed Indian again, then
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: By God, he loves it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure he hates it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Generals' reputations are being made in France today, fighting on the Western Front. Not as Military Governors in India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the devil's going on back there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It must be that Indian that made all that fuss back in Africa. My cabin boy told me he was on board.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why haven't we seen him? (Finding the name) Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. That's it. He was traveling Third Class. There he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God -- he's dressed like a coolie! I thought he was a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After he came out of jail he refused to wear European clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THIRD CLASS AREA - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi is smiling, trying to move on, but answering the questions of an Indian journalist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He speaks with an uncertainty and tentativeness that he had lost in South Africa, patently overwhelmed by the reception. An English journalist catches him as he turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An exuberant woman puts a garland over his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles uncertainly again. As he turns he is face to face with an American reporter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An Indian reporter has cornered Ba behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi half-twists to hear Ba's answer, but his arm is taken by a young Indian (Nehru) in elegant European clothes. Another garland is thrown over his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Ba. Offhand, her eyes on Gandhi ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She joins her hands, acknowledging a garland placed around her shoulders, and pushes on after Gandhi. Charlie helps to guide her. Featuring Gandhi. The young Nehru, somewhat amused by all the excitement, leads Gandhi through the crowd to a little flower-covered platform. We see a banner: THE CONGRESS PARTY WELCOMES GANDHI.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins. He has guided Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and in some embarrassment, he mounts the platform. There is a great cheer, but in the silence that follows we hear the military band from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi looks around at the crowd. Finally he speaks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes the pranam and starts for the steps. The crowd is a little disappointed, but they manage a cheer and applause. Nehru is standing next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man (Patel). They exchange a wry glance, "Not exactly a world- beater." A car door slams. The camera pulls back. Nehru has slammed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, the top down. He has seated Gandhi in it beside Patel, taking Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur rides in front. The crowd still surges around and Gandhi is looking apprehensively back for Ba.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins boyishly, in part to comfort, in part unable to contain his amusement at Gandhi and his evident confusion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, I haven't "refused"... I -- I simply wanted to dress the way my comrades in prison dressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you support the war effort, Mr. Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have demanded rights as a British citizen, it is therefore my duty to help in the defense of the British Empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do now that you're back in India?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I don't know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As an Indian woman how could you accept the indignity of prison?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Mr. Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dignity comes from following my husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he too speaks with an Oxbridge accent) Just a few words -- then we'll get you to civilization.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am glad to be home. (A little round of applause.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thank you for your greeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll follow with your wife -- don't worry, everything's arranged.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - STREETS OF BOMBAY - EXTERIOR - DAY With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car pulls off. He finally turns to Patel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are crowds along the street, and Gandhi -- in surprise that they are for him -- waves tentatively. Patel waves too but he eyes Gandhi rather critically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have come to a main thoroughfare. A crowd still lines the streets but it is thin and around and between we see groups of desperate poor, parked on the pavement, staring with blank curiosity at the passing car, but too listless and too out of touch to move from their little squatters' patches. Patel looks at Gandhi's clothes rather disapprovingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is staring at the street. From his point of view we hold on a gaunt young, aged woman holding a baby wrapped in rags as threadbare as her sari. Another hollow-faced child leans against her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is that young man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's young Nehru. He's got his father's intellect, his mother's looks and the devil's charm. If they don't ruin him at Cambridge -- Wave! Wave! -- he may amount to something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must say when I first saw you as a bumbling lawyer here in Bombay I never thought I'd be greeting you as a national hero.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm hardly that, Mr. Patel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, you are. It's been two hundred years since an Indian has cocked a snoot at the British Empire and got away with it. And stop calling me Mr. Patel, you're not a junior clerk anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat; still hesitant) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The new Military Governor of the North West Province was on that ship. Too bad you came back Third Class -- he might have been impressed by a successful barrister who had outmaneuvered General Smuts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leadenly) Yes... I'm sure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A splendid peacock, its tail fanned in brilliant display, lords it on a velvet lawn. A woman in a sumptuous silk sari is trying to feed it crumbs. Behind her, Gandhi's reception is in full spate -- silver trays, tables covered in fine linen, Indian servants, a swimming pool, a small fountain, the grounds filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries gathered with their wives to meet the new hero from South Africa. A beautiful and beautifully dressed woman (Mrs. Nehru) stands next to her distinguished husband (Motilal Nehru).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods lightly toward Nehru. Featuring Nehru who is introducing Gandhi to two men, one tall, slender, ascetic looking, but dressed impeccably (Jinnah). The other with a haunting face -- beard, flowing dark hair, the air of a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical (Prakash -- whom we recognize from the opening sequence in Delhi at Gandhi's assassination).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi has bowed to Jinnah, now he looks a little startled at Prakash. Prakash grins and makes the pranam to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi nods...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He meets Prakash's gaze firmly, the first moment we have seen any sign of the Gandhi of South Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie Andrews touches Gandhi's arm, excusing himself to the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi bows to the others and is led off to an Indian bishop in full clerical robes. Behind him we see Patel regaling a small group with some story of court or society. As Gandhi leaves, Jinnah, Nehru and Prakash watch him clinically. Except for the servants, Gandhi is the only Indian male not in European clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru grins slowly, thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We get a shot of Ba in a gathering of Indian women. She stands listening, seemingly tongue-tied in the sophisticated patter. And we cut to Charlie introducing Gandhi to a man in obvious ill health, but well dressed, looking like the professor, philosopher and elder statesman he is (Gokhale).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gokhale is pleased, Gandhi amused. He bows very respectfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has offered his hand during this, and Gandhi has helped him from the garden chair he has been seated on, handing him the cane that is resting against it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another grin. Gokhale has started to walk with him, looking at him intently, penetratingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is brusque but affectionate; we know he regards Charlie as Gandhi does... and Charlie does too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He still hasn't smiled, but Gandhi and Charlie have.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . NEHRU (wittily) No, I leave practical matters to my husband and revolution to my son...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Jinnah, our joint host, member of Congress, and the leader of the Muslim League and Mr. Prakash, who I fear is awaiting trial for sedition and inducement to murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have not actually pulled a trigger, Mr. Gandhi, I have simply written that if an Englishman kills an Indian for disobeying his law, then it is an Indian's duty to kill an Englishman for enforcing his law in a land that is not his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is a clever argument; I am not sure it will produce the end you desire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (testingly) We hope you intend to join us in the struggle for Home Rule, Mr. Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a pause)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I? Mohan -- I would like you to meet someone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told the press he would support the British in the war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (acidly) That's non-violence for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he a fool?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not certain... But I wouldn't be surprised.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I lied to you, Mohan, when I told you I decided to come to South Africa to meet you. Professor Gokhale sent me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're trying to make a nation, Gandhi -- and the British keep trying to break us up into religions and principalities and "provinces." What you were writing in South Africa -- that's what we need here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a smile) I have much to learn about India. And I have to begin my practice again -- one needs money to run a journal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense. (He turns to Charlie) Go on, Charlie. This is Indian talk -- we want none of you imperialists.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a mock threat) All right -- I'll go and write my report to the Viceroy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go and find a pretty Hindu woman and convert her to Christianity -- that's as much mischief as you're allowed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This is private -- beautiful and still. Gandhi walks along slowly, taking the pace of the ailing Gokhale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins self-deprecatingly but Gokhale persists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses and looks at Gandhi -- and for the first time he smiles. When he speaks his voice is thick with feeling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are watery with emotion, but he stares at Gandhi rigidly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Forget your practice. India has many men with too much wealth -- it is their privilege to nourish the efforts of the few who can raise India from servitude and apathy. I will see to it -- you begin your journal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have little to say. India is an "alien" country to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, change that. Go and find India. Not what you see here, but the real India. You'll see what needs to be said. What we need to hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I saw you in that tunic I knew... I knew I could die in peace. (A dying man's command) Make India proud of herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT Indian. Steam. A breed of its own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT Gandhi sits by a window in the dimly lit coach. Ba sleeps on the seat next to him, another member of the party next to her. Gandhi's solemn eyes are studying the huddled humanity in the rocking coach. People are sleeping everywhere, some half-erect on the benches, many on the floor among the bundles and trunks and bedrolls and baskets. Some have children, some are very old. One old man, sleepless like Gandhi, stares back at him across the shadowed squalor of the coach; somewhere unseen a crying baby is soothed by his mother. Gandhi looks at the bench across from him. Charlie Andrews, his tall frame cramped in a tiny space between the window looks at Gandhi dozily, a little smile of sufferance, then he closes his eyes again, leaning his head against the rocking window frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - A SMALL TOWN - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi is carried along in a ceremonial chair borne on the shoulders of some trotting men. The chair is swathed in flowers, and flowers are being showered on Gandhi by the running children and the crowd lining the narrow street. Ba and Charlie and two others are following in a flower-bedecked ox-cart, lost in the mass of people that are swirling around Gandhi. On a building top a British officer watches emotionlessly as Gandhi and the crowd pass below him. On this building and others we see some on his Indian soldiers watching with their rifles beside them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY As from a train... but the shots are varied; some close of farmers and water buffalo, and ragged children and women in colorful saris carrying pots on their heads, and some distant of villages as units, one and another and another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Gandhi's face in the window, he and Ba standing, looking out together, neither speaking. Gandhi writing in the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches. Gandhi sweeping part of the carriage, making disgruntled passengers move as he tries to bring some cleanliness to their surroundings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A broad alluvial plain, the river threading through it, purple and gold in the rising sun. The camera races with the train along the river's edge, the reflected sun glimmering on the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The sun is high and the train is stopped by the river. People have come out of the coaches to cool their heads with the touch of water, to stretch their legs. We see an English clergyman from the Second Class coaches, dipping a toe cautiously into the water, children of some British enlisted soldiers wading, splashing, faces alight with fun. And, farther along, the parasols of one or two of the English First Class passengers, a woman dousing her neck delicately with perfume. A British officer, tunic unbuttoned, smoking a long cigar as he walks along in a few inches of water, his trousers rolled up, his shoes off. Across the river down from the Third Class coaches a small group of Indian women is squatted by the river's edge, washing clothes. Some carry infants on their backs. Some small children stand near them. Their ritual of washing goes on, but they are all watching the passengers of the train. Gandhi stands with Ba and Charlie among the Third Class passengers. Ba cools her face with water. Charlie, his trousers rolled up, plays a tentative splashing game with a skinny little Indian boy. Gandhi is holding a large white head cloth which he is soaking in the water, but his eyes have been arrested by the sight of the women across the river. And now we see the women closely from his point of view, the camera panning slowly along them. Their bodies are skin and bone. The clothes they wear, which looked normal from the distance, are rags -- literally, shredded rages, one hung on another. The children are hollow-eyed and gaunt, staring listlessly at the train. One boy, with a stump for an arm, aimlessly pushes at the flies that buzz around him. Gandhi stands erect, lost now in the revelation of their poverty. His eyes hold on one woman at the river bank. Though her frail face is almost skeletal, it is beautiful but scarred by a severe rash down her cheek and neck. The cloth she is washing is a shredded piece of muslin. Her eyes have met Gandhi's as he watches her. Gandhi stares for a moment, a long beat. Then he slowly moves his arm out into the water and, without taking his eyes from her, releases the head cloth he has been rinsing. It floats along on the water down toward the woman. She looks from Gandhi to it with sudden excitement, a sense of incredulity. As the cloth nears her, she rises and moves almost greedily out into the water to take it. Her hands snatch at it quickly. Then she stands, looking at Gandhi. The infant on her back shifts, its huge hollow eyes reacting to the movement. Gandhi smiles slowly, tilting his head just slightly to her. And now that she has possession of the cloth, her manner calms again. And she looks back at him, and her lips almost part with a tiny smile of thanks. Hold Gandhi, staring at her, fighting the pain in his eyes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT Threading like a lighted necklace across the darkness of a vast plain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Climbing green hills -- a totally different terrain -- and again we intercut, this time the train climbing: a boy and buffalo running a huge, crude grinding wheel, train climbing; farmers in terraced fields, train climbing faster and faster... until suddenly with a hoot of the whistle and the screech of brakes it stops!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi is leaning out of a window in a Third Class coach. Ahead of him other passengers are looking too; some have jumped down. Gandhi and Charlie jump down too. As they come clear they can see that a military train of an engine and two cars has been derailed ahead of them. A small troop of cavalry are coming slowly along the line of Gandhi's train toward them. Featuring the cavalry. They are British and their troop leader is viciously angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is swinging his sword, not lethally, but threateningly at the Indian passengers from the train. His British NCOs are equally angry and deliberately ride close to the passengers, forcing them back against the train. Gandhi and Charlie step back. And as the troop goes past we see from their point of view a group of Indian bearers, trotting in the middle of the horsemen, carrying two litters -- covered, each hanging by straps from a long pole -- and each bearing a badly wounded British soldier; one appears to be dead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Clear the way! Get out of the way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The shadow of a train moves slowly along the ground, a sense of tension and foreboding. We hear the engine chugging slowly. The camera lifts. Gandhi and Charlie stand at a window, staring out grimly. Other passengers are looking off too. Ba is seated, staring straight ahead, her face taut, deliberately not seeing what the others are seeing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Their point of view: On a hill across from the railroad track part of a prison wall is visible. In front of it a thick pole is straddled across two others. From this crude gallows two Indian men hang by the neck. One is in turban and dhoti, the other in a tunic. The sound of the train stopping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Close shot. Incense rising in shot. The camera pulls back and back. The incense is burning in a bowl sitting before Gandhi on a make-shift platform set in the little valley between the train line and the little hill where the Indian men have been hanged. A small crowd sits in a crescent before him, Ba and Charlie are bent in prayer on the platform behind him. When the camera comes to rest, the edge of the gallows and a portion of one of the hanged men is in the frame. We know we are looking from someone's point of view near the prison wall. Finally, Gandhi lifts his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The murmur of resistance from the crowd is louder at this. Gandhi shakes his head at the dissent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (at first distant, as from the hill) I ask you to pray for those who died. (Closer) For the English soldiers... (a murmur) who were doing what they thought was right. (Closer) And for the brave terrorists whose patriotism led them to do what was wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not my law, it is the law of creation. We reap what we sow. Out there in the fields -- and in our hearts. Violence sows hatred, and the will to revenge. In them. And in us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - HIS POINT OF VIEW The troop leader, on horseback, is on the hill beside the gallows. The first view of Gandhi on the platform was his. Some of his troops are lined up beside him. He stares down at Gandhi coldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Patel lounges in the water on his back, supported by a large air pillow. Nehru sits at the side of the pool in a swimming suit, his feet dangling in the water. Jinnah sits under an umbrella in an elegant white suit, being served tea by one of three or four servants around. Patel spews a fountain of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru takes an iced drunk from a servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others assent. Nehru shakes his head wistfully.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I agree with Jinnah. Now that the Americans are in, the war will end soon. The Germans are worn out as it is... (he rolls over, facing Nehru) and our first act should be to convene a Congress Party convention and demand independence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And we must speak with one voice -- united.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it reminds him) Ah -- we should invite Gandhi. What the devil has happened to him anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's "discovering" India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cynically) Which is a lot better than causing trouble where it matters. Invite him -- let him say his piece about South Africa -- and then let him slip into oblivion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A fireman heaps coal into an engine's boiler. The train passes camera to the Third Class section, which seems besieged by humanity. People cling to the outside of each door and many more are seated on the central wooden planks on the roofs of the two coaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi and Charlie are riding on the outside of the coach, hanging on through the door, and both enjoying it immensely. Ba, inside the jammed coach, finds it very unfunny. She has a grip on one of Gandhi's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grimaces severely and tugs at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring the roof. And Indian squats right on the edge of the roof above Charlie. He is looking down, offering a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie, who has been grinning, suddenly looks baffled, not to say appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hand still dangles in offering to the tall Charlie. Another angle. Two other Indians on the roof move to where they can grip the first Indian's other arm, as counterforce to the weight of Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Charlie. Hesitatingly, he grips the inside of the window higher, and starts to swing one foot onto the window ledge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi, baffled a second, sees the outstretched hand above them, and in puckish complicity, helps boost Charlie up. Long shot. As Charlie reaches up, his hand is grasped and he starts to scramble and be pulled up to the roof. Featuring Gandhi and Ba. As Charlie's leg, assisted by Gandhi, starts to leave its lodging on the window ledge Ba suddenly turns, sees it, and grabs for it in alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot. Charlie. His face flat on the roof of the train as his arm is still gripped by the Indian, but his leg is being pulled from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Resume Gandhi and Ba. Gandhi quickly moves to free Ba's hand from Charlie's leg and almost loses his own grip. He grabs the window again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba is confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With one hand he pries at her grip. In the chaos of instructions others in the coach are helping Gandhi, and Ba senses she is doing something wrong, but is still not sure what. She lets go. Close shot. Charlie. A desperate sigh of relief. Long shot. Charlie is pulled on up to the top of the coach. Featuring Charlie as he sits, puffing and recovering from the fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie nods grimly. Featuring Gandhi and Ba. Gandhi, smiling, goes on the tips of his toes to get a better view. Ba grabs him desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Charlie. He looks around at the rest of the passengers on the roof, their bundles and baskets clutched beside them. Their poverty is appalling, but they are all smiling at him, a sense of gaiety made in part by his Englishman's participation in their experience. They must shout over the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie stares at him in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is nodding, smiling, expecting Charlie's understanding. And Charlie gives it -- somewhat bleakly. Suddenly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Indians turn. Charlie turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, private) Please! You're being foolish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no room! And the air is lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No violence, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me hang on with two hands or I will fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over the sound of the engine) Englishman Sahib!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come! Come! There is room!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) Place the foot on the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused, but disconcerted) What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Going nearer to God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie! Be careful!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperately) Mohan -- !!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let go! You'll kill him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let go! Let go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see -- most comfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, God, no!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Are you Christian, Sahib?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Yes, yes, I'm a Christian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) I know a Christian. (Charlie acknowledges it politely.) She drinks blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explaining -- obvious) The blood of Christ -- every Sunday!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) Charlie!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Resume Charlie and the Indians.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the Indians are crouching. Charlie closes his eyes ruefully -- he's had better ideas than this -- and he gets as flat as he can.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right, Sahib! Very safe -- bend -- bend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The train, with passengers clinging to the sides and riding on the top, steams into the tunnel, its whistle sounding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Black. A glimmer of light, through steam, the whistle echoing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot. Charlie. In a flash of steamy light, staring wide-eyed at the Indian. Black, and sudden silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pray to God, Sahib! Now is when it is best to be Hindu!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY High. Coming into focus is a lighted platform, and as the scene becomes clearer we see figures on the platform and the banner which reads INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS, and we hear the emotional voice of Jinnah at the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera has been moving in; now it jumps to Jinnah in close shot and intercuts with the impact of his fervid delivery on the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the audience cheers him. Newspaper cameramen crowded around the platform photograph him. Patel comes forward from the back of the platform, clapping. He is chairing the Congress. Jinnah bows, taking his notes, gesturing to the auditorium. A man made for the spotlight, a man loving the spotlight. At last he moves back to his place on the platform. Nehru clasps his hand in congratulation. Others crowd around him. And fleetingly, just in the edge of picture, we see Gandhi -- again, the only one in an Indian tunic -- sitting at the end of the second row on the platform. He is just watching the flood of enthusiasm for Jinnah. Featuring Patel approaching the microphone, stilling the house with upraised hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And again the audience cheers and applauds his little coda. He raises his hands, stilling them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi has already started to come toward the podium. He is greeted with mild applause, but already the convention is performing like a convention now that the spell of Jinnah's major speech has dissipated. As Gandhi reaches the podium, Patel gestures him to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi nods to him and acknowledges the residue of applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means about the journal. Patel has wandered back toward the others, his mind already on them. But he has half heard Gandhi's comment and turns -- a smile, a politician's flexibility -- PATEL (loudly; he is away from the mike) But it's true! I -- I read it... often. Again Gandhi grins -- and takes glasses from his sleeve. This is the first time we have seen them. He has one slip of paper with notes on it which he has put on the podium. He puts his glasses on and faces the convention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the platform, the whispered politics go on. On the floor of the convention, some listen, some talk of other things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru has turned, having caught that last remark. He touches Patel on the shoulder "Listen."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now they are beginning to pay attention on the floor of the hall too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jinnah too is listening now -- aloofly, challengingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is dissent on the floor and on the platform -- but it is muttered and English "polite." Gandhi goes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes off his glasses and folds them and in silence starts back toward his place on the platform. A cameraman flashes a picture, and someone begins to applaud; it is taken up here and there, tepidly. On the platform, the leaders join in perfunctorily. We see one peasant face (Shukla) -- which we will come to know -- watching from the crowd of outsiders who stand in the doorways. Nehru, who has been looking at Gandhi with interest and some surprise turns to Patel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gradually fading in) We were asked for toleration. We were asked for patience. Some gave it and some did not. Well, their war is over! And those of us who supported it, and those of us who refused must forget our differences!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And there can be no excuses from the British now! India wants Home Rule! India demands Home Rule!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And let no one question that Mr. Jinnah speaks not just for the Muslims -- but for all India!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And now I'm going to introduce to you a man whose writings we are all becoming familiar with... a man who stood high in the esteem of our beloved Professor Gokhale... a man whose accomplishment in South Africa will always be remembered. Mr. Mohandas Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (politely) Your journal has made a great impact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am flattered by Mr. Patel (His grin.) I would be even more flattered if what he said were true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since I returned from South Africa, I have traveled over much of India. And I know I could travel many more years and still only see a small part of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and yet already I know what we say here means nothing to the masses of our country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here we make speeches for each other -- and those English liberal magazines that may grant us a few lines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the people of India are untouched. Their politics are confined to bread and salt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Illiterate they may be, but they are not blind. They see no reason to give their loyalty to rich and powerful men who simply want to take over the role of the British in the name of freedom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This Congress tells the world it represents India. My brothers, India is seven hundred thousand "villages" not a few hundred lawyers in Delhi and Bombay. Until we stand in the fields with the millions who toil each day under the hot sun, we will not represent India -- nor will we ever be able to challenge the British as one nation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you read his magazine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- but I think I'm going to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY An open touring car struggling along the bumpy trail. Nehru drives, four friends as young as he with him, all dressed in the same expensive, British manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru is looking a little harassed, from the ragging he is taking and from the ride. The ashram is only half-finished, the ground unworked, the buildings only partially completed and the whole looking like some primitive frontier outpost. They are finally brought to a halt by a goat that is tethered right across the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others laugh; Nehru suffers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This can't be the way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a mocking quote) Yes, I'm sure this is the direction India is taking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To think I almost got excited by Mr. Jinnah when all this was awaiting me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Nehru has half risen in his seat to address Charlie Andrews, who, walking from one somnolent building to another, has stopped dead at the sight of the car. He carries sheaves of page proofs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around the ashram a little dismally.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're looking for Mr. Gandhi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, you'll find him under the tree by the river. (He points off, then glances at the car.) You'd better leave the car -- the ground is rather soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you . . .
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drolly, as he climbs out) Come on! I'm anxious to meet this new "force"!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TREE BY RIVER - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi sits under a tree, peeling potatoes. Nehru and his friends are sprawled out around him. Beside them, the river; in the background the business of the ashram goes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His smile is sardonic, but genuine, theirs embarrassed and self-conscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi has finished the last potato. He glances at Nehru then drops the potato in the bowl. He lifts the pail of peelings to Nehru.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru in his fine linen suit takes the pail awkwardly. His friends watch with amusement, but they too rise to follow as they head for the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He re-directs Nehru toward a trough where two or three goats are tethered, but he keeps right on talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have reached the trough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru has carefully walked around something distasteful on the ground, now he dumps the peelings along the trough and spreads them "delicately." Gandhi scoops some peelings from the trough to feed a goat that nudges him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He meets Nehru's gaze, and for a moment something deeper than argument passes between them. Then something catches Gandhi's eye. He looks off. Ba stands, watching him, waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi turns. The goat is reaching for his bowl of potatoes. He pushes it away and starts for the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru grins, captured by Gandhi's seriousness, and his humor. He hasn't moved, and neither have his friends. They watch Gandhi as he carries his bowl of potatoes to Ba.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi plods on toward the kitchen, carrying the bowl of potatoes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I try to live like an Indian, as you see... it is stupid of course, because in our country it is the British who decide how an Indian lives -- what he may buy, what he may sell. And from their luxury in the midst of our terrible poverty they instruct us on what is justice and what is sedition. (He looks at them, a teasing but mordant grin.) So it is only natural that our best young minds assume an air of Eastern dignity, while greedily assimilating every Western weakness as quickly as they can acquire it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensively) If we have Home Rule that will change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And why should the English grant us Home Rule? Here, we must take the peelings to the goats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We only make wild speeches, or perform even wilder acts of terrorism. We've bred an army of anarchists but not one single group that can really fight the British anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) I thought you were against fighting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just spread it around -- they like the new peelings mixed with the rotting ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where there is injustice, I've always believed in fighting. (He looks at Nehru.) The question is do you fight to change things, or do you fight to punish. (His smile.) For myself, I have found that we are all such sinners we should leave punishment to God. And if we really want to change things there are better ways of doing it than by derailing trains or slashing someone with a sword.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fire is ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, even here we live under tyranny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reflectively) I told you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hm... but look at him. Some "fighter"! I can see the British shaking now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Clothes are dipped in the brownish water. Ba and an ashramite woman squat by the river, washing clothes. It is long past the monsoons and they have had to come far out in the riverbed to the water. But they are laughing at their task.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, because coming along the riverbed toward them is a man (Shukla) who looks as though he has come a long, weary way. His face is gaunt, his little bundle of belongings pathetic. As he nears them, he pauses.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE RIVER BED AT THE ASHRAM

dialogue.raw_text: But it's the ink that is the most diffic --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am looking for Mr. Gandhi...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ASHRAM - INTERIOR - DUSK Shadowed, the end of the day. Gandhi sits cross-legged, watching solemnly as Shukla reaches with his fingers into a bowl to eat. The fingers are thin, half-starved, like the man himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at Gandhi almost sheepishly. He does not eat yet, but his hunger is evident. Ba sits at one side in the shadows watching him as intently as Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is choked and near to tears, resonant with the unspoken agony his words mean for him and the others like him. He looks at Gandhi nervously for a moment, then puts the food to his mouth like a man who is starving, and trying desperately not to show it. Close shot. Ba. The solemn intensity of her gaze reflects her identification with the man's agony. She glances up at Gandhi...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...I've wanted to speak to you for a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...our crops... we can't sell them... We have no money... but the landlords take the same rent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CHAMPARAN - EXTERIOR - NIGHT The camera is low, shooting along the track toward the light of an approaching train. From its distant glow we can see that people line the platform of the small station, waiting, but we cannot tell how thick the crowd may be. The station house. An open staff car pulls up through the press of the crowd. An English captain leaps out and pushes aggressively through the mass of bodies toward the platform. Again the darkness of the ill-lit station and the angle of the camera limit our vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A detail of British troops, already on the station, moves in his wake, just as aggressive toward the crowd as he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant is on the low sloping roof of the station. The captain turns briskly to two of his detail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men join hands and the captain is hoisted up with an assist from Sergeant Putnam. We hear the train stop in the background. On the roof. The captain stands erect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is now standing and his face has frozen. It needs no answer from Putnam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his head slowly, his mouth agape at His point of view. The whole of the obscurely lit platform is covered thick with waiting crowds. They engulf the station house, back and front, and on the other side of the train more people are packed all along its length, and beyond them along the narrow street that stretches through the little collection of houses adjoining the station, every rooftop is covered -- men, women with babes in arms, children. There is no excitement, hardly any movement -- just a vast congregation of people, waiting silently is the darkness -- and as the camera pans we see that the crowd extends, indiscernible, even beyond the range of light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Gandhi. He has stepped down from the train. Shukla guides him, Ba and Charlie a step or two behind. Gandhi moves through the silent crowd, his hands in the pranam, bowing a little to either side. As he advances, the crowd parts -- it is almost eerily silent. As their clothes indicate, the area is Muslim, so some salaam (a touch of the hand to the forehead) and a few tentatively make the pranam back to Gandhi as he moves through them. Most of the faces are gaunt and lean. A destitute people. And suddenly there is a commotion and the sound of boots on the concrete platform, and the English captain shoves his way through to confront Gandhi down the little aisle that was being made for him. The sergeant and part of the detail and behind the captain. The captain stares. Then he looks around at the crowd, suspiciously, a touch of inner fear, then back to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a flicker of recognition, but uncertain. The captain stiffens; a steeling of the will. Another glance at the crowd, this time with an air of outraged authority.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has the cold assurance of a lawyer, and the Captain is a little shaken by it. He glances at Charlie who stands behind Gandhi now, and it makes him all the more uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to make it severe, but it is a comedown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is firm and there is an edge of assertiveness to it that the Captain doesn't like, but Gandhi's unrelenting stare unnerves him. He glances at Charlie again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, the empty severity of weakness. He looks around, then turns and marches off briskly shoving his way through the crowd. "Out of my way, there! Come on, move!" Gandhi smiles reflectively, and the crowd suddenly begins to buzz. Where all was silence before there is now the hum of excitement. Already he has scored a victory -- and as he moves forward again, making the pranam, they return it with flushed greetings. "Gandhi -- Gandhi -- Bapu -- Gandhiji"...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Clear the way there! Get out of the way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir! Up here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me a leg up, will you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is it, Sergeant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awed, a little frightened) What the hell is going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, sir. The agent says they got a telegram and it just said, he is coming... and gave the time of the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the hell is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the devil are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Gandhi. Mohandas K. Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, whoever you are, we don't want you here. I suggest you get back on that train before it leaves the station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly, a glance at the crowd) They seem to want me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now look here. I'll put you under arrest if you'd prefer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On what charge?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want any trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am an Indian traveling in my own country. I see no reason for trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there'd better not be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY The early light of the sun illumines the dwelling. We feature a man in middle age, but one who looks ill and drawn (Meha). He lies on a straw mat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening. It is the kind of listening that opens the heart. Behind him a mass of villagers sits stoically, outside the dwelling, waiting while their case is heard. Meha tries to speak unemotionally but under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze his despair keeps cracking through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near to breakdown, he gestures around the empty house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cannot go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a rhetorical question. Meha nods. Gandhi looks around the crude dwelling, almost nothing remains. We see two young men, one seventeen perhaps, the other older, and a girl, sixteen. And finally Meha's wife, sitting near Ba, the two women listening together but Meha's wife looks like a woman who has given up, her hair is dead and hardly combed, her sari dirty. Meha looks at Gandhi and shakes his head hopelessly. Gandhi nods... He stands slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The words are said bleakly, not to raise false hopes. He glances at Meha's wife. Water comes to her eyes, and she lowers her head. Ba puts her hands on her shoulders and clasps her to her, and the woman breaks, and sobs and sobs...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For years the landlords have ordered us to grow indigo, for dyeing the cloth. Always they took part of the crop as rent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But now the English factories make cloth for everyone. No one wants our indigo. And the landlords won't take their share. They say we must pay our rent in cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What we could, we sold... The police have taken the rest. There is no food, we --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand. (He examines his hands a moment.) The landlords are British?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What we can do... we will try to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CHAMPARAN - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi rides on an open howdah on an elephant, his mind locked in sober reflection. Shukla shares the howdah with him, but does not dare break Gandhi's black mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It registers with Gandhi -- but inside. A moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi shakes himself from his absorption and looks back. Ba and Charlie are mounted on a similar howdah on another elephant, both being led by peasant boys. Charlie is pointing behind them. Coming along the path is a tall Indian policeman on a bicycle. He rides right past Charlie and Ba and comes alongside Gandhi. His attitude is superficially polite, but he is full of righteous authority.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It contains more anger than we have seen him display to anyone but Ba.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is all Champaran like this, Shukla?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Bapu... (He looks across the field.) The whole province... hundreds -- thousands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mohan -- !
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he knows) Are you Mr. M. K. Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry but you are under arrest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not sorry at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A ball is hit. The camera pulls back to reveal a lush, verdant pitch, white-garbed players, English, a few ladies dressed in First World War fashion watching under parasols near the clubhouse and in the shade of trees with a few officers and civil servants, while Indian servants discreetly serve cool drinks. The batsman has hit a four and we see him run down the pitch with his partner until the four is certain, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wicket keeper makes a rude, facetious gesture, but as the batsman turns to settle in his crease again
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has looked up. A car is pulling hurriedly in near the clubhouse, an officer in it, and people are streaming toward it. The car. A major is standing on the back seat. An Indian corporal drives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring the batsman and some of the players as they walk across the field toward the car. They know something's up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The batsman "takes" on him facetiously, and we cut to:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the wicket keeper) Who did you say would be buying the drinks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I've got no idea. All I know is there's a riot or something at Motihari in Champaran, and the whole company is ordered out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's two days' march!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why the match is off. It's mostly Muslim territory and the old man's taking no chances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgusted) God, and it's the best innings I've had since Oxford.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) India's full of grief, old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MOTIHARI - EXTERIOR - DAY A small building on a little Anglicized square. It is surrounded by a milling angry throng of peasants. Featuring the front entrance. The English captain who was at the station when Gandhi arrived is on the top step, looking harried and tense. A small detachment of Indian troops lines the step below him. Charlie Andrews is pushing through the crowd toward the captain. As he approaches, the Indian sergeant holds up his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The captain looks at his clerical collar, his English face, his determination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie moves through the Indian soldiers and up toward the entrance. The captain stares out worriedly over the unruly crowd.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) I wish to see the prisoner, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly) All right, Sergeant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY A basement chamber -- dark, thick-walled and poorly lit. The camera has panned off a close shot of Gandhi as he turns in his cell at the sound of a door opening and approaching footsteps. We have seen only his head and shoulders, which are covered in a shawl. A police guard leads Charlie across the rough, unfinished floor. As he comes to Gandhi's cell we get a fleeting glimpse of Gandhi sitting on a low pallet bed. Close shot. Gandhi as he recognizes his visitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverse on Charlie. He looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot. Gandhi. Head and shoulders. He returns the grin, but anger and determination still dominate his mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now we see Gandhi in full shot for the first time. He is wearing only a white loincloth, the shawl over his shoulders and sandals -- the costume he will wear for the rest of his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie studies him a moment, and being Charlie, he understands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins, and it elicits a little grin from Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Gandhi laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And again Gandhi laughs. Charlie turns to the guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The police guard hesitates, and then unlocks the cell. Charlie enters and sits on a little wooden stool opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly filling most of the space between them. Gandhi has remained seated, pensive. Charlie studies him a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little grin, but his mood remains pensive -- and remote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks up -- his anger, his determination there, but then broken by a hopeless sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie is stunned, and obviously hurt. Gandhi proceeds more gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now Charlie understands. Gandhi smiles; warmth, and sadness. Then he speaks with a determined purposefulness, a friend's trust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has taken some scratched notes from under the bedding and handed them to Charlie. Charlie nods. He sighs, and rises slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi rises, glancing wryly at the prison walls. He nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he faces Charlie; this is the moment of farewell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't know what to say, how to say it. Gandhi meets his eyes -- a smile that shelters Charlie's vulnerability, returns his love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The very English, very steadfast Charlie fights to contain his emotions.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a somber grin) ...Shades of South Africa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite. They're only "holding me" until the Magistrate's hearing. Then it will be prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sympathetically) Did they take your clothes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are my clothes now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (affectionately) You always had a puritanical streak, Mohan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a tone of defensiveness) If I want to be one with them, I have to live like them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you do. (A smile.) But I thank God we all don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure your legs are quite as handsome as mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, but my puritanism runs the another way. I'm far too modest for such a display.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couldn't I be let in with the prisoner? I am a clergyman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit puzzled) They're calling you "Bapu." I thought it meant father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wistfully) It does. We must be getting old, Charlie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want me to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think, Charlie, that you can help us most by taking that assignment you've been offered in Fiji.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to be sure -- they have to be sure -- that what we do can be done by Indians... alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you know the strategy. The world is full of people who will despise what's happening here. It is their strength we need. Before you go, you could start us in the right direction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must leave from Calcutta, and soon. You'll have to say goodbye to Ba for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I get the chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are no goodbyes for us, Charlie. Wherever you are, you will always be in my heart...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MOTIHARI - INTERIOR - DAY It is packed to overflowing; restless. Gandhi sits in the dock. One or two sergeants-at-arms are trying to keep order, but it the uneven and menacing chanting of "Gandhi... Gandhi" coming from the mobs outside the courtroom that fills the atmosphere with threat. The magistrate (English) is surveying the courtroom; he signals his clerk (English) to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The magistrate frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the front row from his point of view. Two or three Indian journalists and one European.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The magistrate receives that news with some alarm. He indicates that the clerk take his place. Gandhi stands. The courtroom is silent, but we can still hear the sound of the chanting outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The magistrate stares. The journalists write. The clerk swallows. The magistrate looks around the courtroom and is only too aware of the mob outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk lowers his eyes to his pad. The magistrate searches the distant wall, the top of his desk, his twitching hands for an answer. Finally
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again the magistrate stares. And so do the journalists. The magistrate wets his lips -- MAGISTRATE Then I -- I will grant release without bail -- until I reach a decision. And now the court explodes. In the chaos of cheering and delight, the magistrate rises, looks around the room and heads for his chambers. The journalists are scribbling furiously. Gandhi turns and starts out of the courtroom. We hear cries of "Gandhi! -- Gandhi! -- Bapu!"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispered conference) I am going to clear the courtroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (politely) I'm not sure we'd be able to. And it is a first hearing, it's supposed to be public. And he's a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worried, angry) I don't know where they found the nerve for all this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure I don't either, but the troops won't be here until tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How the press get here before the military?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That English clergyman sent a number of telegrams yesterday afternoon. I understand one of them even went to the Viceroy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have been ordered out of the province on the grounds of disturbing the peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defiantly) With respect, I refuse to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sternly) Do you want to go to jail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not giving him an inch) As you wish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as much sternness as he can muster) All right. I will release you on bail of one hundred rupees until I reach a sentence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I refuse to pay one hundred rupees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gandhi steps down from the courtroom to the balcony. A huge cheer comes up from the massed peasants below. As he smiles down at them, he is turned by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four young Indians -- elegantly dressed in English clothes -- are following him, having plunged through the crowd in the courtroom. A beat -- and the first young man addresses him over the chaos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi reacts -- with surprise and caution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again Gandhi is surprised -- but even more cautious. Behind him, the crowd begins to chant "Gandhi -- Gandhi."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds casually ironic, but they look determined, even angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is looking at them with a soupcon of skepticism but he is beginning to smell victory. His name echoes around him and is taken up even louder as the news spreads to the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gandhiji! -- Gandhiji! Mr. Gandhi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his accent is as refined as his clothes) Gandhiji -- we are from Bihar. We received a cable this morning from an old friend who was at Cambridge with us. (A smile.) His name is Nehru and I believe you know him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He tells us you need help. And we have come to give it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to document, coldly, rationally, what is being done here. It may take months -- many, many months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (they're eager, impressed) We have no pressing engagements.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will have to live with the peasants. (They nod.) I have nothing to pay you. (They only smile.) Hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CHAMPARAN - INTERIOR - DAY Almost total silence. The room is long, large and imposing -- hardwood floors, overhead fans, an aura of wealth and permanence. Footsteps pace its acres of space... and Sir George Hodge comes into frame. He is rich, middle-aged, Tory -- and at the moment feeling impotent and harried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Governor, Sir Edward Gait -- the portrait of the King prominent behind him -- is feeling as cornered as Sir George but for different reasons. His desk is arrayed with several tall stacks of folders -- all with exactly the same covers -- and on one corner of the desk, some folded newspapers. We can just read "Gandhi" in a headline. He taps one of the folders irritably with his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George looks at him -- half defensive, half defiant. They are old friends -- the same school, the same social class, long together in India -- and their argument is an argument between friend who accept the same premises. But even so the Governor feels the game has not quite been played fairly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George is staring out of the window, vexed, bristling but defensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up one of the papers irritatedly, the London Daily Chronicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George looks at him and sighs heavily. Sir Edward stares back, then drops the paper back on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George turns, and paces back toward him. For the first time we see Sir Edward's personal secretary (a male civil servant) sitting at a small desk and listening with highly developed unobtrusiveness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the first sign of concession. Sir Edward lifts his eyes to his personal secretary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir George looks at the document on the secretary's desk. A moment. The secretary turns it slowly so it is facing him. Sir George looks at it like a snake. The secretary picks up a pen and offers it. A second, then Sir George takes the pen and signs angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns, offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what this country is coming to!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But good God, man, you yourself raised the rent simply to finance a hunting expedition!
