dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And some of these others -- (he gestures to the folders again) beatings, illegal seizures, demanding services without pay, even refusing them water! In India!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody knows what it is to try to get these people to work!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you've make this half-naked whatever-he-is into an international hero.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "One lone man marching dusty roads armed only with honesty and a bamboo shaft doing battle with the British Empire." (He lowers the paper dismally; then the ultimate bitterness) At home children are writing "essays" about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't take another two years of him to save my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do they want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading precisely from a document) A rebate on rents paid. (Sir George huffs.) They are to be free to grow crops of their own choice. A commission -- part Indian -- to hear grievances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wearily) That would satisfy him?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a nod; then pointedly) And His Majesty's Government. It only needs your signature for the landlords.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will be worth it to see the back of him. (A flourish at the end of his signature, then he stands.) We're too damn liberal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps. But at least all this has made the Government see some sense about what men like Mr. Gandhi should be allowed, and what they should be denied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) Things are going to change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BOMBAY - EXTERIOR - DAY Jinnah moves from under the portico. His shining, expensive car is coming in the drive and stops by him. He opens the back door, but only the chauffeur is in the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jinnah closes the door and looks across at the entrance in exasperation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a disdainful comment and he drives the car off toward the garage. Gandhi comes around the corner of the wall into the entrance. He is carrying a bedroll and a bamboo walking stick. Herman Kallenbach is with him, dressed informally, also carrying a bedroll. Jinnah makes a "sophisticated" salaam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi grins, dismissing the formality.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in annoyance) Where is Mr. Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distastefully) He said he preferred to walk, sir. I followed him most of the way. He's just turned the corner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Prophet give me patience.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He came Third Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with effort) My house is honored.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he makes the pranam) The honor is ours. May I introduce Mr. Kallenbach. He's an old friend (anticipating Jinnah's objection) and his interest is in flowers. I presumed to tell him he could wander your gardens while we talked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the suave, but slightly ironic host) I'll send my gardener. I'm sure you'll have much to discuss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY It is spacious, "English." At the door, Jinnah introduces Gandhi to the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again Gandhi grins at the extravagance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A polite little laugh; Jinnah introduces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi makes the pranam, studying him with interest after that comment. Azad gives a gentle salaam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi turns. Featuring Nehru. He stands, awaiting Gandhi's attention. All the others have been dressed in European clothes. The handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic -- much like the one that Gandhi once wore. For a moment Gandhi studies the costume, then a broad smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi nods at the "compliment," but they are all angered by the severity of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again the temper of it produces a little silence. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to a servant who stands, holding a large tray with a silver service of tea. Of them all, Nehru's manner is the most naturally patrician and Jinnah watches him with a somewhat envious awareness of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His stand has produced a little shock of surprise. Holding his tea, he turns to Gandhi with a little smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means Gandhi's of course. Jinnah looks at the two of them. Gandhi has removed his sandals and is sitting cross-legged on a fine upholstered chair. Jinnah's eyes rake him with anger and distaste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look at him with some surprise. As he speaks, he rises and walks to the servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all stare at him, startled by his words and the fervor with which he speaks to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds their gaze, then turns to the immobile servant and with a little smile, takes the tray from him and places it on the table next to him. It makes them all aware that the servant, standing there like an insensate ornament, has been treated like a "thing," a slave. As it sinks in, Gandhi pours some tea then looks up at them with a pleading warmth -- first to Jinnah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It impresses each one of them. But for all his impact, they still take the measure of him with caution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Prayer and fasting"? They are not overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel is the first to recognize the implications.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The idea has caught hold. As the others talk of "papers," "telegrams," "speeches," Jinnah looks over his cup at Gandhi with an air of bitter resignation, but he tries to make light of it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen -- the hero of Champaran.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only the stubborn man of Champaran.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Patel you know. (Patel bows.) Mr. Maulana Azad -- a fellow Muslim... recently released from prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Kripalani. (A bow -- we have seen him at the Congress Conference.) And of course you know Mr. Nehru.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a play on Jinnah's introduction) I am beginning to know Mr. Nehru.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to business: Gandhi has been admitted to the power circle, he is not the power) Well, I've called you here because I've had a chance to see the new legislation. It's exactly what was rumored. Arrest without warrant. Automatic imprisonment for possession of materials considered seditious...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your writings are specifically listed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So much for helping them in the Great War...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fire) There is only one answer to that. Direct action -- on a scale they can never handle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terrorism would only justify their repression. And what kinds of leaders would it throw up? Are they likely to be the men we would want at the head of our country?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been catching up on my reading.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) I too have read Mr. Gandhi's writings, but I'd rather be ruled by an Indian terrorist than an English one. And I don't want to submit to that kind of law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Nehru -- diplomatically -- but with a trace of condescension) I must say, Panditji, it seems to me it's gone beyond remedies like passive resistance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the silence) If I may -- I, for one, have never advocated passive anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am with Mr. Jinnah. We must never submit to such laws -- ever. And I think our resistance must be active and provocative.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to embarrass all those who wish to treat us as slaves. All of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive my stupid illustration. But I want to change their minds -- not kill them for weaknesses we all possess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what "resistance" would you offer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The law is due to take effect from April sixth. I want to call on the nation to make that a day of prayer and fasting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean a general strike?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his grin) I mean a day of prayer and fasting. But of course no work could be done -- no buses, no trains, no factories, no administration. The country would stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God, it would terrify them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a wry smile) Three hundred fifty million people at prayer. Even the English newspapers would have to report that. And explain why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But could we get people to do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he is half sold already) Champaran stirred the whole country. (To Gandhi) They are calling you Mahatma -- the Great Soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fortunately such news comes very slowly where I live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing, to the others) I think if we all worked to publicize it... all of the Congress... every avenue we know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps I should have stayed in the garden and talked about the flowers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICEROY'S PALACE - EXTERIOR - DAY A garden party in full imperial splendor. A military band plays discreetly in the background. Princes, maharajahs, generals, ranking British civil servants and their ladies taking tea on the manicured lawns among the exotic flowers. But over all there is a thread of anxiety, we pick up one or two nervous phrases: "At the West Gate there were no taxis at all!," "Of course, the Army will always be loyal." And the camera picks out a civil servant stepping from a door of the palace carrying a sheaf of telegrams and cable forms. He searches the assembled guests, then heads with almost indecorous haste toward his target. It is the Viceroy, Lord Chelmsford. With him, talking quietly, are his aide-de-camp, the Governor of the province and his ADC, and the commanding general of the Army in India. Lord Chelmsford's ADC is the first to react to the civil servant's arrival and his impatient attendance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord Chelmsford turns expectantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His firmness doesn't restore Kinnoch's normal aplomb. He holds the telegrams forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the general.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That takes the wind out of all of them. Grimly, Lord Chelmsford looks out across the palace's ordered lawns and gardens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sir -- it's Mr. Kinnoch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitant, stunned) Nothing... nothing is working, sir -- buses... trains... the markets... (Personal, incredulous) There's not even any civilian staff here, sir... Everything has stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (curt, firm) Is it simply Delhi and Bombay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir -- Karachi, Calcutta, Madras, Bangalore. It's, it's total.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the ultimate) The Army had to take over the telegraph or we'd be cut off from the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's going to sell his own paper tomorrow in Bombay. They've called for a parade -- on Victoria Road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clenches his jaw and turns to the General) Arrest him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BOMBAY - INTERIOR - DAY A prison door opens. Gandhi, in prison clothes, is led along a small corridor to a room. The door is held open by a prison guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE JAIL - BOMBAY - INTERIOR - DAY Nehru waits for Gandhi. He rises when Gandhi enters. The guard signals Gandhi to a chair across a small wooden table from Nehru. The guard closes the door, but remains in the room. Nehru's face is a map of concern, but he manages a small smile of greeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi, who also looks worn, rises his eyebrows whimsically at the use of that name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means "Bapu" -- "Father."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi sighs, and their faces and minds go to more somber matters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi has listened to it all with a growing sense of despair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a real smile, but the same affection) It seems less formal than "Mahatma."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since your arrest the riots have hardly stopped. Not big --; but they keep breaking out. I run to stop them... and Patel and Kripalani -- they are never at rest. But some English civilians have been killed, and the Army is attacking crowds with clubs -- and sometimes worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I'm wrong... maybe we're not ready yet. In South Africa the numbers were small...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Government's afraid, and they don't know what to do. But they're more afraid of terrorists than of you. The Viceroy has agreed to your release if you will speak for non- violence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a sad smile) I've never spoken for anything else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The golden dome of the Temple fills the screen, shimmering. The sound of a car, and marching feet. The camera pulls back from the dome, revealing the rooftops, the trees and then suddenly, center of frame, the face of General Dyer -- blunt, cold, isolated in a cocoon of vengeful military righteousness. He is traveling slowly, steadily in an armored car at the head of fifty armed sepoys -- Gurkhas and Baluchis -- immaculate, precise, awesome. Behind them a staff car with Dyer's English ADC and a British police officer. It is a relentless, determined procession, filling the dusty street with a sense of menace and foreboding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - AMRITSAR - EXTERIOR - DAY A large public garden, enclosed by a thick, old, crumbling wall. A large crowd is gathered around a speaker on a platform at one side of the park. It is political, but the crowd is mixed. We see Muslims and Hindus, many of them Sikhs, old men, little children, women with babes in arms. Some donkey carts, a sense of fair-time gaiety. We close in on the speaker -- a Muslim. He clutches a copy (we need not see the title) of Gandhi's journal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...England is so powerful -- its army and its navy, all its modern weapons -- but when a great power like that strikes defenseless people it shows it brutality, its own weakness! Especially when those people do not strike back. (He holds aloft the clenched journal.) That is why the Mahatma begs us to take the course of non-violence!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY General Dyer, his armored car, his sepoys, moving toward the gate. Dyer looks ahead calmly. His point of view. The Gate of the Bagh. A rickety double gate in the high crumbling wall. On each pillar, poster notices for the meeting: "For Congress -- For Gandhi." In the distance the speaker and the assembled crowd. Nearer, a few vendors, loiterers and children. At the sound of the armored car and marching feet, a few turn in curiosity. Another angle. The armored car grinds forward. It won't go through the gates, one fender scraping against the gate post. Dyer gives a quiet order, the car backs away. Dyer jumps down lightly -- a man in splendid condition. He walks through the gate and stands quietly in the at-ease position, hands clasping his swagger stick behind his back. looking off at The speaker -- medium shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long shot -- his point of view. The two platoons of sepoys, rifles at the port, trot smartly through the gate and fan out on either side of the motionless and dominant figure of Dyer. Resume the speaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Medium close -- the sepoys and Dyer. He issues his commands in a quiet and unemotional voice, as though they were on maneuvers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant major issues the command. The troops port arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, the sergeant major barks the command, the bolts slam back and forth, the magazines clatter. Featuring the platform and the front of the crowd. They have all turned now to watch, frozen in incredulity and fascination. The sound of the sergeant major's orders and the sinister rattle of breeches and bolts drifting to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their point of view. The distant figures facing them. Resume the crowd. Numbly they begin to back away, pressing against the speaker's stand, themselves. A man picks up a child. Their point of view. The small, distant figures of the sepoys again. A word of command. One platoon kneels and takes aim. Another command. The second platoon, standing behind the first, takes aim. Featuring Dyer. His ADC approaches. The British police officer stands off to one side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is final. Resume the crowd. A ripple of panic now, everyone pressing back, but still they cannot credit what they see. Only one or two have the presence of mind to push clear and seek shelter. It is too late. Close shot Dyer, still calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long shot over the sepoys and their sights, the wavering crowd distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flash shot along the line of sepoys; the rifles jerk and bang. The crowd, running, screaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dreadful press of panic-stricken people flying toward the walls. And again the crash of rifles. Some fall. Others run off-screen in an aimless, irresistible wave. Dyer is walking behind his men, telling them, with a view to maximum accuracy, what he has told them on the firing range (it makes him a little irritable to have to repeat it).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks off at the crowd. His eyes narrow. A group of men are hurling themselves at a breach in the top of the wall, hanging there, scrabbling for a purchase, some disappearing, a few heroic individuals astride the wall reaching down to assist their women and children in the swirling crowd below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods. The corporal looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He directs the attention of his neighbors in the firing line toward the new target; they shift their aim. A man reaching for a child -- who is also propelled upward by its mother from below -- is hit, falls, so that he and the child crash into the crowd below. Sepoys firing ad lib. Dyer watching the effect, careful and conscientious. Swift tracking a man running through the staggering crowd, over the litter of bodies, his mouth open, his eyes wild. He arrives at a well, throws down the rope and slides down it. Others seize the idea and in panic throw themselves into the well, dropping out of sight. Featuring Dyer. Meticulously, he taps a corporal on the shoulder with his swagger stick and indicates the well. The corporal signals his line of men. At the well. The gathering crowd -- men, women -- and laced with rifle fire. From behind the sepoys we see the whole Bagh, littered with dead and dying, a thick ruck around the well, the walls hanging with wounded and dying, the firing continuing, loud, loud, louder... until -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE ENTRANCE OF THE JALLIANWALLAH BAGH

dialogue.raw_text: ...If we riot, if we fight back, we become the vandals and they become the law! If we bear their blows, they are the vandals -- God and His law are on our... (He glances up.) side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soldiering on) ...We must have the courage to take their anger...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Port arms, Sergeant Major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Load.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost to himself as he too is riveted) ...Our pain will be our victory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do we issue a warning, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffly) They've had their warning -- no meetings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sergeant Major -- SERGEANT MAJOR Take aim!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reload!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take your time. Take your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Corporal!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE FORT OF LAHORE - INTERIOR - DAY Silence. The camera is close as it crosses a table with legal documents. Gradually we hear a muffled cough, whispers, shuffled papers, and it at last comes to a large close shot of General Dyer. Another angle. A Commission of Inquiry sits in the large Armory Hall of the Old Fort. Dyer faces a panel of Commissioners: Lord Hunter, presiding, Mr. Justice Rankin, General Barrow, a British civil servant, and an Indian barrister. The Commission functions like a public parliamentary committee -- little ceremony, no judicial robes, a small group of public and press, who sit on wooden chairs behind a barrier that isolates the Commission's business. Much of that public is English -- fellow officers and civilians. A Government Advocate (English) turns to face Dyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dyer glances woodenly at the panel -- a man in some shock at the consequences of what he assumed was an act worthy of praise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Advocate looks at him with a degree of disbelief -- more at his attitude than his statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A slight reaction from the public section. Dyer's jaw tightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at the panel like a reasonable man making a reasonable point. The evasiveness, the only half-buried embarrassment of their response only deepens his own withdrawal into himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dyer thinks about it. Then unashamedly -- DYER I think, probably -- yes. A muted reaction from the public section. The Indian barrister stares at him a moment, then simply lowers his eyes to his notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the first time there is the hint of uncertainty in his manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is just a tremor of distaste quickly suppressed among the panel. Not so quickly in the public section.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dyer looks at him quickly. The question is unexpected, even a little "clever." The officers listening clearly resent it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that answer stops the Advocate. He smiles dryly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dyer faces him stonily, a seed of panic taking root deep in his gut.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: General Dyer, is it correct that you ordered your troops to fire at the thickest part of the crowd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (righteously) That is so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One thousand five hundred and sixteen casualties with one thousand six hundred and fifty bullets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My intention was to inflict a lesson that would have an impact throughout all India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General, had you been able to take in the armored car, would you have opened fire with the machine gun?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General, did you realize there were children -- and women -- in the crowd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that was irrelevant to the point you were making?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could I ask you what provision you made for the wounded?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a moment, then firmly) I was ready to help any who applied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General... how does a child shot with a 3-0-3 Enfield "apply" for help?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Quiet: the same silence as at the Court of Inquiry. The camera is panning slowly along a section of the wall. We are close and see the bullet holes, the patches of splashed blood, the scratches where fingers have dug at the surface of the wall to claw a path to safety... And finally the camera comes to a close shot of Gandhi, matching that of Dyer, whom we have just left. He is surveying the wall in the now empty park numbly, desolately. Nehru stands a few feet away from him, his mood the same, the same benumbed grief and incredulity. Resume the wall -- Gandhi's point of view. The camera continues its pan -- bits of human hair matted in the dried blood, and the bullet-ripped foliage, the well, trampled ground around it, little pieces of clothing. Flies buzz around the debris. Abstractedly, Gandhi touches the bucket rope that lies across the surround. Nehru has moved to the other side of the well. Gandhi lifts his eyes to him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NEW DELHI - EXTERIOR - DAY The imposing capitol building of the British Raj in India. We establish then cut into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Featuring the Viceroy, Lord Chelmsford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chelmsford is pacing along one side of a large conference table. Just in front of this is the "British" side -- two generals (a full general and a brigadier), a naval officer, two senior civil servants, a senior police officer. Across from them is the "Indian" side: Gandhi, Nehru, Patel, Jinnah, Azad. This time Gandhi is in the middle and speaks with the full authority of a leader. The Indian side acknowledges Chelmsford's disclaimer -- coolly, but accepting it. That lifts Chelmsford's hopes a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is spoken with the cold determination of a man still angry. It stops Chelmsford in mid-pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The British are stunned almost to speechlessness -- the audacity, the impossibility of it -- and from Gandhi of all people. The senior civil servant, Kinnoch, is the first to recover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi and the others just look at him. Chelmsford is realist enough to recognize that a faux pas has been made, and he strives to get the meeting back on the course he intends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has deliberately if delicately caught the eye of both Jinnah and Maulana Azad during this. Gandhi knows the trouble this can cause and he answers more for those on his side than the Viceroy's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its finality is such that for a moment there is no response at all, but then the General smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His smile flitters cynically on the mouths of the others on his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at them all, then up at Lord Chelmsford behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - THE SAME GOVERNMENT COUNCIL ROOM Close shot -- a crystal decanter. The top is lifted, whiskey pours. The camera pulls back. We are still in the Council Room, but time has passed. The Indian delegation has gone, and the British are relaxing as a servant pours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they all laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are some smiles, but not all of them are quite so amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is an instruction they all find correct.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You must understand, gentlemen, that His Majesty's Government -- and the British people -- repudiate both the massacre and the philosophy that prompted it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I would like to do is to come to some compromise over the new civil legis -- GANDHI If you will excuse me, Your Excellency, it is our view that matters have gone beyond "legislation."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We think it is time you recognized that you are masters in someone else's home. (It chills, stiffens; Gandhi proceeds only an iota softer) Despite the best intentions of the best of you, you must, in the nature of things, humiliate us to control us. General Dyer is but an extreme example of the principle. It is time you left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With respect, Mr. Gandhi, without British administration, this country would be reduced to chaos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patient, ironic) Mr. Kinnoch, I beg you to accept that there is no people on earth who would not prefer their own bad government to the "good" government of an alien power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly, choked) My dear sir -- India is British! We're hardly an alien power!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if His Majesty could waive all other considerations, he has a duty to the millions of his Muslim subjects who are a minority in this realm. And experience has taught that his troops and his administration are essential in order to keep the peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All nations contain religious minorities. Like other countries, ours will have its problems. (Flat, irrevocable) But they will be ours -- not yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how do you propose to make them yours? You don't think we're just going to walk out of India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... in the end you will walk out. Because one hundred thousand Englishmen simply cannot control three hundred fifty million Indians if the Indians refuse to co-operate. And that is what we intend to achieve -- peaceful, non-violent, non-co- operation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Until you yourself see the wisdom of leaving... your Excellency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mocking his exchange with Gandhi) "You don't just expect us to walk out?" "Yes."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Extraordinary little man! "Nonviolent, non-co-operation" -- for a moment I almost thought they were actually going to do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully) Yes -- but it would be wise to be very cautious for a time. The Anti- Terrorist Act will remain on the statutes, but on no account is Gandhi to be arrested. Whatever mischief he causes, I have no intention of making a martyr of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT A roar of approval from a huge crowd. We are featuring two British soldiers, their faces partially lit by a flickering torch light that reveals their tense wariness. Another angle. And we can see its cause. A huge crowd is gathered around a platform -- torches sprinkled through it -- and their mood is confident, belligerent. As their defiant roar carries through the night air we see that Gandhi sits cross-legged on the platform. Nehru is with him. Patel, now for the first time in an Indian tunic, and Azad, also in an Indian tunic. Desai, Gandhi's new male secretary, is with them. But it is Ba who is speaking at the microphone, who has brought the shout of defiance from the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the end of her speech and she makes the pranam and turns away. There is applause and noise, but Ba does not acknowledge it; she simply sits cross-legged behind Gandhi, who is talking with Patel and Nehru. At last he rises, and the noise and applause increase to something like chaos. In close shot we see other British soldiers watching on the perimeter of the crowd and they are now made even more wary by the enthusiasm of this greeting. Gandhi fiddles with his glasses, preoccupied; finally he looks out over the crowd and holds up a hand -- almost lazily -- and gradually, but quite definitely, the crowd stills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We intercut with the crowd, listening raptly. Gandhi holds up one finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither of these goals is easy, and the audience reaction shows it. Now Gandhi raises a third finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the crowd breaks into stamping and applause. Gandhi lets it run for a time, then stills it with the one small gesture as before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This has sobered the audience somewhat. Now he looks out across them as though seeking something. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is an excited stir; he silences it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot -- the ground. As suitcoats, shirts, vests, trousers, are flung into a pile. Featuring the two British soldiers -- later -- on the edge of the crowd, staring off, their faces now brightly lit by darting flames. Their point of view. A huge triangular pile burns before the platform, an excited half-naked crowd swirling in the shadows around it. Resume the two British soldiers. They look at each other with a kind of fear a rampant crowd can excite in those who must hold it...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (simple, direct) ...but now something worse is happening. When Gandhiji and I were growing up, women wove their own cloth. But now there are millions who have no work because those who can buy all they need from England. I say with Gandhiji, there is no beauty in the finest cloth if it makes hunger and unhappiness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My message tonight is the message I have given to your brothers everywhere. To gain independence we must prove worthy of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There must be Hindu-Muslim unity -- always. (A second finger.) Secondly, no Indian must be treated as the English treat us so we must remove untouchability from our lives, and from our hearts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Third -- we must defy the British.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not with violence that will inflame their will, but with firmness that will open their eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: English factories make the cloth -- that makes our poverty. (A reaction.) All those who wish to make the English see, bring me the cloth from Manchester and Leeds that you wear tonight, and we will light a fire that will be seen in Delhi -- and London!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And if, like me, you are left with only one piece of homespun -- wear it with dignity!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The small train station near the ashram. Kallenbach stands by a new (early 1920s) Ford touring car, watching as a train pulls into the station. As people start to jump off the train he moves forward. Featuring Patel, getting out of a compartment marked "Second Class." He lugs a bedroll and a bag. Despite the Indian tunic he now wears he cannot help but look and act like the incisive, patrician lawyer he is under the skin. As he moves through the crowded platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up; it is Kallenbach who is the insistent "helper."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach is smiling too. He reaches for the bags again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And grandly, he relinquishes the bags and looks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their point of view. In the chaos of the Third Class we see Maulana Azad coming out of a section of the coach. He is carrying a baby wrapped in rags. The child's mother with two little ones hanging on her has followed him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Azad hands the woman the baby and she obviously thanks him. He makes a little salaam to her and moves through the confusion of the platform toward the camera. Resume Patel and Kallenbach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Azad approaches them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Kallenbach clasp with their free hands, both grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the camera pans with their glances at they look back with real interest toward the First Class coach. Porters are unloading the baggage of two or three passengers here and helping some others (English and Indian) to board. In the foreground we see a tall Indian woman in a red sari. Farther along there is a large stack of luggage being added to by a porter. An English woman is hovering about it. She is well dressed, but rather dreary and unprepossessing, and the camera zooms in toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel grins. Like most witty men, he loves wit in others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel groans. They turn back to the train and just as they do, the tall Indian woman in the red sari tips a porter, taking one small bag from him and turns: Mirabehn (Madeleine Slade) is tall, quite pretty and extremely English despite the sari. The minute she turns, she stops on seeing the now startled Kallenbach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach recovers sufficiently to -- KALLENBACH ...And you would be Miss Slade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The word means "daughter." Patel and Azad stare at each other in something like bafflement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me -- just let me get out of your way, please. (Someone reaches for his bedroll and bag.) No, thank you, I'll manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (joyous -- it's been a long time) Ah, Herman! (Of the bags) No, no -- don't destroy my good intentions. I'm feeling guilty about traveling Second Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do it as a friend -- and admirer -- not a servant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, in that case!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maulana is made of sterner stuff. Our trains met in Bombay, but he's back there in that lot somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There he is -- out Gandhi-ing Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head at it all) When I think what our "beloved Mahatma" asks, I don't know how he ever got such a hold over us. Is he back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Now that things are moving he's going to write and only take part when it's necessary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Patel) It was a Hindu child and it tried to wet on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. A Muslim beef eater -- I'm only surprised he missed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a she.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, that explains it. (He grins.) Well, do I carry your luggage as penance or -- KALLENBACH There's another passenger -- a Miss Slade. (He turns automatically, as Patel and Azad do, toward the First Class section.) She's the daughter of an English admiral. (Patel and Azad look back at him in quick surprise. Kallenbach smiles.) She's been corresponding with him for a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what does the daughter of an English admiral propose to do in an ashram -- sink us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly -- his manner) From the looks of the luggage, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She wants to make her home with us -- and Gandhiji has agreed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd be Mr. Kallenbach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) I prefer the name Gandhiji has given me -- Mirabehn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY An ox labors along in harness. We follow him for a moment, then move along the traces of the harness to the Ford touring car that it is pulling. In the car Kallenbach and Mirabehn sit in the front seat, Patel and Azad in the back. Closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does what little steering is necessary and Mirabehn smiles at it all, finding everything delightful. She peers ahead in the direction of the distant ashram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn has turned to look at him. She has the same sophomoric eagerness and intensity as the young Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn is enthralled by the wit, the modesty that underlines the words. She faces Kallenbach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She thinks she does, and that he would want to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It surprises, but it doesn't deflate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach, whose size and stillness carry the aura of some great piece of primitive sculpture -- solid, true, disturbingly profound -- searches inside himself for the answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is so profoundly simple and deeply felt that it obviously touches the deeply emotional Mirabehn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (of the car) It was a gift and it only worked a few weeks, but when Gandhi came home he struck on this idea. He calls it his ox-Ford. Comfortable -- and yet more our pace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Might Mr. Nehru be there too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glibly) The irresponsible young Nehru is in prison -- again. Though there is a rumor that under pressure from your country, they will let him out -- again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't know how closely we follow your struggle -- (to Patel personally) how many in England admired what you did in Bardoli. It must have taken enormous courage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, in this country one must decide if one is more afraid of the government or Gandhi. (Of Azad, Kallenbach and himself) For us, it's Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a note of wonder) And you're German...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And do you feel Indian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you've been with him so long -- why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'd come to believe I would never meet a truly honest man. And then I met one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Ba has a spinning wheel on the small porch and Gandhi is sitting next to her with another. He is trying to imitate her action -- which is fast and dexterous -- and he gets in a terrible jumble. Ba watches, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leans across and tries to extricate his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Ba laughs again and Gandhi smiles, tapping her with playful reproval on the top of her bent head. There are footsteps and Gandhi looks up. Patel stands in the doorway. Gandhi's face changes to something like elation. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means "leader" and it is the name the peasants have given Patel. Gandhi uses it with an intonation of novelty and respect. He stands and crosses to Patel, clutching him emotionally, and it brings a bit of emotion from the sophisticated Patel. Gandhi holds him back to look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel gets hold of himself, and affects his usual glib cynicism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles again, then, his arm still around Patel's shoulder, he turns to greet the others. Azad looks at him, then facetiously, as though to put down Patel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi laughs again, squeezing Patel's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Azad shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi reaches forward and touches his hand, and he sees Mirabehn on the porch. For a moment their eyes meet and then Mirabehn moves forward quickly and takes his hand, kissing it, tears running down her cheek. Gandhi touches the top of her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - GANDHI'S BUNGALOW - INTERIOR - TWILIGHT The camera is on a row of sandals by the door -- Patel's, Azad's, Desai's, Gandhi's. It pans to the room. Gandhi sitting facing Patel and Azad, Desai in the background, making notes of the discussion. Gandhi is carding fiber to thread as they talk. Mirabehn, seated like the others, is almost in the circle, sitting near Ba, and listening like her. Ba's spinning never stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks up at Azad, Azad shakes his head solemnly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he does not go on. It has a terrible sobriety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Azad shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi reaches out and touches his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds Azad's eyes, giving strength. Then he turns to Mirabehn, made more aware of her by Azad's reference. For a moment he looks at her sari.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tone suggests he thinks it is homespun. Mirabehn nods, a little choked that his attention is turned to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles approvingly. Then a shadow -- GANDHI What do the workers in England make of what we're doing? It must have produced hardship. Mirabehn beams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn nods and looks resignedly at Ba. Ba is spinning. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn looks down at the shoes on her feet -- and then at the others and their bare feet -- and she looks up in grinning, self-conscious embarrassment. Ba smiles at her affectionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn looks at her, accepting the warmth behind the teasing. It is the beginning of an enduring friendship.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stop -- stop...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God gave you ten thumbs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (morosely) Eleven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sardar...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you've done is a miracle. You have made all India proud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It must have been the only Non-violent campaign ever led by a man who wanted to kill everybody every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) Not true! (He means himself.) The secret is mastering the urge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He came Second Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we can't expect miracles all the time. (Then to Azad, more soberly) Your news I understand is not so good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, come -- you will be my daughter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...but then some rioting broke out between Hindus and Muslims -- violent, terrible...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whether it was provoked... (he shrugs, a hint of suspicion) But it gave them an excuse to impose martial law throughout Bengal. (He looks at Gandhi, shaking his head grimly.) Some of the things the military have done...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is the campaign weakening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The marches and protests are bigger if anything but with the censorship here (a nod toward Mirabehn) they know more in England than we do, and it saps the courage to think you may be suffering alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are not alone. And martial law only shows how desperate the British are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that homespun? Or cotton from Leeds?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent for it, from here. I dyed it myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It has. But you'd be surprised. They understand -- they really do. It's not the workers you have to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. (A glance toward Ba.) Ba will have to teach you to spin too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would rather march.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First spin. Let the others march for a time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First lesson: To march, wear shoes, to spin, do not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll teach you all our foolishness, and you must teach me yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT A small town. Featuring the faces of six Indian police constables as a torch light parade passes them. There are enough of them in their group to be watching the marchers with a challenging disdain. The marchers are men in loin- clothes and tunics; they brandish torn and ripped English cloth and shout in unison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have cut to the parade -- and it is the tail end, going around a corner ahead. Some of the marchers wave their cloth tauntingly at the police. One policeman suddenly steps out and grabs at a piece of cloth waved at him. He pulls it viciously from the marcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chases the marcher and boots him with his foot. Another marcher runs at the policeman, swinging at him with his piece of cloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle -- sudden. He is whacked across the face with a billy club and falls, clutching his face and spouting blood from his nose. Another angle. The police are now all attacking, swinging clubs and kicking at the tail-enders of the march. And the tail-enders begin to scream
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Home Rule! Long live Gandhi! Buy Indian! Long live Gandhi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll stuff your damn mouth with it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave him alone -- he wasn't harming you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help! Help us! as they try to scramble away from the attack. Out of shot we can still hear the disappearing chant: "Home Rule! Long live Gandhi!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT The parade is on this street. A tail-ender, blood streaming down his face, runs around the corner. lose shot -- the tail- ender. As he stops
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle. Some of the marchers turn at the shout.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) Help! Help us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - THE FIRST STREET A few of the tail-enders watching, some running clear of the police, some being beaten. Two police have a man on the ground. One policeman looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their point of view. The corner where the parade has disappeared. It is now packed with more marchers, more flooding in from behind. We see the whole street, the marchers massed near the corner, spread out, staring at the police, who are now frozen in their mayhem, staring off at the marchers. For a second, utter silence. And then the police begin to back away from their victims. The marchers start to move forward. The police draw their guns, and the marchers suddenly run at them, a guttural roar, as though they were one single wild beast. Featuring the police. They start to run, some turning to fire at the pursuing crowd, then running on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT A small building for this small town. A policeman on duty holds the door and the fleeing police, first one, then two more, then the last three, run into the building. The crowd surges around it, smashing windows, hurling stones. Close shot. English cloth shirts pushed together and ignited. Second close shot. Trousers, already aflame, being hurled through a broken window. All around, the noise of the angry, surging crowd, stones raining on the building. Shouts: "Out -- Out!" Later. A corner of the building engulfed in flames. The camera pulls back and we see the whole building swept with fire. The heat of it keeps the crowd back but they are still shouting "Out -- Out! -- Out" -- and a sudden cheer. At the door of the flaming building. One policeman appears, his face blackened with soot, his hands up over his head. Another appears in the smoke behind him, and they start to come out -- not only the original six but the five or six others who were in the building -- rushing suddenly from the heat of the fire. Close shot -- the crowd. We are close on the body of the first policeman as he runs into the crowd and on the instant we see a sword slash at his arm. Another angle. The crowd massed around the fallen figure, a flash of the sword going up over the heads -- a breathless pause -- and it comes down again... savagely. Later. The flames of the crumbled building. The crowd has gone and we only hear the roar of the flames. The camera pans across the flames, and we see a skull, charred flesh still clinging to it, the eyes black holes, the teeth bare as it burns in the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Close shot -- Gandhi. His face drawn, stunned, as he stares emptily at the floor. He is sitting on the carpet in the center of the room. A moment of silence and then we begin to hear the tick of a clock, the sounds of others moving in the room, and finally
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle. Patel leans with one arm on a table, his mood as devastated as Gandhi's; he is looking at an Indian paper on the table by his hand. A moment then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has been standing, looking out of a window. He turns, and tosses a newspaper on a desk. It is a New York Times and we just glimpse the picture of the severed head lying in the smoldering ashes. And now we see Nehru and Azad in the background too. And Desai. Jinnah as usual in a finely cut European suit, the others are dressed in tunics of homespun as they will be to the end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turn to him -- a sense of surprise, but they don't really believe he means the statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at him. Gandhi doesn't move. Patel looks up hopelessly at Jinnah. Azad keeps his eyes fixed on Gandhi, sensing, fearing what is going to happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Gandhi with a mounting sense of annoyance. Gandhi is listening, but still withdrawn into himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jinnah turns away in anger. Patel sighs. Nehru feels helpless but he continues to try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stares into nothing -- mulling that. Finally
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru stares at him -- surprised. Azad is not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi does not react. And Nehru ignores the thought too, because like Azad his mind is already on the real danger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks up at him -- a resigned fatalism.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's one bit of news they haven't censored.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it's all over the world... (ironically) India's "non-violence."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bleakly) What can we do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sepulchrally) We must end the campaign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After what they did at the massacre -- it's only an eye for an eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he hasn't moved; the same tone) An eye for an eye only ends up making the whole world blind. (Now he looks up at them.) We must stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a baffled smile) Gandhiji -- do you know the sacrifices people have made?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We would never get the same commitment again -- ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we obtain our freedom by murder and bloodshed I want no part of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleading) It was one incident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Tell that to the families of the policemen who died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu -- the whole nation is marching. They wouldn't stop, even if we asked them to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will ask. And I will fast as penance for my part in arousing such emotions -- and I will not stop until they stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgustedly) God! You can be sure the British won't censor that! They'll put it on every street corner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- but Gandhiji people are aroused... they won't stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I die, perhaps they will...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - TWILIGHT Mirabehn walks across the grounds toward Gandhi's bungalow. She carries a small tray with a pitcher and a glass. We see a few people working in the background, and a mass of people camped near the entrance, some sprawled, some sitting, some standing -- all waiting. The steps of Gandhi's bungalow. A doctor in a white tunic sits on the porch, reading. On a small table beside him we a stethoscope and the equipment to measure blood pressure. He looks up at Mirabehn as she mounts the steps, and nods. Mirabehn reaches the doorway and is suddenly brought up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE INTERIOR - MIRABEHN'S POINT OF VIEW - TWILIGHT In the shadows, Ba sits by Gandhi's mat bed. She is holding him as he heaves in a spasm of dry retching, his face to the wall. When he is finished, he lies almost limp in her arms and she gently lowers him to the mat. She strokes his head. Mirabehn stiffens herself. She is not yet devotee and nurse. She removes her sandals and walks across the room. Ba looks up at her. She glances at the jug and glass, then nods. She turns to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She strokes his sweating head again, touches his shoulder and gets up. For a moment the two women hold each other's gaze, then Ba smiles weakly, and leans her head into the taller Mirabehn's shoulder. With her free hand Mirabehn touches Ba's head. Then Ba straightens, and leaves without looking back. Mirabehn bends and sits by Gandhi's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi struggles to turn, and Mirabehn helps him. When he turns we see that his face is wet with sweat from the dry heaving and his hands and arms are quivering and he cannot stop them. She looks at him nervously, then pours a glass from the pitcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back, and propping up his head, helps him to sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi swallows with difficulty. He pauses, letting his head fall back and she lowers it down to the mat again. He tries to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn looks daunted by his intractability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi signals her down to him. She bends so she is looking at the floor and he is speaking almost into her ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We intercut their faces, very close, as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the very last of it Mirabehn has turned her face to him, touched with emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn straightens up, smiling, wiping the tear from her cheek with mock discipline. She starts to pour water from the pitcher into the glass again, then she turns suddenly, her attention caught. Her point of view. The doorway. Nehru stands in it. Kallenbach and Desai are a step or two behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands, moving back from Gandhi. Nehru crosses and kneels in Mirabehn's place. Gandhi looks up at him and his eyes light. He moves his shaking hand out and Nehru clasps it. A moment of personal feeling between them, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a victory. Gandhi's face cracks into a tearful grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Nehru chokes with emotion and laughter at the same time. He buries his head on Gandhi's hand, clutching it to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I must get ready for evening prayers. Mirabehn is here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've brought your drinking water. May I turn you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is a little lemon juice in it. That is all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herman has gone to meet Pandit Nehru -- there was a telegram. Almost everywhere it has stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When it is everywhere, then my prayers will be answered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you find me stubborn?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (her own honesty) I don't know... I know you are right. I don't know that this is right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse, strained) When I despair, I remember that all through history the way of truth and love has always won.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There have been tyrants and murderers, and for a time they can seem invincible. But in the end they always fall. Think of it -- always... When you are in doubt that that is God's way, the way the world is meant to be... think of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the paternal smile) And then -- try to do it His way. (A tear runs down Mirabehn's face. She touches his shoulder. Gandhi just leans his head back in exhaustion.) And now -- could I have another feast of lemon juice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Panditji -- come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jinnah, Patel, all of Congress has called for the end of non-co- operation. There's not been one demonstration. All over India people are praying that you will end the fast. They're walking in the streets, offering garlands to the police -- and to British soldiers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (croaked) Perhaps -- perhaps I have overdone it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Bright sunshine. A little boy is pulling a goat by a tether. He turns with a bright smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverse angle. Gandhi is walking, holding Ba's shoulder for support with one hand, and Mirabehn's with the other. It is some days later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy grins at Gandhi's feigned alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of a motor disturbs them. Gandhi turns. His point of view. Coming into the entrance, along the bumpy path are two police cars (early 1920s Morris). They have to stop because they are impeded by Gandhi's ox-Ford. Four Indian policeman hop quickly out of the second car. A British police superintendent, and his British deputy get more decorously out of the first. Another angle. Gandhi has turned with his two props, Ba and Mirabehn. The police are approaching him. Kallenbach is running from the fields. Nehru is hurrying from another building carrying sheaves of page proofs. Other ashramites converge from the fields and buildings. The British police superintendent (who is Scottish) stops before Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru stares at him and the policemen with growing incredulity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It stops Nehru. He looks at Gandhi and sighs in unmastered frustration, but he moves to Gandhi's side. Gandhi turns to Mirabehn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at them, then slips his free hand on Nehru's shoulder and he turns to the superintendent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Gandhi, Ba and Nehru, as they walk to the car behind the somewhat surprised superintendent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Nehru firmly. Nehru knows him well enough now not to argue -- even at this, though his face shows the struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs and Nehru struggles to join in the joke.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Bapu!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning. (Of the goat) Don't let her go. If she bumps me I am done for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. I milk her every day, she's not --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) Sedition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it is too absurd) You can't be serious! This man has just stopped a revolution!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (uncomfortably; he knows) That's as may be. I only know what I am charged to perform.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe it -- even the British can't be that stupid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Panditji -- please, help me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must help Herman -- and Ba. (He releases her, and says more loudly to the others) I have been on many trips -- it is just another trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am at your command.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Nehru) If there is one protest -- one riot -- a disgrace of any kind, I will fast again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (and now he smiles -- Gandhi to Nehru, special) I know India is not ready for my kind of independence. If I am sent to jail, perhaps that is the best protest our country can make at this time. And if it helps India, I have never refused to take His Majesty's hospitality.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AHMEDABAD - INTERIOR - DAY A quiet hum in a packed courtroom. Armed sepoys line the wall. Featuring Judge Broomfield and the clerk. The Judge is flipping through documents on the case, a troubled frown on his face. At last, he shuts the folder and nods to the clerk. The clerk turns and says in a moderately loud voice -- CLERK Call the prisoner to the bar. The sergeant-at-arms turns and moves to the door at the side of the bench. The courtroom immediately falls silent. The sergeant-at-arms opens the door -- a moment -- and Gandhi enters slowly. He has recovered a bit more, but he still moves slowly. Featuring Judge Broomfield. As Gandhi enters, he lowers his glasses, places them on his desk, and rises, facing Gandhi. Featuring two English court reporters. One nudges the other in astonishment, signaling off toward the judge. Their point of view. The clerk, confused as well as astonished, see the judge standing, facing Gandhi in respect, and dutifully, he too stands. Resume the reporters. A disbelieving exchange of glances, the sound of others standing around them. They glance back. Full shot -- the courtroom. The whole court rises, the astounded reporters the last of all. Featuring Gandhi. He takes the prisoner's stand. He looks around, a little surprised, a little affected by the demonstration. He looks up at the judge. For a minute their eyes meet, the judge makes a little bow to Gandhi. Gandhi reciprocates... and the judge sits down. Featuring the reporters shrugging incredulously to each other, as they sit once more. Later. The Advocate General is speaking from a folded journal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a little shock of reaction around the courtroom. The Advocate General smiles with a brittle disdain, then he turns to the judge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The judge nods. He turns, glancing at the empty table for defense counsel, and then to Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is almost a cruel challenge to the obviously humane Broomfield. The reporters scribble, watching the Judge even as they write, because the mere doubt in the Judge's face reflects on the whole position of the British to India. Featuring Judge Broomfield. He lowers his glasses soberly, staring at them for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at Gandhi and his own respect for him is almost poignantly manifest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A stunned intake of breath from the whole courtroom, then in absolute silence the clerk scribbles the sentence in his notebook. A pause. The Judge lowers his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He folds, and refolds his glasses and then without looking at anyone he rises. The court rises and he walks stiffly to his chambers. Featuring Gandhi. He stands, staring at Broomfield, and now it is his face that shows the respect.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ..."Non-co-operation has one aim: the overthrow of the Government. Sedition must become our creed. We must give no quarter, nor can we expect any." (He looks up at Gandhi.) Signed M. K. Gandhi, in your journal Young India, dated twenty-second March of this year. Do you deny writing it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all. (To the judge) And I will save the Court's time, M'Lord, by stating under oath that to this day I believe non-co-operation with evil is a duty. And that British rule of India is evil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Prosecution rests, M'Lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I take it you will conduct your own defense, Mr. Gandhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no defense, My Lord. I am guilty as charged. (Then testingly) And if you truly believe in the system of law you administer in my country, you must inflict on me the severest penalty possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is impossible for me to ignore that you are in a different category from any person I have ever tried, or am likely to try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a long beat) It is nevertheless my duty to sentence you -- to six years' imprisonment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a personal statement, not a real hope) If however His Majesty's Government could -- at some later date -- see fit to reduce that term, no one would be better pleased than I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Long shot. From far above the hills we see a car traveling along the road. Its style tells us some years have passed. Featuring Walker -- close. The reporter from the New York Times, whom we first saw as a younger man in South Africa. He is in an open car, turning back to look at something, his face intrigued by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see from Walker's point of view an Indian woman walking along the road, leading a tall camel that carries sacks of produce. Two young girls in ragged saris walk with her, and a boy of eight leads a smaller camel behind them. They are staring off at the car. Resume Walker. He swings back around, fascinated with what he is seeing of India. The car is an early 1930s Morris Minor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs, "Nobody knows"...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Collins has suddenly slowed the car, then swerves around a pair of elephants hauling logs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Collins glances at him in surprise as he steers the car around another procession of camels heading toward the port.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker smiles too, but it soon passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Collins looks at him in real surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He honks as he goes around a wooden-wheeled cart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (English accent) Yes, I'm sure that's exactly what they hoped. Put him in prison a few years and with luck he'd be forgotten. And maybe they'd even subdue him...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he certainly wasn't forgotten! And as soon as he got out he was back tramping the country, preaching non-violence and demanding a free India. Everybody knows another showdown's coming -- but when, and over what --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I read you account of that crowd in Calcutta and that he was twisting the Lion's tail again...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (falteringly) ...and I knew something had to give. And I was determined to be here when it did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How does a reporter in Central America learn that Gandhi was born in Porbandar anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He certainly makes good copy. (A laugh.) The other day Winston Churchill called him "that half-naked Indian fakir."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I met him once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean Gandhi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Back in South Africa... (reflectively) long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was he like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lots of hair... and a little like a college freshman -- trying to figure everything out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he must've found some of the answers...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PROBANDER - INTERIOR - DAY Simple. Austere. Filtered light. Featuring Gandhi -- close. He is looking straight ahead. Reverse angle. Across the emptiness of the temple, Ba faces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle featuring Walker and Collins, who are sitting alone, in the cool shadows of the temple, watching with fascination as Gandhi and Ba repeat their marriage ceremony for them, Walker jotting notes occasionally, but his eyes always glued to Gandhi and Ba, who are in part lost in memories and echoes of a significance only they can know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wide shot. Showing the two of them before the altar of the temple, moving closer to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close shot -- Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Walker, now too entranced by the ceremony, by the depth of layered emotions in Gandhi and Ba's voices and eyes to take any notes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba and Gandhi. Near to meeting now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba takes the last step, so that they are face to face. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment their eyes hold -- the many dreams, and hopes and pain -- the love of many years. Walker watches, his own face taut with emotion. Resume Gandhi and Ba. And Gandhi slowly lifts his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He touches Ba's lips with his extended fingers and she kisses them gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has lifted her fingers to his mouth and he kisses them gently. Featuring Walker and Collins both touched, the overtly cynical American obviously even more than the likeable Englishman. Gandhi turns to them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a step forward) "In every worthy wish of yours, I shall be your helpmate."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a step) "Take a fourth step, that we may be ever full of joy."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a step)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: will ever live devoted to you, speaking words of love and praying for your happiness."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Take a fifth step, that we may serve the people."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: will follow close behind you and help to serve the people."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Take a sixth step, that we may follow our vows in life."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: will follow you in all our vows and duties."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a last step) "Take the seventh step, that we may ever live as friends."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "You are my best friend... my highest guru, and my sovereign lord."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I put a sweetened wheat cake in her mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I put a sweetened wheat cake in his mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And with that we were pronounced man and wife. (Solemnly) We were both thirteen...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PORBANDAR - EXTERIOR - DAWN A tiny, beautiful city rising steeply out of the Arabian Sea with tall, thick-walled buildings, half-fortresses, half- homes, their white walls tinted amber and gold now by the early light of the sun. Featuring Gandhi, sitting on a promontory watching the sunrise in solemn meditation... He becomes aware of the sound of footsteps and he turns to see Walker approaching, a little knapsack over his shoulder. Gandhi smiles. Walker comes to his side, looking out over the bay and city, truly impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker looks down at him. Gandhi scowls up in the early light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both watch the waves beat on the shore a moment, the changing hues of the sunrise on the whites of Porbandar.
direction.name: direction
