direction.raw_text: He looks out to sea, and we intercut his face with Walker's, the sea, and the town itself as the sun turns it white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker studies him as this profound man reaches, in his middle years, a profound insight. Featuring Gandhi staring out to sea, his mind locked in reflection, and suddenly his head lifts, his eyes become alert, he is caught by some excitement which he weighs for a moment, then he stands, his manner suddenly tingling with optimism. Walker stares at him, then at what Gandhi seems to be looking at. His point of view. The waves lapping the shore below them. Walker turns back to Gandhi, puzzled. But there is no mistaking the sudden glow in Gandhi's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at him, a teasing smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grin broadens, and then he starts briskly down the promontory. Walker scrambles up after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gulls fly over them, squawking in the growing light. Gandhi pauses, looking up at the gulls, then back down to the sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns from the sea to Walker, his eyes confident, elated, then he continues on down the promontory. Still baffled, Walker glances at the sea, at him, then hurries after. Full shot. The waves running against the shore...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even as a boy I thought so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trying to keep track of you is making me change all my sleeping habits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you've come all this way because you think something is going to happen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hm. (Then weightedly) Is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps. I've come here to think about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (musing) Do you remember much of South Africa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A great deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've traveled so far -- and thought so much. (He smiles in self- mockery, and turns toward the city.) As you can see, my city was a sea city -- always filled with Hindus and Muslims and Sikhs and Jews and Persians. (He looks at Walker.) The temple where you were yesterday is of my family's sect, the Pranami. It was Hindu of course but the priests used to read from the Muslim Koran and the Hindu Gita, moving from one to the other as though it mattered not at all which book was read as long as God was worshipped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was a boy I used to sing a song in that temple: "A true disciple knows another's woes as his own. He bows to all and despises none... Earthly possessions hold him not." Like all boys I said the words, not thinking of what they meant or how they might be influencing me. (He looks at Walker... then out to the sea again, shaking his head.) I've traveled so far... and all I've done is come back home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what you're going to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It would have been very uncivil of me to let you make such a long trip for nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going back to the ashram (then firmly) and then I'm going to prove to the new Viceroy that the King's writ no longer runs in India!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Close shot -- the Viceroy, a "new one," Lord Irwin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another angle. He is looking in astonishment at his principal secretary. His ADC, a general, a brigadier, a senior police officer are with him. Like him they hold the same offices, but are a new team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin looks at him, still trying to penetrate the significance of the act. The senior police officer helps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin has listened; it's beginning to make a little sense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The principal secretary blanches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin looks at his ADC, then paces a bit, pondering it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment as Irwin considers it, then it is the general who speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin has turned to him. And this makes up his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is concerned enough to be angry, but certain enough to be dogmatic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Salt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. He is going to march to the sea and make salt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is a Royal Monopoly on the manufacture of salt, sir. It's illegal to make it or sell it without a Government license.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- he's breaking the law. What will he be depriving us of, two rupees of salt tax?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a serious attack on the revenue, sir. Its primary importance is symbolic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't patronize me, Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. I -- in this climate, sir, nothing lives without water -- or salt. Our absolute control of it is a control on the pulse of India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's the basis of this "Declaration of Independence"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. The day he sets off everyone is supposed to raise the flag of "Free India." Then he walks some two hundred and forty miles to the sea and makes salt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I say ignore it. Let them raise their damn flags, let him make his salt. It's only symbolic if we choose to make it so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointedly) He's going to arrive at the sea on the anniversary of the massacre at Amritsar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General Edgar is right -- ignore it. Mr. Gandhi will find it's going to take a great deal more than a pinch of salt to bring down the British Empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAWN It is very early, the light just beginning to break, and we are looking out across the river toward the distant town, and against the pink glow of the sky we can see people in groups wading across the river toward the ashram. And suddenly a mass of people, hidden by the embankment, appear at the top of the steps coming up from the river, and the camera lifts slightly with their movement and we see that they are but the forerunners of a long tendril of humanity that stretches across the river, all the way back to the distant outskirts of the city. And around the ashram many fires are burning, people are cooking breakfast, some are packing knapsacks for the journey, others are strewing the path from the ashram with leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAWN Quiet, just the buzz of activity from outside the building. Gandhi lies on a mat and Ba and Mirabehn are massaging him with oil as he checks page proofs, an oil lamp by his side. Nehru sits cross-legged next to him, taking the proofs as Gandhi finishes them. Maulana Azad sits to one side. Behind them Desai is making notes on Gandhi's instructions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Nehru and Azad solemnly to emphasize the point. Nehru nods; a little smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means Gandhi of course, and Gandhi accepts the reference, but it is the acceptance of the strict sergeant major: "Don't fail me." Then he looks to Azad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru nods. Ba moves to massage the top of Gandhi's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi grins, looking at Mirabehn, who is massaging his legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at Nehru, a benign shrug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru smiles. He stands, having taken the last proof sheet. Azad rises with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is pleasurably impressed with that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans back and closes his eyes. Ba rubs his head soothingly. Nehru bends and squeezes his arm in farewell. Gandhi nods, not opening his eyes. Nehru and Azad smile at Ba and leave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Nehru) ...the real test will come if I am arrested. If there is violence we lose all our moral advantage. This time it mustn't happen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not beginners anymore. We've been trained by a strict sergeant major.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I'm taken, Maulana is to lead the march. If he is arrested, Patel, then Kripalani, then yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should be relaxing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure I'm fit for at least five hundred miles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should ride the pony. It is not necessary to walk to prove the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have two of them bossing me now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must get these to the printer. (He looks down at Gandhi.) I know it will succeed. Even my mother is prepared to march.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Jinnah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) He's waiting. He's not prepared to accept it will mean as much as you think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles confidently) Wait and see... wait and see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LATER - EXTERIOR - DAY The sun higher, but still early light. A green, white and saffron flag (the colors of India) is pulled up an uneven pole. The sound of gentle clapping. Gandhi is off to one side, just in front of the veranda of his bungalow, not paying attention to the ceremony. Ba and Mirabehn watch from the veranda as Pyarelal (Desai's new assistant), with a knapsack over his own shoulders, hands Gandhi his. As Gandhi slips it on, the ashramite boy whom we saw with the goat hands him a long staff. And Gandhi moves around the edge of the bungalow, heading toward the entrance of the ashram. A long line of ashramites and marchers stretches from opposite the flagpole to the entrance of the ashram. As Gandhi walks briskly along it, they turn, ready to follow him. When he nears the entrance Gandhi sees Walker standing in front of a collection of newsmen, cameramen, a newsreel crew. He begins to smile, Walker returns it. Gandhi pauses by him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles. He turns back toward his bungalow. Ba and Mirabehn stand there watching, Desai with them. Gandhi holds their gaze a second, then turns and starts forward. Pyarelal takes up a position next to him, the marchers follow. Featuring Walker. He steps back, letting Gandhi proceed into the range of the cameras on his own. The crowd around the entrance throws flowers in Gandhi's path, some calling out, "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!" Gandhi passes the cameramen and starts along the trail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (of the press) You've done me a great service.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a grin, then a play on Gandhi's words to him) It would have been uncivil of me to have let you make such a long trip for nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A thinner crowd here, but going all along the path. To one side we see two police cars drawn up, and several policemen (a British officer, a British sergeant, and four Indian constables) lined up near them. As Gandhi nears them Walker moves up beside him. Some of the newspaper cameramen trot behind to get the picture of Gandhi's arrest. Among the newsmen we see Collins. Featuring Gandhi and Walker, Pyarelal just behind them all glancing ahead at the police, who are now quite near.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker smiles -- a little uneasily -- for they are now near the police. Gandhi nods to them amiably as he passes along in front of them. Walker is turning, watching for a move from the police but begins to grasp that there may be none. He hurries along closer to Gandhi again, one eye still on the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi glances at him. Walker too wears a knapsack. Gandhi nods to it, though never breaking his pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods politely toward the British police officer at the end of the police line. Walker stops, letting the procession march on by him, looking at the British police officer, then writing busily in his notebook. Collins stop by him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it over if they arrest you now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not if they arrest me -- or a thousand -- or ten thousand. (He looks at Walker.) It is not only generals who know how to plan campaigns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if they don't arrest you? What if they don't react at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still have your notebook? (Walker fumbles for it; Gandhi goes right on talking.) The function of a civil resister is to provoke response. And we will continue to provoke until they respond, or they change the law. They are not in control -- we are. That is the strength of civil resistance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wryly) He said he's in charge...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A dusty approach to a dusty little village. Both sides of the track are lined with peasants holding flower petals and leaves, all gazing expectantly down the road. Behind them the village is strung with the green, white and saffron colors of Independence. Two large policemen stand arms-akimbo at the front of them all, their postures imposing and threatening, though the impression is somewhat weakened by the children skirting around them. A little band of drummers and flute players suddenly begins to play. The crowd starts to jump up to see, and the flower petals begin to float in the sky. "Gandhi! Long live Mahatma Gandhi!" Another angle. Gandhi and the procession of marchers and ashramites stride down the dusty road toward them. A newsreel truck and crew ride along about two-thirds of the way back. A car of cameramen and reporters tails at the end. Featuring Gandhi. He looks at Walker, walking along a few paces behind him, at the side of the procession. He is wiping sweat from his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles and turns back. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And grinning at it, he passes by the policemen and into the cheers of the crowd. Long shot, high. As the procession trails into the village, we see several villagers, knapsacks or bundles strung over their shoulders, run around the police and join the end of the procession.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you going to walk all the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a weary grin) My name is Walk-er. And I intend to report it the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) "My name is Walk-er"...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT In the dark a large group of students comes stumbling, laughing, across the ditch that separates the road from the field. The student leader gets clear of the ditch and comes upon Pyarelal and Walker. They are standing near a group of American newsmen playing poker by a campfire. He addresses Pyarelal good-naturedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The student leader follows his gaze and the camera pans off with his glance. We see that the numbers have grown immensely. Fires dot the field and spread and spread and spread. Behind Walker and Pyarelal the newsreel truck and three cars for reporters are spread out around the fires. We identify a couple of Frenchmen and a Japanese. Walker looks at Pyarelal and shakes his head in wonder at it all.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've come to join the march. What do we do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bluntly) Be sure you're awake in the morning. (It comes from a knowledge of students. He smiles and nods off.) Find a place to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAWN A small Indian boy is high in a dead tree. Below him a couple of bone-thin cattle graze in the early light as he stares off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - BOY'S POINT OF VIEW - EXTERIOR - DAWN The huge procession stretched out along the road. Resume the boy. He grins as though he is privy to some great secret.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A blunt, rotund, powerful-looking woman (Sarojini Naidu) in an outrageously colorful sari strides along the dusty road as though she could cover another thousand miles -- and means to. The sound of hundreds of marching feet, of cars, some distant singing. The camera lifts and pulls back. We see that Naidu is marching just behind Gandhi, like a determined lieutenant, and that the procession has grown even greater. Two newsreel trucks now, four cars of reporters, some people riding donkeys, some walking with camels trailing, loaded with belongings. And at the "Y" junctions the newsreel crews suddenly go into action because another enormous procession is waiting to join the first, mingling already, making one immense column of humanity. And as they pass the camera up close we see an extraordinary variety of participants: old, young, students, peasants, ladies in saris and jewels, Muslims, Hindus, Sikhs, Christian nuns, Untouchables, merchants, some vigorous and determined, others disheveled, tired and determined. Suddenly the sound of waves and gentle wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The camera closing fast (helicopter) as the silhouette of a man appears running up a sand dune, lifting his arms to the sky and the camera sweeps over him and up, revealing a crescent of beach and ocean, and for a second it holds on the sea as it did at Porbandar, then pivots to the truly astronomical crowd thronging the shore, an immense wheel of human beings, and in its hub a gathering around Gandhi. We descend on that center, recognizing the newsmen, Walker, Pyarelal, Sarojini Naidu, and at last Gandhi picking up a handful of natural salt and lifting it high. During the last of this
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wide-angle shot. Gandhi in the center of the wildly cheering crowd, the camera pulling back and back... and the shot becomes black and white, and we hear the music of Movietone News.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with that we get the Movietone Music tag and as the film fades, the lights go up on
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Man needs salt as he needs air and water. This salt comes from the Indian Ocean. (The salt crystals are added to an urn already partially full. The camera pulls back and Gandhi lifts the urn. All around him the pressing crowd: newsreel cameramen, reporters -- Walker, Collins, Naidu, Pyarelal. Firmly) Let every Indian claim it as his right!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and so once more the man of non- violence has challenged the might of the British Empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY A couple of civil servants move about to raise the window shades while Lord Irwin stares at the blank screen set up in his office. The general, the brigadier, the senior police officer, Irwin's ADC and the principal secretary are all present. The two men who ran the projector are quietly dismantling it. Finally, Irwin turns to the senior police officer, who fidgets, but answers the implied questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Irwin nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the first time he is truly angry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're making it everywhere, sir -- mobs of them -- publicly. Congress leaders are selling it on the streets of Delhi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're being made fools of around the world!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't there any instruction from London?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're required to stop it. (He stands, his mind made up.) And stop it we will. (He looks at the senior police officer.) I don't care if we fill the jails, stop it. Arrest anyone, any rank -- except Gandhi. We'll cut his strength from under him. And then we'll deal with the Mahatma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A young British subaltern trots up to the wall and looks down. His face falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The beach. Subaltern's point of view. Packed with people making salt, selling salt, buying salt. Resume the British subaltern. He looks back. His point of view. Behind him there is an open military truck and about twenty sepoys. Formidable for an ordinary crowd, nothing to handle this. The subaltern stiffens bravely and signals the men somewhat unconvincingly from the truck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right -- jump to it -- clear this beach!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Men, women and children are making little paper packets of salt from piles heaped along long tables. A group of policemen barge into the room, knocking tables and salt and paper in every direction with their lathis, seizing some of the volunteers for arrest. In the chaos an old man calmly picks up a piece of paper from the floor, a handful of salt, and folds another packet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CITY STREET - EXTERIOR - DAY Nehru is on the back of a big open truck that is stationary in the street. The truck is loaded with boxes that contain salt packets and Nehru and eight or nine others are selling them to people who flock about the truck. The sound of horses. Nehru lifts his head. Mounted Indian police are coming down either side of the street, a wave of foot police running forward down the center. Some of the people run, others deliberately stand fast. The mounted police converge on the truck. Nehru is grabbed, and hurled so that he half falls, half leaps to the street. One of the men with him is knocked along the ground by a policeman. He is young and vigorous and he swivels on the ground as though to strike back. Nehru lunges toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a lathi is brought smashing across the side of Nehru's head. He is knocked to his knees; blood streams from his head. He feels the side of his head, the blood soaking his hand. He struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who has struck him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It stops the policeman for a second, and a sergeant suddenly intrudes, recognizing Nehru.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant sighs grimly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No violence, Zia!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (repeating quietly, as though to Zia) ...no violence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're Nehru -- NEHRU I'm an illegal trader in salt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT The desk lights are on. Irwin, the senior police officer, the principal secretary. Tension, fatigue, frustration as the senior police officer outlines the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The senior police officer looks up, realizing his gaffe and wishes desperately he could relive the last couple of minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means incite violence. The Viceroy ponders it -- favorably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The senior police officer is brought up by the chill directness of it. He looks at Irwin and the principal secretary for a moment in uncertainty. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns to leave Irwin speaks -- almost offhandedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The senior police officer stares at him, then
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...There's been no time to keep figures, but there must be ninety -- a hundred thousand under arrest. (Grimly, incredibly) And it still goes on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) Who's leading them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know! Nehru, Patel, almost every Congress Official is in jail... and their wives and their children -- we've even arrested Nehru's mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrewdly) Has there been any violence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted, offhand) Oh, in Karachi the police fired on a crowd and killed a couple of people and -- (and this hurts) and in Peshawar the Deputy Police Commissioner lost his head and... and opened fire with a machine gun. (He looks up at them quickly, defensively.) But he's facing a disciplinary court! You can't expect things like that not to happen when -- IRWIN (dryly) I believe the question was intended to discover if there was any violence of their side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, sir -- no, I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (again the Machiavellian mind) Perhaps if we arrested Gandhi, it might --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to senior police officer) He's addressed this letter directly to you, has he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir, he has. The usual -- India's salt belongs to India -- but then he says flatly that he personally is going to lead a raid tomorrow on the Dharasana Salt Works.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Thank him for his letter, and put him in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. Yes, sir. It will be my pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Fields, keep that salt works open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delighted) Yes, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockade-like entrance. Above the gate we see the sign DHARASANA SALT WORKS. Before it six British police officers and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen. They face their opposition, unmoving, tense. The camera pans from them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a huge group of volunteers lining up to face the police as tautly as the police face them. Walker is off to one side, climbing to stand in the back of Collin's car. He watches, looking tensely from one group to the other, almost terrified by what seems about to happen. Collins leans against the back of the car near him, watching with an equally appalled expectancy. There are two other reporters near them. From Walker's point of view. We see Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance. We hear only a shuffle of feet, the clank of a lathi against a metal police buckle. The air itself seems breathless with tension. Featuring Azad. He has approached the chief police officer. He stops before him politely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Azad looks at him a second, then glances at the troops. He is clearly afraid, but there is an air of tragic inevitability in his face. He moves back to address the volunteers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and starts down the dip toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots, as Azad leads the first row of volunteers down and up the dip. We intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable onslaught, the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with the volunteers a foot from them, the police strike with their lathis. A groan of empathic anguish from the waiting volunteers, but then we get A series of shots As the next row moves forward and the horror of the one-sided mayhem proceeds heads are cracked, faces split, ribs smashed, and yet one row of volunteers follows another, and another into the unrelenting police, who knock bleeding bodies out of the way, down into the dip, swing till sweat pours from their faces and bodies. And through it we intercut with Mirabehn and the Indian women rescuing the wounded, carrying them on stretchers to be bandaged. We see Walker helping once or twice, turning, watching, torn between being a professional spectator and a normal human being. And always the volunteers coming, never stopping, never offering resistance. And finally on sound there is an insistent click, click, click, like a thud of the lathis but becoming clearly the slap of an impatient hand on a telephone cradle and out of the carnage of the salt works we dissolve to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I would like admission to the Works.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (equally politely) I am sorry, sir. That cannot be allowed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last night they took Gandhiji from us. They expect us to lose heart or to fight back. We will not lose heart, we will not fight back. In his name we will be beaten. As he has taught us, we will not raise a hand. "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) Now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - TWILIGHT Close shot -- a telephone cradle being pounded. Walker is at the phone at a table in the corner of the small, cluttered store. His clothes are matted with blood and dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he continues urgently reading the story that lies on his notes on the little stand before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shifts the mangled notes and comes to his last paragraph. He speaks it trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LORD IRWIN'S OFFICE - INTERIOR - DAY Silence. The camera moves across the empty room and discovers Irwin, standing by himself, looking out of the window down into the street. Closer. His numb, motionless face is stirred to consciousness by something outside. He focuses somberly on it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into the phone) Hello! Ed! Ed! Goddammit, don't cut me off! (Then suddenly he's through.) Ed! Okay -- yeah -- right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "They walked, with heads up, without music, or cheering, or any hope of escape from injury or death." (His voice is taut, harshly professional.) "It went on and on and on. Women carried the wounded bodies from the ditch until they dropped from exhaustion. But still it went on."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Whatever moral ascendance the West held was lost today. India is free for she has taken all that steel and cruelty can give, and she has neither cringed nor retreated." (On Walker close. His sweating, blood and dirt-stained face near tears.) "In the words of his followers, 'Long live Mahatma Gandhi.' "
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - IRWIN'S POINT OF VIEW - EXTERIOR - DAY Through the formal entrance comes a single black car. A motorcycle policeman precedes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The black car pulls up before the front of the palace and stops. There is no sign of activity. It is as though the building and grounds are deserted except for Irwin alone in his office. Gandhi gets out of the car. He too is alone. In his dhoti and shawl he starts to mount the grand stairs. Wide angle. The great palace, the magnificent entrance, and the little man in the dhoti, who in a sense has conquered it all, marching to the great doors. Two Gurkhas spring to attention and the doors are swung open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY The principal secretary, with a look of faint distaste for someone out of shot, discreetly moves out of the doors, and closes them behind him. Featuring Gandhi, just inside the door. He is looking across the wide office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverse angle. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk looking, still, in some kind of shock, staring at Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift cut to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am aware that I must have given you much cause for irritation, your Excellency. I hope it will not stand between us as men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gandhi, I have instructions to request your attendance at an All- Government Conference in London to discuss -- to discuss the possible Independence of India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Wide screen, but slightly under-cranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. A. Gandhi, Mirabehn and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails -- Mirabehn is holding the tether of a goat -- all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere. B. Gandhi on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London being greeted by a cheering crowd. Mirabehn holds an umbrella over him as he takes a bouquet from a little child. The now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beams possessively at his side. C. Gandhi, in his dhoti, waving to a small crowd as he enters the gates of Buckingham Palace. A London bobby watches. D. Gandhi, taking his seat at the conference table among the formally -- in some Maharajahs' cases, elaborately -- dressed delegates. A gavel is struck and Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening address.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beneath its unctuous political veneer it is blatantly divisive and clearly reveals the true intent of the Conference. As Gandhi looks at MacDonald, we read on his face his perception of the sad truth. E. Gandhi, Mirabehn and Charlie walking under an umbrella in the rain, their heads bent in glum conversation. F. Gandhi being welcomed and kissed by a group of millworkers outside a large mill entrance identified by the sign GREENFIELD COTTON MILL, LANCASHIRE. He is hugged and squeezed by some hefty female millworkers, all grinning happily, Gandhi not least. G. Gandhi in a radio studio, seated at a table, a large microphone labeled "CBS" before him, technicians and Mirabehn in the glass booth behind him, Walker across the table from him, the "On the Air" sign bright...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walker cringes, glancing at the lighted "On the Air" sign. He signals "Yes" frantically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the booth. Everybody including Walker and Mirabehn are nodding "Yes." Gandhi shrugs, grins at everyone's excitement, and begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the speech continues in the thin, static-y tones of thirties' radio, we see Mirabehn and the technicians listening in the control room./ Walker, across the table from Gandhi./ The outside of Broadcasting House./ The Empire State Building and Manhattan./ A mid-western farmhouse./ A thirties' radio set in a thirties' American living room./ A family, listening, kids playing on the floor, half ignoring it, the mother ironing, the father in an armchair, a newspaper open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: H. Gandhi shaking hands with MacDonald outside No. 10 Downing Street, MacDonald smiling the politician's smile, Gandhi smiling rather sadly. I. Gandhi on the deck of a boat, sitting on a deck chair, wrapped in blankets, staring somberly out to sea. Reverse angle: the wake of the boat in the vast ocean.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A SUCCESSION OF BLACK-AND-WHITE "NEWSREEL" SEQUENCES OF GANDHI'S VISIT TO ENGLAND AND THE ALL-GOVERNMENT CONFERENCE

dialogue.raw_text: I think our first duty is to recognize that there is not one India, but several: a Hindu India, a Muslim India, and India of Princely States. And all these must be respected -- and cared for -- not just one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Walker) Do I speak into that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are they ready? Do I start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am glad to speak to America where so many friends exist that I know only in my heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing over all) I think your interest and the world's has fallen on India, not only because we are struggling for freedom, but because the way we are doing so is unique as far as history shows us. Here in Europe mighty nations are, it seems, already contemplating another war, though I think they, and all the world, are sick to death of bloodspilling. All of us are seeking a way out, and I flatter myself that perhaps the ancient land of India will offer such a way. If we are to make progress we must not repeat history, but make history. And I myself will die before I betray our belief that love is a stronger weapon than hate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The gentle sounds of the country. A girl of twelve leads a limping goat slowly across the grass. She pauses and looks up questioningly. Reverse angle -- close. Gandhi is watching from the porch of his bungalow. We can tell he is sitting and turned to watch the goat, but we see only him and a portion of the bungalow behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back. Another angle. He is spinning (expertly), and gathered on the porch with him are Nehru and Jinnah and Patel and Azad and Kripalani. Desai and Pyarelal are inconspicuously in attendance as always, Pyarelal now clearly sharing Desai's role as secretary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is in his white suit, the black-ribboned pince-nez. He sits on a wicker chair, Nehru and Patel lean against the railing, Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor like Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi winds up what he has done, and starts to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi has moved toward the steps. He stops and looks at Patel. A wry, gentle smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Nehru. He looks at Jinnah and shrugs. Jinnah takes it less philosophically and his eyes burn with anger as he watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured goat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is only a sprain. Take her to the river, and we'll make a mud-pack for her. Go -- I won't be long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So the truth is, after all your travels, all your efforts, they've stopped the campaign and sent you home empty-handed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are only clinging to old dreams (looks up from his spinning to Jinnah) and trying to split us in the old way. But the will has gone -- Independence will drop like a ripe apple. The only question is when (another glance at Jinnah) and how.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I say when is now -- and we will determine how.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Precisely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are preparing for war. I will not support it, but I do not intend to take advantage of their danger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blithely, but to the point) That's when you take advantage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. That is just another way of striking back. We have come a long way together with the British. When they leave we want to see them off as friends. (He starts down the steps and heads for the river.) And now, if you'll excuse me, there is something I must attend to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resignedly) "Mud packs."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . INTERIOR. DUSK. Gandhi is moving with the stream of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section. Ba and Mirabehn are struggling along behind him, Desai and Pyarelal completing the little group. They pass a newspaper stand: "Hitler's Armies Sweep On." As they move out into the flux of the station we see many uniforms, the sense of a nation readying for war. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian troops. As Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant (a Captain) move out from one side of the troops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stops, looks up at him, at the troops behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi shakes his head with a weary grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The British Colonel signals back to the troops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a detail marches up to them, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares at the adjutant belligerently. He looks flummoxed. Later. Long shot -- high. The colonel and his adjutant striding toward the exit of the station. Following behind them, a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi. The camera tracks across the platform and we see they are being followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba. And the camera tracks again and we see they are being followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Mirabehn!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gandhi -- sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have instructions to inquire as to the subject of your speech tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The value of goat's milk in daily diet. (Into his eyes) But you can be sure I will also speak against war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir. That can't be allowed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right, Mrs. Gandhi. I have orders to return with you and your companion to the Mahatma's ashram.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you take my husband, I intend to speak in his place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A jeep bounces along the road. It is driven by an American lieutenant and his passenger is a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform (Margaret Bourke-White). As the jeep passes the camera we pan with it and see the walls of a palace ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jeep slithers to a stop, and Bourke-White grabs a camera that is strapped around her, stands, and takes a picture of the palace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stop! Wait a minute!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BOURKE-WHITE'S POINT OF VIEW - EXTERIOR - DAY The palace looks evocative -- a lonely, incongruous building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY LIEUTENANT It was the Aga Khan's palace, but they've turned it into a prison. Bourke-White slips back down into her seat; we see the arm band on her jacket: "Press." The lieutenant starts the jeep up and they head toward the gate, where we see a British soldier on guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White just absorbs it, staring at the palace, taking in the experience with the appetite of her breed, and her own particular sensitivity.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting over the motor) They've got most of the leading Congress politicians in this one. But Nehru and some others are over in Dehra Dun. Your timing's pretty lucky. They had your Mr. Gandhi cut off from the press but last month his personal secretary died and they've let up on the restrictions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AGA KHAN'S PALACE - INTERIOR - DAY Gandhi sits by the window that is grilled rather than barred. He is spinning in a shaft of light -- and looking off -- as we hear a camera click and the rustle of movement. His hair, only half-gray in London, is now white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White -- who has been moving, crouching to shoot him and the light -- sags back against the wall, relaxing at last. She has a smile as penetrating and warming as his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi grins and glances toward his dhoti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meaning he doesn't wear many clothes. Bourke-White bursts into an appreciative radiance -- already she has assessed him, and been won.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I have heard of Life Magazine. (A smile.) I have even heard of Margaret Bourke- White. But I don't know why either should be interested in an old man sitting in prison when the world is blowing itself to pieces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat -- and she smiles) You're the only man I know who makes his own clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, but for me that's not much of an accomplishment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AGA KHAN'S PALACE - EXTERIOR - DAY Gandhi walks along, Bourke-White loping along beside him, a little distance away, listening, but searching too for an angle, a moment that is right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has Gandhi in the foreground, a soldier on the wall above and behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi shrugs but suffers it. We feature him, low, from her point of view, as he walks on, the soldier pacing on the wall in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She clicks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No -- prison is rather agreeable to me, and there is no doubt that after the war, independence will come. My only worry is what shape it will take. Jinnah has -- BOURKE-WHITE Stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now go on -- just as you were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coaching)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...what shape it will take." Jinnah has -- what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at first disconcerted, but then flowing) Jinnah has -- has cooperated with the British. It has given him power and the freedom to speak, and he has filled the Muslims with fears of what will happen to them in a country that is predominantly Hindu. (He stops, lowering his head gravely.) That I find hard to bear -- even in prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A spinning wheel works rapidly. The camera lifts. Gandhi is at the wheel and he is smiling off at Bourke-White, who is trying ineptly to imitate him on another spinning wheel. The garden they are in has gone to seed a bit, but with latticed fretwork in the walls dappling sunlight on the grass and shrubs it is still beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's grinning at her own frustration and she keeps trying, but there's no doubt she means it. Gandhi's smile broadens. Wryly he lifts his own "product" -- a tiny roll of thread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they both laugh... a guard on the wall distantly looks at them wonderingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she responds to the sophistication of that observation. He pivots around, moving beside her, and slowly demonstrates the process, taking her hands, guiding her. Bourke-White watches him as much as the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he smiles a little wisely at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His tone is not altogether patient. She looks at him in surprise and he sighs tolerantly. Then reflectively
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White looks at him and there is enough sense in this argument to give her pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares at him, and we know she thinks him much more profound than she had thought initially.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (archly, but emphatically of the spinning) I do not see it as the solution of the twentieth century's problems!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a friend who keeps telling me how much it costs him to keep me in poverty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bit more seriously) But I know happiness does not come with things -- even twentieth century things. It can come from work, and pride in what you do. (He looks at her steadily.) It will not necessarily be "progress" for India if she simply imports the unhappiness of the West.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But do you really believe you could use non-violence against someone like Hitler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a thoughtful pause) Not without defeats -- and great pain. (He looks at her.) But are there no defeats in this war -- no pain? (For a moment the thought hangs, and then Gandhi takes their hands back to the spinning.) What you cannot do is accept injustice. From Hitler -- or anyone. You must make the injustice visible -- be prepared to die like a soldier to do so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is my finger supposed to be wrapped around that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) No. That is what you get for distracting me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you expect when you talk like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to unravel the mess) I expect you to show as much patience as I am now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every enemy is a human being -- even the worst of them. And he believes he is right and you are a beast. (And now a little smile.) And if you beat him over the head you will only convince him. But you suffer, to show him that he is wrong, your sacrifice creates an atmosphere of understanding -- if not with him, then in the hearts of the rest of the community on whom he depends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you are right, you will win -- after much pain. (He looks at her, then smiles in his own ironic way.) If you are wrong, well, then, only you will suffer the blows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AGA KHAN'S PALACE - INTERIOR - NIGHT Ba, Mirabehn and Bourke-White sit on straw mats around the room, an oil lamp is the only light. It is women's talk, but Ba is defending her husband, speaking simply, but with total conviction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White accepts it at face value. She opens another line of inquiry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's terribly curious, but she doesn't want to offend. Ba sees both the curiosity and the hesitancy. She smiles across at Mirabehn, then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again Ba smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shrugs... the implication is it was a long time ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at them soberly and then they all burst into laughter like girls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...not at all. Bapu has always said there were two kinds of slavery in India -- one for women, one for the untouchables -- and he has always fought against both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it rankle, being separated from him this way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... but we see each other in the day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delicately) But not at night...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In Hindu philosophy the way to God is to free yourself of possessions -- and the passions that inflame to anger and jealousy. (A smile.) Bapu has always struggled to find the way to God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean he -- he gave up -- (how to phrase it, finally) married life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four times he tried -- and failed. (Mirabehn and Bourke- White grin. The older woman gives a wistful smile.) But then he took a solemn vow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he has never broken it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - TWILIGHT Military move quietly but urgently in and out around the main entrance. Two military ambulances are drawn up nearby. A British major comes down the steps quickly. He is almost at the bottom when a British army doctor starts to go up them. The major signals him to one side. They talk quietly and confidentially.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The major looks defeated and depressed by the news.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've got permission to move her -- he can go too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's had a coronary throm -- a serious heart failure. She wouldn't survive a trip. It's best to leave her -- and hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - TWILIGHT Ba lies on a mat, a pillow beneath her head, her eyes closed, her breathing short. Mirabehn sits next to her, rubbing a hand up and down her arm. Gandhi sits a little distance away, staring at the floor and into nothingness. Pyarelal sits inconspicuously behind him. Azad and Patel come to the doorway, Patel makes the pranam toward Ba and holds it as he obviously prays. Azad has bowed his head and he too is clearly making some prayer for her. Finally Azad takes just a step forward. Gandhi looks up at him. For a moment he folds his hands absently, then he stands. He moves to Ba's side and kneels. She does not open her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba's eyes flutter open. She holds her hand out to him and he takes it. When he goes to release it, she clutches it. Gandhi hesitates, and then he sits, holding Ba's hand in his lap. He looks across at Mirabehn and nods for her to go. Mirabehn smiles weakly, gives Ba a last little rub of farewell and stands. The doorway. Patel stands, letting Mirabehn pass before him and do down the corridor with Azad. He looks back. His point of view. Gandhi sitting, holding Ba's hand, his eyes once more on the floor in their empty stare. Another angle -- later. The light has changed. A fly moves along a small section of the floor that still contains a ribbon of the dying sunlight. Gandhi still sits, holding Ba's hand, staring into nothingness. The doctor appears in the doorway. He pauses, nods amiably to Gandhi, though Gandhi does not react to his presence at all. Moving quietly, the doctor goes to the other side of Ba and crouches, and lifts her wrist to feel her pulse. He holds it for a moment, then lifts his eyes in doubt and sudden fateful apprehension. He glances at her, then slowly lowers her arm and puts the branches of his stethoscope in his ears. He puts the acoustic bell over her heart... a moment, and he lifts it slowly, his face confirming for us what he and we already know: there is no heartbeat. He glances at Pyarelal, who only lowers his eyes. The doctor turns his head slowly to Gandhi. Gandhi. His point of view. His posture is utterly unchanged, Ba's hand still in his lap, his eyes still staring emptily at the floor in front of him, but suddenly tears begin to run down his cheeks. He does not move, there is no change in his empty stare, but the tears continue to flow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is time for my walk -- I won't be long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The funeral pyre burns, its work almost done. Mirabehn, Patel, Azad, Pyarelal, stand with other prisoners and the military wardens in solemn obeisance to the dead -- and the living, for Gandhi sits a little distance from the pyre, wrapped in his shawl, staring at the dying embers in tragic and impenetrable isolation as though he may never move again. Close shot -- Mirabehn watching him her face wet with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Extreme close shot. A piece of cloth, shimmering in a stiff breeze... For a moment we hold it in silence and then we hear the sound of an aircraft growing louder and louder. And slowly the camera pulls back and we see that the cloth is part of a pennant of the nose of an aircraft. We cut from the pennant to see the aircraft stopping before a reception area, a carpet rolled out toward its door. An Indian regimental band strikes up martial music. A detachment of Indian Royal Air Force comes to attention at the shouted command of their NCO. Featuring the aircraft doors. An elaborately dressed military aide opens the door and Lord Louis Mountbatten, resplendent in naval uniform, steps out onto the platform. He pauses and renders a salute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru, Lady Mountbatten and dignitaries. English and Indians watch as Mountbatten approaches a group of microphones identified as NBC, CBS, BBC, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins in his youthful, beguiling manner and makes the pranam to the cheering crowd. It is cut off by the sound of a door being opened, close.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We have come to crown victory with friendship -- to assist at the birth of an independent India and to welcome her as an equal member in the British Commonwealth of Nations. (A little smile.) I am here to see that I am the last British Viceroy ever to have the honor of such a reception.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICE-REGAL PALACE - EXTERIOR - DAY Jinnah stands by one of the great pillars of the immense portico. It is a break in their Independence Conference, and as he lights a cigarette, a weary Gandhi approaches him with Azad. Jinnah's anger is clearly too deep to be left at the conference table. He slaps his lighter shut and addresses Gandhi in hushed but fiercely felt words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru and Patel are approaching from the conference room, both of them looking worn and angry too. Jinnah raises his voice deliberately so Nehru will hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jinnah sneers at the idea, though he cools a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is staring at Jinnah trying to fathom the source of his anger and fear. He turns to see that Mountbatten has been standing in the open door to the conference room, as torn as Gandhi by the conflict, feeling it best controlled in formal discussion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi nods, and reluctantly the adversaries move back to the conference room. Gandhi is last through the door. He pauses by Mountbatten, a little sigh -- "How difficult, how difficult" -- then he puts a friendly hand on Mountbatten's shoulder and the two of them enter together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't give a damn for the independence of India! I am concerned about the slavery of Muslims!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not sit by to see the mastery of the British replaced by the mastery of the Hindus!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patiently, not yet believing it can't be settled) Muslim and Hindu are the right and left eye of India. No one will be slave, no one master.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world is not made of Mahatma Gandhis. (He looks at Nehru and Patel.) I am talking about the real world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The "real India" has Muslims and Hindus in every village and every city! How do you propose to separate them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where there is a Muslim majority -- that will be Pakistan. The rest is your India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a forced patience) Mohammed -- the Muslims are in a majority on two different sides of the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (acidly) Let us worry about Pakistan -- you worry about India.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, perhaps we should recommence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Featuring Godse waving a black flag and shouting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have pulled back and we see a whole gathering of Hindu youths near the entrance to the ashram. Many wave black flags. A couple of trucks that have brought them, and a car, are along the path. Kallenbach is stepping out of an old 1942 open Austin that he has put in a waiting position near the entrance to the path. The chanting shout "Death to Jinnah!" suddenly dies. The youths -- and Kallenbach -- look back toward the ashram. Featuring Gandhi's bungalow. Nehru has stepped out onto the porch and he glares at the youths. It is his presence that has silenced them. Kallenbach smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with others) Death to Jinnah! Death to Jinnah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Gandhi is rising from the floor, where his spinning wheel sits. He stops, halfway up, listening, then, a weary sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn is spinning across the room. She lifts her head as a signal to someone out of shot. Gandhi's two grand nieces, Manu and Abha, who help Mirabehn now that Ba is gone, rise quickly at Mirabehn's signal, Manu to help with his shawl, Abha to hold his sandals so that he can slip into them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's cross -- he's worried about other things. Mirabehn just smiles at it. Gandhi looks down at Abha, and taps her sharply on the top of the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods obediently, the flicker of a smile around her mouth, youthful, irrepressible. The beauty of it almost saddens Gandhi. He taps her again -- gently -- and goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God, they've stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm your grand uncle but I can still walk either of you into the ground and I don't need to be pampered this way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish your quota of spinning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Kallenbach shoos a chicken from the back seat of the Austin and dusts off the seat. He steps back out. Gandhi is approaching with Nehru and Azad, Pyarelal trails close behind. We have seen Azad and Pyarelal come out on the porch behind Nehru. As Gandhi near the car a Hindu youth with a black flag calls to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are all awed, timid even in his actual presence, and the mood of their gathering has changed altogether. Gandhi looks at the youth and the line of others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sweeps them sternly with his eyes, all his fatigue and strain showing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he lowers his head and moves on to the car, where Kallenbach holds the door for him, Nehru, Azad and Pyarelal following. Another angle. As they get into the car, we see the car that sits by the two trucks that have brought the youths. In the back seat we see two men, one of whom is Prakash (The bearded man at Gandhi's assassination).
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu -- please. Don't do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) What do you want me not to do? Not to meet with Mr. Jinnah? (Fiercely) I am a Muslim! (He stares at them, then relents.) And a Hindu, and a Christian and a Jew -- and so are all of you. When you wave those flags and shout you send fear into the hearts of your brothers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not the India I want. Stop it. For God's sake, stop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT Jinnah is on the small balcony of this elaborate room. He is looking down in a slightly supercilious manner. As usual he is impeccably dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has been looking at Gandhi, who sits on the floor of the large room some distance from him, just lifting his head from prayers. Nehru, Patel and Azad are on the same side of the room as Gandhi. They rise from prayer as Jinnah comes down the steps to them. Gandhi hesitates, then begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Jinnah has drawn himself up. His vanity is too great not to be touched by that prospect. He measures Gandhi for a moment to see that he is sincere, and when he is satisfied with that, he turns slowly to Nehru, Patel and Azad. Nehru glances at Patel. They have all been taken by surprise by the offer -- and do not feel what Gandhi feels. Nehru looks hesitantly at Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It bears the stamp of undeniable truth. Gandhi's eyes sag with the despair of a man whose last hope, whose faith, has crumbled around him. Jinnah smiles cynically, he spreads his hands "See?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stares at him numbly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, please, if you've finished your prayers, could we begin with business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear Jinnah, you and I are brothers born of the same Mother India. If you have fears, I want to put them to rest. (Jinnah listens impatiently, skeptically. Gandhi just glances in Nehru's direction.) I am asking Panditji to stand down. I want you to be the first Prime Minister of India (Jinnah raises an eyebrow of interest.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: to name your entire cabinet, to make the head of every government department a Muslim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu, for me, and the rest, (his hand gestures to Patel and Azad) if that is what you want, we will accept it. But out there (he indicates the streets) already there is rioting because Hindus fear you are going to give too much away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you did this, no one could control it. No one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is your choice. Do you want an independent India and an independent Pakistan? Or do you want civil war?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEW DELHI - EXTERIOR - DAY On a platform in the foreground Mountbatten and Nehru. A band plays the Indian National Anthem loudly and there is the roar of a tremendous crowd as the green, white and saffron flag of India is raised on the flagpole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KARACHI - EXTERIOR - DAY On a platform in the foreground Jinnah and a British plenipotentiary. A band plays the new Pakistani National Anthem loudly and there is the roar of a tremendous crowd as the white, green with white crescent, flag of Pakistan is raised on the flagpole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Silence. The little flagpole is empty, the rope dangling, flapping loosely down the pole. Gandhi sits on the porch of his bungalow, spinning. The hum of the spinning wheel. Inside we can just see Mirabehn, spinning too. But apart from that, he is alone; the whole ashram seems deserted. We hear the sound of a bell on one of the goats, fairly distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Featuring Kallenbach. He is taking the goat and tethering it near the path of the ashram. He stills the bell with his hand. As he ties it the camera angle widens and we see Margaret Bourke-White sitting on the grass, watching Kallenbach and looking off toward Gandhi's bungalow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach looks at her. Her tone criticizes more than his stilling the goat's bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach stands and looks across at her, judging, then appealing to her humanity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White grabs a clump of grass, twists it free, and sighs. She tosses the grass vaguely at the goat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kallenbach stops, staring absently at the ground ahead, then
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you being a little overprotective?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow. Tomorrow photograph him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came all this way because I believed the picture of Independence Day was of him here alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is violence, and the fear of violence, that have made today what it is... Give him the dignity of his grief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And while we're sitting here feeding goats, what will happen to all the Muslims in India and the Hindus in Pakistan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gandhi will pray for them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The camera is high (helicopter) and moving and from its position we meet and then pass over an immense column of refugees -- ten, twenty abreast -- moving down one side of the railroad track toward camera. Women, children, the sick, the aged, all burdened with bedding, utensils, household treasures, useless bric-a-brac and trudging with them every type of cart, wagon, rickshaw, pulled by donkey, camel, bike, oxen. It stretches endlessly to the horizon. Tiny green, white and saffron flags here and there indicate that it is a Hindu column and spotted through it we see people in fresh bandages, some on stretchers, sticking out like radioactive tracers in the huge artery of frightened humanity. And the camera lifts and tilts, slowly swinging to the opposite direction, and as it does, reveals another vast column across the track, several yards away, moving in the opposite direction: veiled women in purdah, the crescent flag of Muslim Pakistan here and there. As the camera levels and speeds along it, we see that this column too reaches to the horizon, that it too carries its wounded. An unbelievable flood of desperate humanity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of the vast refugee column. A woman's arms cradle a baby in swaddling. Blood has seeped through the swaddling in three or four places, some of it dried. Flies buzz around it. And suddenly we hear the woman's sobs and she rocks the baby and we know it has stopped moving, stopped breathing, and a male hand gently touches the back of the baby, checking, and the camera pans up to the face of a man. Again in extreme close shot so we cannot tell whether they are Hindu or Muslim. And the man's eyes knot, and he swings out of shot as he runs in fury and rage at the other column.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two columns -- and a howl of hate and grief! And the camera sweeps to where men are running at each other across the track, some already fighting. Knives, pangas, hatchets; women screaming and running; a besieged wagon tipped. Another angle. And as the fighting grows more fierce streams of men from each column run back to partake, but the bulk of the two columns hurries off, scrambling, running, some leaving their bundles, fleeing the melee in terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SEVERAL LOCATIONS - DAY/NIGHT A Muslim pulled through broken glass in an urban market shop./ Night: a Hindu temple daubed with blood, the bodies of women and children strewn before it; screams, the sound of fighting./ Mud and straw houses burning, figures running through them./ A city street: a truck crashes into a barricade of rickshaws and bales, and is set upon by a swarm of knife- and panga-bearing men. From the back of the truck opponents with swords and clubs leap into battle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Chaos. It and the adjoining office have been made into something like operations rooms. Military and civilian aides move back and forth. Telephones at work everywhere. A huge map on the wall is constantly having data changed by people receiving messages there. Nehru is glancing at a telex message; he turns and gives it back to the military aide who's given it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns. Patel has a message he was going to present to him. He hesitates, grins dismally, and crumples the message -- "No use." Nehru sags. He looks at Patel with haggard eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru nods solemnly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel reacts to that -- surprise, apprehension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel nods grimly -- the noisy chaos of the room. Someone shouts at Nehru, "Prime Minister!"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (fast, curt) No. There just are not that many troops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What he can!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was right. It's insane -- anything would have been better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you found him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's in Noakhali.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's tramping from village to village -- no police, no troops -- trying to quell the madness single-handedly. (He sighs, half in admiration, half in hopeless exasperation at the old man's audacity.) Maulana has gone to bring him back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In silence -- looking tragic, tired and defeated. He is sitting in his characteristic manner, staring down at the carpet before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera angle has changed. We are in
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (dull, lifeless) What you have done in Noakhali is a miracle, Bapu, a miracle, but millions are on the move -- millions. There is no way to stop it... and no one can count the dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT Patel and Azad are there and Pyarelal of course, and with them now the giant figure of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the first time we have seen him among Gandhi's intimate group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is an empty and despairing echo of Gandhi's words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has turned and seen Gandhi standing slowly. It has almost stopped him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is moving toward the door. It stops them all. Pyarelal moves tentatively to open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi turns, looks at him bleakly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In Calcutta it's like civil war. The Muslims rose and there was a bloodbath, and now the Hindus are taking revenge -- and if we can't stop it there'll be no hope for the Hindus left in Pakistan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...an eye for an eye making the whole world blind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't there any troops to spare?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tense, fragile) Nothing -- nothing. The divisions in Bombay and Delhi can hardly keep the peace now. And each fresh bit of news creates another wave of  mad... ness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could we cut all news off? I know -- NEHRU Bapu -- please. Where are you going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sounding like an old man) I don't want to hear more...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) We need your help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is nothing I can give.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Calcutta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT We are high. There are fires, the sounds of spasmodic gunfire, of looting, screams, the roar of police vehicles and occasional sirens. The camera zooms in on a poor quarter of artisan dwellings in narrow streets. Outside one of the houses is a car, an army jeep, policemen, a few soldiers and a group of people. It seems a little island of calm in a sea of wild chaos. On the roof of the house, a figure moves into the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R - TAHIB'S ROOF The figure is Gandhi. He peers down at the dark, rioting streets. Azad, Tahib, a Muslim whose house this is, Mirabehn and Pyarelal are with him along Abdul Ghaffar Khan. A police commissioner moves to Gandhi's side, demanding his attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a sudden commotion just below them and angry shouts: "Death to Muslims!," "Death to Muslims!" Gandhi peers down. His point of view. A surging gang of youths, many carrying torches, and far outnumbering the little group of police and soldiers, are shouting up at the roof. We see three or four black flags and stains of blood on many of them. A few hold knives still wet with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A feral roar goes up at the sight of Gandhi, but he stands unmoving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring Gandhi. It is a comment too grave for glibness, and Gandhi is obviously struck by the pain of it. He pauses for a moment, staring down at the youth:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes it mean the youth. For a second it makes an impact, but then the youth shouts his defiance at him and his message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An angry chorus of acclamation; when it dies
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is ambiguous, open-ended, meaning anything your mother and father would wish you to do. Tears flush from the boy's eyes and he stares at Gandhi with a kind of hopeless anguish and rage. But the impact is on the youth alone; around him the others begin to take up the chant "Death to Muslims!," "Death to Muslims!" Gandhi turns from the street. He looks at the police commissioner -- at his fatigue, his concern, his manifest respect. Gandhi musters a weary smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The commissioner looks at him, uncertain, not knowing what to do, as the angry chanting continues above the sound of rioting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, please, I don't have the men to protect you -- not in a Muslim house. Not this quarter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am staying with the friend of a friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There he is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his voice emotional, tearful) Why are you staying at the home of a Muslim! They're murderers! They killed my family!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because forgiveness is the gift of the brave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To hell with you, Gandhi!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the youth) Go -- do as your mother and father would wish you to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have lived a lifetime. If I had shunned death -- or feared it -- I would not be here. Nor would you be concerned for me.
