(He lets it sink in then he takes the commissioner's arm and moves back toward the center of the roof.) Leave me -- and take your men. (An understanding touch of the arm.) You have more important things to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY An old, inadequate hospital -- dark cavernous. Margaret Bourke- White is moving among the densely packed litter of wounded women. She is positioning herself to photograph Gandhi, who is speaking to a woman who cradles a small baby. The corridors behind him are even more packed. The few doctors and nurses hardly have room to move. Featuring Gandhi. Azad and Mirabehn are behind him as he moves on, and behind them, like a giant guardian, Abdul Ghaffar Khan. We hear "Bapu, Bapu" muttered quietly here and there. Gandhi bends to a woman whose face is bandaged and a cruel wound is half-exposed between her mouth and eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are tears in Gandhi's eyes now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the weight of his helplessness hangs on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu... Allah be with you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And with you. (He touches her wrinkled hand.) Pray... I cannot help you -- pray... pray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A streetcar (tram) crashes into a barricade of carts, rickshaws, a couple of old cars, smashing through to breach the barricade, but stopped in the end by the mass of debris. The streetcar is loaded with Indian troops and they break from the stalled vehicle to chase A gang of Hindus -- organized -- runs down the street from the troops, some dragging the bodies of victims with them. We see several Hindu black flags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - NIGHT He speaks across his desk to a senior police commissioner. The same activity going on in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An aide slips a newspaper on his desk in front of him. He doesn't look at it till the senior commissioner lowers his head and turns, accepting defeat. Then Nehru glances at the paper. In thick headlines: GANDHI: A FAST UNTO DEATH! Nehru doesn't move for a moment. Then he lifts his face slowly to his aide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The aide shakes his head -- there's no answer. Nehru lowers his head again; it is like another burden on a man who already has too many. He grips his temples... a terrible sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru thinks on it solemnly, then nods yes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) No! There will not be a Hindu Police and a Muslim Police. There is one police!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why must I read news like this in the paper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Patel. Arrange a plane. We will go -- Friday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY The sounds of rioting and looting on nearby streets, but here a mass of people are gathered. Many youths with black flags. Two black government limousines. Motorcycles. Police and soldiers. They are looking off to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TAHIB'S HOUSE It runs up the side of the building and is lined with waiting people. Nehru and Patel are climbing the stairs, moving past them almost irritably as they mutter "Nehru, Nehru," "Patel," and make the pranam to the eminent men. In the heat of the city Tahib's rooftop is still Gandhi's "home" and has become a center of activity. Azad clears someone aside and ushers Nehru and Patel under the canopy awning. Nehru pauses as he lowers his head. His point of view. Gandhi lies curled awkwardly on his side of the cot. He is writing, Pyarelal taking the pages as he finishes, both ignoring all the people, the sounds of gunfire and distant shouting, but he looks tired and tightens his jaw occasionally in pain. The camera pans. A doctor sits near the foot of the cot, Abdul Ghaffar Khan beyond him. Near the other edge of the canopied area, Mirabehn sits with Bourke-White. They are whispering quietly, but Mirabehn has stopped on seeing Nehru and she smiles a relieved greeting. She knows Gandhi's feeling for him. Bourke-White stares at him and Patel for a second and then her hand goes slowly, almost reflexively, for her camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ON GANDHI Nehru crosses and kneels so that he is almost at Gandhi's eyeline. Gandhi must take his eyes from his writing to look, and he is almost moved to tears at the sight of Nehru. His hand shakes a little as he holds it out to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi turns to pat their joined hands with his other hand. He does so with effort, and at last he sees Patel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel sits near the head of the cot so the three of them are on a level. Outside the canopied area, Bourke-White is crouched, her camera framing the three of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles and reaches to touch hands with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is despairingly sincere. But Nehru feels he has an antidote for that despair. The distant sound of an explosion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White captures the sense of elation in his face. From her discreet distance, she lowers the camera, holding it against her mouth, waiting for Gandhi's response. Gandhi nods to Nehru, accepting the news with a sad wistfulness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru isn't prepared for this resistance. He glances at Patel, and we see that they recognize that their bland conviction that they could talk him out of the fast was deeply misplaced. Nehru turns back -- this time no confidence, only concern. A forced smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles, pain etched in his eyes. He touches Nehru's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru stares at him, feeling the sudden fear that Gandhi means it. Patel, Mirabehn, Azad, Bourke-White are gripped by the same realization.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sardar... (He looks him over.) You have gained weight. You must join me in the fast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wittily, warmly) If I fast I die. If you fast people go to all sorts of trouble to keep you alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu, forgive me -- I've cheated. I could have come earlier. But your fast has helped. These last days people's minds have begun to turn to this bed -- and away from last night's atrocity. But now it is enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All that has happened is that I've grown a little thinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow five thousand Muslim students of all ages are marching here in Calcutta -- for peace. (The real point) And five thousand Hindu students are marching with them. It is all organized.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad -- but it will not be enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu, you are not so young anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry for me -- death will be a deliverance. (There is water in his eyes, but his words have the weight of a man truly determined to die.) I cannot watch the destruction of all I have lived for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT An outside broadcast truck is parked among the usual crowd, grown even larger now, and more women among them. The sounds of distant fighting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT The senior technician, in earphones, signals across to Mirabehn. She holds a microphone by Gandhi, who is lying on his side. He seems almost out of touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at her, and then the microphone. When he speaks into the microphone his voice is very weak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now we go into the streets, intercutting with Gandhi but seeing Hindus listening around loudspeakers on corners, in little eating houses, Muslim shops where people live in the back, and neighbors gathering defensively in groups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans back, exhausted. Mirabehn is looking at him; she starts to sing softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi, his eyes closed, takes it up in his weak, croaking voice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Each night before I sleep, I read a few words from the Gita and the Koran, and the Bible... (we intercut with Bourke-White and those on the roof watching) tonight I ask you to share these thoughts of God with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the books are there, but he does it from memory of course) I will begin with the Bible where the words of the Lord are, "Love thy neighbor as thyself"... and then our beloved Gita which says, "The world is a garment worn by God, thy neighbor is in truth thyself"... and finally the Holy Koran, "We shall remove all hatred from our hearts and recline on couches face to face, a band of brothers."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Lead Kindly Light, amidst the circling gloom..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "The night is dark, and I am far from home, Lead thou me on..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Two police motorcycles lead a black limousine to a stop before Tahib's house. The crowd now gathered is very large. More mixed than before but still predominantly of youths, many still with black flags. Nehru gets out of the limousine with a Muslim leader, a tough- looking man who carries himself with the authority and power of a mobster (Suhrawardy). And they start to go up the outside stairs. Suddenly we hear the shout "Death to Gandhi!," "Death to Gandhi!" And Nehru turns, pushing past Suhrawardy fiercely and going back onto the street. He runs at the crowd, where the shout comes once more from the back. His face is wild with anger and shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd has spread from him all along the street; they stand against the walls of the houses staring at him, terrified to move. We see, just in passing, the frightened, apprehensive faces of Godse, and near him, Apte and Karkare. Nehru stands, staring at them all, his face seething with anger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hysterically) Who dares say such things! Who?! (And he is running at them and they spread in fear.) Come! Kill me first! Come! Where are you?! Kill me first!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY We are featuring a copy of Life Magazine. On the cover is a picture of rioting men fighting and diagonally a cut-out of Gandhi lying on his cot. The caption reads: "An Old Man's Battle." As the magazine starts to be opened, it is suddenly put to one side. Another angle. Mirabehn is rising, leaving the magazine at her feet. She moves to Nehru and Suhrawardy as Azad ushers them into the canopied area. Abdul Ghaffar Khan sits quietly in the background. Mirabehn speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru looks across at Gandhi. The doctor, who is testing Gandhi's pulse yet again, glances at him -- no encouragement -- and moves away. Nehru moves to the side of the cot and Gandhi smiles weakly and holds out a hand, but he is in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks up at Suhrawardy, who nods. Gandhi looks back at Nehru. There is no hint of him changing his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi smiles whimsically, he touches him again but there is no change in his attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nehru looks at him hopelessly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: His pulse is very irregular -- the kidneys aren't functioning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu, I have brought Mr. Suhrawardy. It was he who called on the Muslims to rise; he is telling them now to go back to their homes, to lay down their arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (personally) Think what you can do by living -- that you cannot do by dying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleadingly) What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a moment) That the fighting will stop -- that you make me believe it will never start again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY A huge crowd, some smoke in distant buildings, some damage near to help us know this is still Calcutta, and all is not yet at peace. The camera sweeps over the crowd, past the loudspeakers on their poles. We see surly knots of belligerent rowdies, mostly young, but not all, hanging on the fringes as we move over the heads of the mass of listening people to a platform where Nehru speaks. Azad, Suhrawardy, and others sit on the floor behind him. We have heard his voice over all this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Sometimes it is when you are quite without hope and in utter darkness that God comes to the rescue. Gandhiji is dying because of our madness. Put away your "revenge." What will be gained by more killing? Have the courage to do what you know is right. For God's sake, let us embrace like brothers...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT Featuring the Muslim leader Suhrawardy, leaning against a wall, watching an action out of shot with evident tension. We hear a little clank of metal. Another angle. There are five men facing Gandhi. They wear black trousers and black knit vests. There are thongs around their arms that make their bulging muscles seem even more powerful. They are Hindu thugs (Goondas). Their clothes are dirty -- and they are too -- but they are laying knives and guns at Gandhi's feet. Mirabehn, Azad, Pyarelal, the doctor and others on the roof watch fascinated, a little frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi is looking at him, testing, not giving or accepting anything that is mere gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Goondas stand. They glance at Suhrawardy; he smiles tautly and they start to leave, but one (Nahari) lingers. Suddenly he moves violently toward Gandhi, taking a flat piece of Indian bread (chapati) from his trousers and tossing it forcefully on Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn and Azad start to move toward him -- the man looks immensely strong and immensely unstable. But Gandhi holds up a shaking hand, stopping them. Nahari's face is knotted in emotion, half anger, half almost a child's fear -- but there is a wild menace in  that instability.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi stares at him, breathless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is as though the man has told him of some terrible self- inflicted wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost reflexively he holds his hand out to indicate the height of his son. He glares at Suhrawardy and then back at Gandhi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is sobbing, but in his anger it seems almost as though he means to kill Gandhi in retaliation. A long moment, as Gandhi meets his pain and wrath. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nahari sneers, but there is just a flicker of desperate curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his hand to the height Nahari has indicated as his son's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nahari has listened. His face almost cracks -- it is a chink of light, but it does not illumine his darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now the light falls on Nahari. His face stiffens, he swallows, fighting any show of emotion; then he turns to go. But he takes only a step and he turns back, going to his knees, the sobs breaking again and again from his heaving body as he holds his head to Gandhi's feet in the traditional greeting of Hindu son to Hindu father. A second, and Gandhi reaches out and touches the top of his head. Mirabehn watches. The Goondas watch. Suhrawardy watches. Finally
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is our promise. We stop. It is a promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go -- try -- God by with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat! I am going to hell -- but not with your death on my soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only God decides who goes to hell...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stiffening, aggressive)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I killed a child... (Then an anguished defiance) I smashed his head against a wall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a fearful whisper) Why? Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tears now -- and wrath) They killed my son -- my boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Muslims killed my son... they killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a way out of hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find a child -- a child whose mother and father have been killed. A little boy -- about this high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and raise him -- as your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only be sure... that he is a Muslim. And that you raise him as one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently, exhaustedly) Go -- go. God bless you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: GANDHI NEAR DEATH/NEHRU GOES ON FAST

direction.raw_text: - POLICE STATION - CALCUTTA - EXTERIOR - NIGHT Trucks with riot squads (shields and truncheons) in place, but they are lounging, waiting. There is silence, and air of somnolence. Some of the riot squad lounge in little groups around the courtyard. A distant cough. Featuring a senior riot squad officer dressed and ready for action. He it is who coughed. He coughs again, clearing his throat. A police sergeant stands by him, both are reading the front page of a paper the senior riot squad officer holds. We see two huge lines of headline: GANDHI NEAR DEATH/NEHRU GOES ON FAST. In one of the trucks one of the men offers another a cigarette. A telephone rings sharply, inside. The senior riot squad officer and the sergeant run in as engines start; the men run to their places, lower visors, headlights go on!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY A constable mans the telephone. He listens as the senior riot squad officer and the sergeant run to him tensely. The sound of the great doors opening in the courtyard, more engines revving up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances up at the senior riot squad officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs at the senior riot squad officer and hands the information slip to another constable behind the desk. The sergeant sighs, and moves to the outside door. We hear him bellow, "Stand down." The constable hangs up and sighs heavily. The senior riot squad officer shakes his head, and turns and walks slowly to the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir, yes, sir, (He holds up his hand to the senior officer) "Wait."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (writing, from the phone) Accident, "Christie crossroads," a lorry and a rickshaw. Yes, sir, I have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - POLICE STATION - EXTERIOR - NIGHT The senior riot squad officer and the sergeant stand in the doorway as the engines die. The men relax... the silence returns. A dog barks distantly, disturbed by the noise... A bird caws once or twice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't have believed it, Mr. Gupta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sergeant, it's a bloody miracle...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT It lies in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY Mirabehn is bent over Gandhi. He is curled almost in the fetal position, his face looking wan and sunken. For the first time there is silence, no explosions, no distant shouts, no gunfire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the police commissioner, Suhrawardy, two doctors, Abdul Ghaffar Khan, and some others. Nearer Gandhi, behind Mirabehn, are Nehru, Patel, Azad and Pyarelal. Gandhi turns to Mirabehn, his face shaking, peering into her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His weary eyes look at her; he looks up slowly to Azad. Azad nods "It's true." Then Patel
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi looks at Nehru. Nehru just nods tautly. Gandhi looks down, then lifts his head to Azad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The relief brings water to their eyes and grins to their faces. Nehru bends to Gandhi. Gandhi holds his hand out to him, and Nehru clutches it. Then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a joke in their way with each other and Gandhi's eyes light, his smile comes. But it is tired. He puts his other hand over Nehru's and Nehru lowers his head to it, crying silently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu, there's been no fighting -- anywhere. It has stopped -- the madness has stopped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is foolish if it is just to save the life of an old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... no. In every temple and mosque they have pledged to die before they lift a hand against each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maulana, my friend, could I have some orange juice... Then you and I will take a piece of bread together...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, Bapu, it is not difficult. I have fasted only a few hours and I accomplished what you could not do in as many days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - DAY As in the opening sequence -- but a few minutes earlier. The crowd is beginning to gather for the evening prayers. We see a tonga or two, a gardener opening the gate to the garden, three policemen standing, talking idly among themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INTERIOR - DAY Laughter. Gandhi is eating muli; he holds his head back to capture the lemon juice. We hear the click of a camera
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Manu hands him a cloth and he wipes his hands. Another click of a camera. He is not fully recovered, but well on the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is all light and for fun. We get a wide-angle shot now and see that Bourke-White is shooting one of her favorite subjects again. She is enjoying the banter, as is Mirabehn, who is spinning quietly to one side of the room, and Patel, who sits cross-legged like Gandhi on the floor. Pyarelal is working on papers with him but grins at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she shoots him again, as he hands the cloth back to Manu. Abha is sitting next to Manu, looking at a collection of pictures of Gandhi, obviously Bourke-White's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is wry, but waspishly chiding. Abha suddenly holds a picture up for Gandhi to see. It's one of him, ears wide, eyes round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi taps her on the head with his finger as she smiles. But Bourke-White has looked from Patel to Gandhi, clearly shaken by the implication in Patel's words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abha has signaled to the cheap watch dangling from his dhoti. He glances at it, and holds his arms out. The two girls help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is photographing his getting-up and leaning on the two girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves off, but has a sudden thought and turns to Patel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patel nods soberly and Gandhi starts for the door, Bourke- White moving with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has passed her, he's in the doorway. We see the crowd at the end of the garden, where the light of the day is beginning to soften. He turns, teasing in his slightly flirtatious way with women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shoots him against the door -- the crowd milling distantly, waiting -- then she lowers her camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns; the last words have betrayed the smile on his face; they have a painful sense of truth about them. Bourke-White watches as he moves into the garden toward the crowd in the distance. She turns to Mirabehn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an observation -- and a question. Mirabehn accedes gravely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourke-White stares at her, then turns to look out at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mirabehn nods, but she keeps on spinning and tries to sound cynically resigned but her innate emotionalism keeps breaking through in her voice and on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is laced with pain. Bourke-White turns and looks out at Gandhi -- so tiny, so weak as he walks between his "props." He has now reached the end of the garden and is moving among the crowd assembled there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That is how you eat muli.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the photographer) I'm not sure I want to be remembered that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, with luck you may not be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he'll be remembered for tempting fate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mickey Mouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You really are going to Pakistan, then? (Gandhi shrugs, and she chides too) You are a stubborn man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a grin, in the mood of their "flirtation") I'm simply going to prove to Muslims there, and Hindus here, that the only devils in the world are those running around in our own hearts -- and that's where all our battles ought to be fought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what kind of a warrior have you been in that warfare?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a very good one. That's why I have so much tolerance for the other scoundrels of the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ask Panditji to -- to consider what we've discussed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (of the photographs) Enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a plea) One more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a temptress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just an admirer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing's more dangerous, especially for an old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a sadness in him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He thinks he's failed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? My God, if anything's proved him right, it's what's happened these last months...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am blinded by my love of him, but I think when we most needed it, he offered the world a way out of madness. But he doesn't see it... and neither does the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BIRLA HOUSE - EXTERIOR - TWILIGHT Gandhi is moving forward in the crowd, one hand resting on Manu, the other on Abha. He makes the pranam to someone, the crowd is bowing to him, some speaking, and we also see the crowd from his point of view -- "Bapu," "God bless you," "Thank you -- thank you." He turns to a very old woman, who makes a salaam to him. Gandhi touches her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smiling, he turns back. A jostling, the sound of beads falling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gandhi turns to the person; he makes the pranam. Full shot. Godse is making the pranam to him and he suddenly, wildly draws his gun and fires. The camera closes on Gandhi as he staggers and falls, the red stain of blood seeping through his white shawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Manu and Abha bend over him, silent in their first shock. The sound of panic and alarm begins to grow around them, they suddenly scream and begin to cry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Allah be with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to someone) Brother, Bapu is already late for prayers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, God... oh, God...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bapu! Bapu!
dialogue.name: dialogue
